questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe thigh pain. A mass is palpated below the inguinal ligament, diagnosing a strangulated femoral hernia. What structure would be immediately lateral to the herniated structures?
questions.solution:
Option A: Femoral Vein

  • A femoral hernia is situated below the inguinal ligament and is present in females only as the femoral ring through which the abdominal contents protrude is larger in females
  • If the hernia gets strangulated, it can cause a lot of pain and has to be surgically treated
  • In the case of a femoral hernia, the contents of the abdomen are pressed through the femoral ring, which is directly lateral to the lacunar ligament and just medial to the femoral vein.
  • The femoral vein would be immediately lateral to the femoral hernia.

Option B: Femoral Artery

  • The femoral artery is lateral to the femoral vein

Option C: Pectineus muscle

  • The pectineus muscle is situated inferiorly to the femoral ring

Option D: Femoral Nerve

  • The femoral nerve is most lateral and is lateral to the femoral artery and vein

questions.text: What problems are likely to be observed during the physical examination of a 23-year-old man presenting to the emergency department with a deep, bleeding stab wound to the pelvis, where an MRI reveals transection of the right ventral primary ramus of L4?

choices.text: Reduction or loss of sensation from the medial aspect of the leg
Loss of the Achilles tendon reflex
Weakness of abduction of the thigh at the hip joint

questions.solution:
Option A: Reduction or loss of sensation from the medial aspect of the leg

  • The ventral branch of L4 contains sensory and motor nerve fibres. A stab wound can lead to loss of sensitivity of the dermatome innervated by this segment.
  •  The L4 spinal nerve innervates the  L4 dermatome, which comprises the Medial buttock, lateral thigh, medial leg, dorsum of the foot, and big toe.
  • So if the L4 spinal nerve is damaged, there will be a loss of sensation over the medial aspect of the leg

Option B: Loss of Achilles reflex

  • The loss of the Achilles tendon reflex is mainly related to an S1 deficit. As S1 is responsible for the motor component of the Achilles reflex and its damage of  S1 can cause loss of  Achilles reflex

Option C: Weakness of abduction at the thigh at the hip joint

  • The obturator internus and the gluteus medius and minimus muscles are responsible for the thigh's abduction and are innervated by the nerves L4, L5, and S1 (where L5 is usually dominant).

Option D: Inability to evert the foot

  •  Nerves L5, S1 and S2, are responsible for the eversion of the foot (S1 dominant)

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with erectile dysfunction is prescribed tadalafil, which inhibits phosphodiesterase type 5. After taking the medication, venous blood exiting the affected tissues will first enter which structure?
questions.solution:
Option B: Deep dorsal vein

  • Tadalafil relaxes smooth muscles in the corpora cavernosa of the penis. This allows the blood to enter the sinusoids.
  • The filling of blood compresses the venous system of corpora cavernosa; thus, constriction of veins causes reduced outflow of blood from the corpora cavernosa. This causes the erection of the penis.
  • Penis uses three venous systems to drain blood out of its tissues. These are the superficial venous system, intermediate venous system, and deep venous system. 
  • The superficial venous system drains the skin of the penile shaft and the subcutaneous tissues of the penis.
  • The intermediate venous system drains the corpus spongiosum, glans, and distal two-thirds of the penis.
  • The deep venous system containing the deep dorsal vein drains the corpora cavernosa of the penis as tadalafil acts on the corpora cavernosa of the penis, so the venous blood from there gets drained into the deep dorsal vein of the penis.

Option A: External pudendal vein

  • The external pudendal vein receives blood from the skin and subcutaneous tissues of the penis but not the erectile tissues.

Option C: Internal pudendal vein

  • The internal pudendal veins do not directly receive blood from the erectile tissues.
    • Small veins of the deep dorsal vein may communicate with the internal pudendal vein in the pelvis.

Option D: Superficial dorsal vein

  • The superficial dorsal vein of the penis drains the skin and subcutaneous tissues of the penis
    • It joins the external pudendal vein, which, in turn, joins the great saphenous vein.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male came to the emergency department complaining of right upper quadrant pain and 2 episodes of vomiting since morning. Tests revealed elevated levels of all liver enzymes, and you ordered CT suspecting a stone. The patient is diagnosed with choledocholithiasis, a stone in the common bile duct. You prepare for surgery knowing the following anatomical considerations are true, except:

choices.text: It opens 10 cm distal to the pylorus
Portal vein lies posterior to it
It usually opens into the duodenum separate from the main pancreatic duct

questions.solution:
Option D: It usually opens into the duodenum separate from the main pancreatic duct

  • This is an incorrect statement.
  • The common bile duct joins the pancreatic duct to form the hepatopancreatic duct, which opens into the 2nd part of the duodenum (10 cm distal to the pylorus) at the major duodenal papilla.

Option A: It opens 10 cm distal to the pylorus

  • The common bile duct joins the pancreatic duct to form the hepatopancreatic duct, which opens into the 2nd part of the duodenum (10 cm distal to the pylorus) at the major duodenal papilla.

Option B: Lies anterior to IVC

  • The common bile duct lies anterior to the inferior vena cava.
  • It passes from the head of the pancreas.
  • It is divided into the retroduodenal, supraduodenal, intraduodenal, and retroperitoneal segments.

Option C: Portal vein lies posterior to it

  • The hepatic duct lies in front and to the right, the hepatic artery to the left, and the portal vein behind and between the duct and artery.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents to the emergency department with chest discomfort and drooling after eating a chicken steak. He has a history of ingesting a caustic solution 5 years ago. Physical examination shows he can talk and breathe without effort, with vague and constant chest pain. Chest X-ray reveals no subcutaneous emphysema. Endoscopy confirms a retained meat bolus 23 cm from the upper incisors. Which structure is located at this site?
questions.solution:
Option B: Superior mediastinum

  • This patient has a history of caustic ingestion, now presenting with drooling and chest pain due to obstruction of chicken steak in the esophagus at the level of superior mediastinum, which is the most likely site of stricture in this patient.
  • The aortic arch leaves an imprint on the right anterior edge of the esophagus in the superior mediastinum at about 23(±3 cm) beyond the upper incisors.
  • This is the 2nd most common location of injury and stricture formation.

Option A: Posterior mediastinum

  • The left main bronchus compresses the esophagus in the posterior mediastinum.
  • Although this area can also be damaged from caustic ingestions, it resides lower down, at 30 cm beyond the incisors.

Option C: Anterior mediastinum

  • The anterior mediastinum is limited laterally by the pleura, posteriorly by the pericardium, the sternum, the left transverse thoracic muscle, and the fifth, sixth, and seventh left costal cartilages contain only the superior and inferior Sterno-pericardial ligaments and remnants of the thymus.
  • These structures do not come into contact with the esophagus.

Option D: Epigastrium

  • The abdominal portion of the esophagus is variable in length (0.5 - 2.5 cm).
  • The esophagus and the stomach junction lie inferior to the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: A 74-year-old male complains of bad breath, food regurgitation during sleep, weight loss, and difficulty swallowing solids. Barium swallow study reveals abnormalities. What is depicted in the provided radiograph?

choices.text: Defect in the muscular wall of the laryngopharynx

questions.solution:
Option D: Defect in the muscular wall of the laryngopharynx

  • The radiograph shows a Zenker's diverticulum, also known as pulsion-pseudo-diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Results from herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle(dehiscence),
  • Focal weakness in the laryngopharynx(hypopharynx) at the normal cleavage plane between the fibers of the two parts of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle (superior to the cricopharyngeus muscle and inferior to the thyropharyngeus muscle).

Option A: Achalasia

  • Absence of oesophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower oesophageal sphincter (LES).
  • Barium swallow shows a bird's beak appearance.
  • Oesophageal manometry is used to diagnose achalasia and shows incomplete LES relaxation, high resting LES pressure, and absent oesophageal peristalsis.

Option B: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

  • Characterized by heartburn, regurgitation, and dysphagia caused by excessive retrograde movement of acid-containing gastric secretions.
  • An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is used to diagnose GERD.

Option C: Diffuse oesophageal spasm

  • Characterized by contractions of normal amplitude that are uncoordinated, simultaneous, or rapidly propagated.
  • Barium swallow shows diffuse uncoordinated contractions of the oesophagus.

questions.text: Which structure on the anterior abdominal wall is likely to be defective in degenerative malformation of the transversalis fascia during development ?

choices.text: Sac of a direct inguinal hernia

questions.solution:
Option B: Deep inguinal ring

 

 

The picture above shows that:

  • The deep inguinal ring lies in the transversalis fascia, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.
  • The defective structure in the anterior abdominal wall leads to degenerative malformation of fascia transversalis.
  • The deep (internal) inguinal ring is a defect in the transversus abdominis fascia that allows the contents to enter the canal and leave the abdomen before extending obliquely, medially, and inferiorly through the canal to exit at the superficial (external) inguinal ring.
  • The deep or internal ring is located just above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament and lateral to the epigastric vessels.
  • The deep ring is formed by the transversalis fascia, which provides the posterior covering of the contents of the inguinal ring.

 

Option A: Superficial inguinal ring

  • The superficial inguinal ring is in the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle.

Option C: Inguinal ligament

  • The inguinal ligament and the anterior wall of the inguinal canal are formed by the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle. So, it doesn't have any role in the degeneration malformation of the transversalis fascia.

Option D: Sac of a direct inguinal hernia

  • The peritoneum forms the sac of a direct inguinal hernia.
  • It is not formed by fascia transversalis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old diabetic male came into your clinic complaining of sudden painless vision loss in his left eye, along with flashes and floaters. He says a curtain has fallen on his eyes. You do a fundoscopy and see the retina ballooning forward. A diagnosis of retinal detachment is made. Explain to your intern that the site of detachment is:

choices.text: Between the inner nuclear layer and the outer nuclear layer
Between the pigment epithelial layer and the layer of outer segments of rods and cones

questions.solution:
Option D: Between the pigment epithelial layer and the layer of outer segments of rods and cones

  • The site of retinal detachment is between the pigment epithelial layer and the layer of outer segments of rods and cones;
  • It corresponds to the intra-retinal space between the inner and outer layers of the optic cup.
  • There is a space between the neurosensory retina and retinal pigment epithelium called sub-retinal space. The adhesions between these layers are relatively weak, making them susceptible to detachment.
  • Retinal detachment occurs when fluid from the vitreous compartment passes through a retinal hole and separates the pigment epithelial layer from the layer of outer segments of rods and cones.

Option A: Within the outer plexiform layer

  • Retinal detachment occurs at the junction of the pigment epithelial layer and the layers of rods and cones.
  • There is no potential space within the outer plexiform layer.

Option B: Within the inner plexiform layer

  • Retinal detachment occurs at the junction of the pigment epithelial layer and the layers of rods and cones.
  • The inner plexiform layer is not a potential site for detachment.

Option C: Between the inner nuclear layer and the outer nuclear layer

  • Retinal detachment occurs at the junction of the pigment epithelial layer and the layers of rods and cones.
  • These two layers are not continuous, making it the least favorable option.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with dizziness, tinnitus, numbness in the left arm, intermittent double vision, and a significant difference in blood pressure between both arms. Which of the following arteries has a reversal in its blood flow in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ipsilateral vertebral artery

  • This patient with a difference in BP between both arms, numbness of the left arm, and symptoms of decreased cerebral blood flow (tinnitus, dizziness, double vision) is most likely suffering from the subclavian steal syndrome.
  • In subclavian steal syndrome, there is retrograde flow in the ipsilateral vertebral artery due to an ipsilateral subclavian artery block proximal to vertebral artery origin.

Option B: Contralateral vertebral artery

  • The subclavian artery stenosis results in lower pressure in the distal subclavian artery and upper limb ischemia.
  • Consequently, blood flows from the contralateral vertebral artery to the basilar artery and then retrogrades down the ipsilateral vertebral artery away from the brainstem.

Option C: Ipsilateral subclavian artery

  • Subclavian steal syndrome occurs due to stenosis of the ipsilateral subclavian artery. Consequently, blood flow is reversed in the ipsilateral vertebral artery to supply the upper limb.

Option D: Contralateral subclavian artery

  • The contralateral subclavian artery has normal anterograde blood flow in subclavian steal syndrome.

questions.text: As an intern in the general medicine department, you recall a patient in the Neurology department undergoing a neurological examination where the resident asked her to close her eyes, place a 'key' on her hand, and identify/recognize it. What aspect of neurological function does this test evaluate?
questions.solution:
Option A: Posterior column

  • Stereognosis is the ability to recognize the form and texture of an unseen familiar object.
  • It is a function of the posterior column (dorsal column-medial lemniscus system).
  • The dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway (DCML) is a sensory pathway of the central nervous system. It conveys the sensation of fine touch, vibration, pressure, two-point discrimination, and proprioception (position) from the skin and joints.
  • It is also called the posterior column - medial lemniscus pathway and consists of two parts. The dorsal (posterior) column runs from the spinal cord to the medulla, and the medial lemniscus, runs as a continuation of the dorsal column, from the medulla to the cortex.
  • In the cortex, the DCML pathway projects onto the primary somatosensory cortex of the postcentral gyrus. The dorsal column is formed by two large fasciculi (bundles of nerve fibres) running through the posterior spinal cord: fasciculus gracilis and cuneatus.

Functions of Dorsal column- Medial lemniscus system

  1. Pressure
  2. Vibration
  3. Tactile discrimination
  4. Stereognosis
  5. Conscious proprioception

Option B: Posterior spinocerebellar tract

  • The dorsal spinocerebellar tract (posterior spinocerebellar tract) conveys unconscious proprioceptive information from proprioceptors in the skeletal muscles and joints to the cerebellum.

Option C: Spino-olivary tract

  • Located in the anterior funiculus of the spinal cord, the spino-olivary tract enables the transmission of unconscious proprioception.
  • It is also involved in balancing.

Option D: Spinothalamic tract

 

  • Spinothalamic tract carries pain and temperature sensations from body.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man who fell off a roof presents with a fixed, dilated left pupil and a hematoma on his head. What type of suture is found between the bones involved in the skull fracture of the parietal bone in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Serrate

  • This is a case of parietal bone fracture caused due to history of falls from the roof.
  • Serrate suture is the suture in which the edges of bones present a saw-toothed appearance.
  • The serrate suture is present between the two parietal bones, which is known as a sagittal suture.
  • The frontonasal suture is also a serrate suture which is continuous with the frontomaxillary suture across the top of the bridge of the nose.
  • This suture is present between the superior border of the nasal bones and the nasal process of the frontal bone.

Option B: Denticulate

  • Denticulate suture: The margins present teeth with tips broader than the roots, e.g., lambdoid suture.

Option C: Squamous 

  • Squamous suture: Here, the edges of bones are united by overlapping, e.g., the suture between the parietal bone and the squamous part of the temporal bone.

Option D: Plane

  • Plane suture: The borders are plane and joined by sutural ligaments, e.g., a suture between palatine bones of two maxillae.

questions.text: Where do the primordial germ cells develop?

choices.text: Develops in the gonads at week 4 of embryonic development
Develops in the yolk sac at week 4 of embryonic development
Develops in the gonads at month 5 of embryonic development
Develops in the yolk sac at month 5 of embryonic development

questions.solution:
Option B: Develops in the yolk sac at week 4 of embryonic development

  • The above figure A shows the development of primordial germ cells at the endodermal wall of the yolk sac, and figure B shows the migration of the primordial germ cells toward the gonadal ridge.
  • On day 4, after fertilization, the advanced morula changes to a blastocyst, which contains blast cells and a cyst-like cavity. The blast cells are divided into outer trophoblastic cells and inner embryoblast cells. The outer trophoblastic cells are further divided into cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast cells. These cells help in the development of the placenta.
  • The inner embryoblasts form two germ layers (hypoblast and epiblast), the dorsal amniotic cavity and the ventral yolk sac cavity.
  • Primordial germ cells (PGCs) are isolated from epiblasts at the end of week 2 and are migrated to the endodermal wall of the yolk sac at week 4. They migrate towards the genital ridge and reach there at the end of week 5 to form gametes
  • After 6 weeks of intrauterine life, sexual differentiation begins in the genital tubercle and two genital swellings. At first, the gonads are sexually indifferent. In human males, a 'testis determining factor (TDF) gene on the sex-determining region of the Y chromosome (SRY) initiates the development of testes. Testes secrete testosterone converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) which ultimately leads to the formation of male internal and external genitalia.
  • The absence of a sex-determining region on the Y (SRY) chromosome leads to the development of ovaries. As there is no Y chromosome in females, females develop ovaries instead of testes.

Option A: Develops in the gonads at week 4 of embryonic development

  • The primordial germ cells form in the yolk sac at the start of the 4th week. Gonads develop after the 6th week.

Option C: Develops in the gonads at month 5 of embryonic development

  • After 6 weeks of intrauterine life, sexual differentiation begins in the genital tubercle and two genital swellings. The external genital formation is under the influence of androgens (i.e., dihydrotestosterone DHT)
  • The gonads are formed by the end of the 6th week.

Option D: Develops in the yolk sac at month 5 of embryonic development

  • The yolk sac formation is at an early stage of embryoblast development, around 1-2 weeks.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought by his mother for progressive difficulty in walking. He started to walk at 11 months. He is at the 50th percentile for weight and the 60th percentile for height. He eats a well-balanced diet. Four months ago, his mother noticed he was having difficulty getting up from the floor. On examination, his calves are hypertrophied bilaterally. He uses his hands on his thighs to support himself while slowly getting up from the floor. Which of the following statements is true about this child’s condition?

choices.text: It is an X- linked recessive disorder
Skeletal muscle wasting occurs due to abnormalities of the contractile filaments
Muscle wasting occurs in the pelvic region only
It is a form of titinopathy

questions.solution:
Option A: It is an X- linked recessive disorder

  • This child is suffering from Duchene muscular dystrophy
  • Duchenne’s muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder.
  • There is a genetic defect in the dystrophin gene; it results in the deficiency of the protein dystrophin (427-kDa) in skeletal muscle.
  • There is progressive muscle paresis and atrophy, which starts in the proximal lower limbs (pelvic girdle) and extends to the upper body and distal limbs as the disease progresses.
  • Calf pseudohypertrophy is also present due to the replacement of muscles with fat tissue.
  • The affected individuals arrive at a standing position by supporting themselves on their thighs and then using their hands to "walk up" the body until they are upright (Gower sign)

Option B: Skeletal muscle wasting occurs due to abnormalities of the contractile filaments

  • Actin and myosin are the major contractile filaments in muscles.
  • Dystrophin is a structural protein in muscle, and this condition occurs due to the absence of this protein and not due to its abnormality.

Option C: Muscle wasting occurs in the pelvic region only

  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a severe type of muscular dystrophy that primarily affects boys.
  • Muscle weakness usually begins around the age of four and worsens quickly.
  • Muscle loss typically occurs first in the thighs and pelvis, followed by the arms.

Option D: It is a form of titinopathy

  • Titinopathy is a form of muscular dystrophy associated with defects in the TTN gene.
  • It is one of the most severe forms of inherited muscular dystrophy.
  • Duchene muscular dystrophy is associated with a genetic defect in the dystrophin (DMD) gene; it results in the deficiency of the protein dystrophin (427-kDa) in skeletal muscle.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with celiac disease visited the physician because of difficulty seeing at night. She complained about frequent, foul-smelling stools on further investigation. Stool analysis revealed a high content of partially digested fat. Deficiency of which of the following causes her condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Vitamin A

  • Malabsorption syndrome is a condition characterised by the failure of digestion and absorption in the small intestine. Malabsorption syndrome is generally caused by Crohn’s disease, Tropical sprue, Steatorrhea, and Celiac disease.
  • Here, the woman presents with malabsorption syndrome and undigested fat in the stool, so a deficiency of the fat-soluble vitamin is suspected.
  • Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin that can be excreted in the faeces and fat in persons with celiac disease and other diseases that cause malabsorption of intestinal contents.
  • Retinal, which is necessary for the synthesis of rhodopsin in the rods of the retina, can be deficient when there is a lack of Vitamin A.
  • Decreased rhodopsin levels in the rods can lower the retina’s sensitivity to light, thus causing night blindness.
  • Night blindness is due to the deficiency of vitamin A, which is essential for the function of rods. Vitamin A deficiency occurs because of the following causes:
    • A diet containing less vitamin A
    • Decreased absorption of vitamin A from the intestine.
  • Vitamin A deficiency causes defective cone function. Prolonged lack leads to anatomical changes in rods and cones and degeneration of other retinal layers. So, the retinal function can be restored only if treatment is given with vitamin A before the visual receptors degenerate.

Option A: Amino Acids

  • Amino Acids have nothing to do with the patient’s symptoms..

Option B: Glucose

  • Glucose deficiency does not cause Night Blindness.

Option D: Vitamin B12

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency causes Anemia

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a history of nonproductive cough and runny nose from the last 1 day. On physical examination, the patient appears comfortable. He is afebrile with a blood pressure of 110/80 mm Hg, heart rate of 50/minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on ambient air. The patient has mild pharyngeal oedema but no jugular venous distension. Auscultation of the heart reveals a slow heart rate, but it is regular with normal first and second heart sounds having no murmurs. Auscultation of bilateral lungs reveals clear breath sounds. There is neither skin rash nor pedal oedema. Admission electrocardiogram shows a 2nd-degree heart block, atrial rate of 90/minute, and ventricular rate of 50/minute. On ECG, the PR interval is the time from the onset of the P wave to the start of the QRS complex. It reflects conduction through the AV node. The normal PR interval is between 120 – 200 ms (0.12-0.20s) in duration (three to five small squares). PR interval is constant in the?

choices.text: None of the varieties of heart block.

questions.solution:
Option B: Mobitz type II block

  • Mobitz type II of the second-degree block has a constant PR interval, with every ‘nth' beat dropped; that is, inconsistently, one impulse from atria does not reach ventricles.
  • It is almost always a disease of His or Purkinje's distal conduction system bundle.
  • It is characterized on a surface ECG by intermittently non-conducted P waves not lagged by PR prolongation and not followed by PR shortening.
  • There is often a fixed number of non-conducted P waves for every successfully conducted QRS complex, and this ratio is often specified in describing Mobitz II blocks.
  • The medical significance of this AV block is that it may progress rapidly to a complete heart block, in which no escape rhythm may emerge.
  • In the third variety of the second-degree block, atria-to-ventricle excitation is a fixed small number ratio (e.g., 3:2). For instance, every third impulse from the SA node will fail to reach the ventricles.

Option A: Mobitz type I block

  • Mobitz type I of the second-degree block shows lengthening PR interval in successive beats, with finally in one beat P wave not followed by QRS complex.

Option C: All types of second-degree blocks

  • The PR interval does not remain constant in all types of heart bundle blocks.

Option D: None of the varieties of heart block

  • It fluctuates in every variety.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of breathlessness and fatigue. His pulse is 80/min, and his blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. His ECG is normal. On echocardiography ejection fraction of this patient is increased. Increase in ejection fraction (EF) is accompanied by decrease in which of the following?
questions.solution:
• An increase in ejection fraction means that a higher fraction of the end-diastolic volume is ejected in the stroke volume (e.g., because of the administration of a positive inotropic agent - Positive inotropic agents act by increasing [Ca2+] within the myocardial cells, thereby enhancing the force of contraction and decreasing ESV).
  • When this situation occurs, the volume remaining in the ventricle after systole, the end-systolic volume, will be reduced.
  • Cardiac output, pulse pressure, stroke volume, and systolic pressure will be increased.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is the most suitable for measuring resistance in small airways?
questions.solution:
Option D: FEV25-75%

  • FEV timed: the percentage of total air exhaled in the given time. E.g., FEV1 is the air exhaled in the 1st second of forceful expiration. Reduced airway obstruction (FEV, <70%).
  • FEV1: 80 – 83 %
  • FEV2: 90 – 93 %
  • FEV3: 97 %

In exhaled air:

  • The first 1/3rd - is air from large airways
  • Next 1/3rd - from small airways
  • Last 1/3rd – from alveoli: Air from small airways is the mid – 1/3rd faction of expired air, i.e., the 25- 75th percent of air

Exhaled = FEV 0.25 – 0.75

  • FEV0.25 – 0.75 = MMFR (maximum mid-expiratory flow rate) ⇒reduction indicates small airway obstruction.

Option A: FEV1

  • This is the amount of air expelled during the first second.
  • Increased airway resistance reduces FEV1.
  • However, FEV1 does not measure airway resistance.

Option B: Closing volume

  • Closing is the volume towards the end of forced expiration, after which some airways have effectively closed.
  • It does not measure airway resistance.

Option C: Total lung capacity

  • The TLC measures the total capacity of the lungs.
  • Although increased airway resistance in obstructive diseases affects TLC, TLC does not define the amount of air resistance.
  • It is reduced in restrictive lung diseases while increased in obstructive lung diseases.

questions.text:
Arrange the following physiological events in the sequence that they occur within the perpheraal chemoreceptors in response to being exposed to hypoxia:


	Reduced conductance of hypoxia-sensitive K+ channels
	Ca2+ influx
	Decreased K+ efflux
	Exocytosis
questions.solution:
Option C: A→C→B→D

  • Hypoxia is defined as low levels of oxygen in your body.
  • An increase in central respiratory drive characterizes the initial response to hypoxia.
  • It occurs due to the activity of the peripheral and central chemoreceptors.
  • Arterial oxygen receptors may involve oxygen-sensitive potassium channels in these chemoreceptors' membranes.
  • Once the chemoreceptors detect hypoxia, various mechanisms are detected to increase oxygen delivery.
  • Several neurotransmitters like adenosine, nitric oxide, GABA, and serotonin have been implicated in the hypoxic ventilator drive.
  • The image given below demonstrates the physiologic sequence of events in hypoxia.

questions.text: The nephron is the functional unit of the kidney. A nephron is made of two parts: a renal corpuscle and a renal tubule. The tubule is further divided into straight and convoluted tubules. Which of the following statement below functionally differentiates the distal tubule of the nephron from the Proximal tubule?

choices.text: The distal nephron has a more negative intraluminal potential than the proximal tubule.
The distal nephron is less responsive to aldosterone than the proximal tubule.
The distal nephron is more permeable to hydrogen ions than the proximal tubule.
The distal nephron secretes more hydrogen ions than the proximal tubule does.

questions.solution:
Option A: The distal nephron has a more negative intraluminal potential than the proximal tubule.

Proximal and distal convoluted tubule:

  • The site of action of acetazolamide is the proximal convoluted tubule, and the site of action of thiazides is the distal convoluted tubule.
  • The distal nephron has a negative lumen potential because it is poorly permeable to negatively charged ions.
  • Therefore, negatively charged ions, mainly Cl−, remain when Na + is absorbed, generating a negative intraluminal potential.
  • Although a similar situation occurs in the proximal tubule, the proximal tubule has a higher permeability for Cl− and therefore does not develop as much negative intraluminal potential.
  • The distal nephron is less permeable to hydrogen than the proximal tubule.
  • Aldosterone increases Na + absorption from the distal nephron but does not affect the proximal tubule.
  • K + is absorbed from the proximal tubule and secreted from the distal nephron.
  • Although the amount of H + excreted daily is determined by the amount of H + secreted in the distal nephron, the proximal tubule secretes much more H + than the distal nephron.
  • Almost all of the H + secreted in the proximal tubule, however, is associated with reabsorption of HCO3. absorbed

Option B: The distal nephron is less responsive to aldosterone than the proximal tubule.

  • Aldosterone is the main mineralocorticoid steroid hormone produced by the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex in the adrenal gland.
  • It is essential for sodium conservation in the kidney, salivary glands, sweat glands, and colon.
  • Aldosterone receptor sites exist on the cell surface of vascular endothelial cells distinct from the classical mineralocorticoid receptors and insensitive to glucocorticoids.
  • It acts through the mineralocorticoid receptor.

Option C: The distal nephron is more permeable to hydrogen ions than the proximal tubule.

  • H+ and HCO3 - are filtered freely by the nephron, and under most conditions, little or no HCO3 - is excreted.
  • That means that essentially 99% or more of the filtered load of HCO3 - is reabsorbed by the renal tubule.
  • Specific regions of the renal tubule (see below) can secrete H+.
  • Reabsorption takes place mainly in the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron.
  • Nearly all the water, glucose, potassium, and amino acids lost during glomerular filtration reenter the blood from the renal tubules.

Option D: The distal nephron secretes more hydrogen ions than the proximal tubule.

  • Hydrogen Ions Are Secreted by Secondary Active Transport in the Early Tubular Segments.
  • The epithelial cells of the proximal tubule, the thick segment of the ascending loop of Henle, and the early distal tubule all secrete H+ into the tubular fluid by sodium-hydrogen counter-transport
  • The kidneys have two main ways to maintain acid-base balance - their cells reabsorb bicarbonate HCO3− from the urine back to the blood, and they secrete hydrogen H+ ions into the urine.
  • Also, by adjusting the amounts reabsorbed and secreted, they balance the bloodstream's pH.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease presents to the emergency complaining of left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath for the last 6 hours. The patient has a BMI of 23 kg/m2. He weighs 70 kg and has a calculated BSA of 1.7 square meters. What would be the cardiac index of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: 3.2 L/min/m2

  • Based on the clinical history of ischemic heart disease and the symptoms at the presentation, the patient is suspected to be suffering from myocardial infarction. His BMI is 23kg/m2 9=(normal range).
  • Cardiac index 
    • The index is usually calculated using the following formula:
    •  
    • Where 
      • CI = Cardiac index 
      • BSA = body surface area 
      • SV =  Stroke volume 
      • HR =  Heart rate 
      • CO = cardiac output 
      • The average human being who weighs almost 70 kilograms has a body surface area of about 1.7 square metres, which means that the normal average cardiac index for adults is about 3 L/ min/m2 of body surface area.
      • 3.2 L/ min/m2 is the nearest possible answer.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency department with low blood pressure and dyspnea for the last 1 hour. He is a known case of ischemic heart disease and has a low cardiac output. He has been a known hypertensive for the last four years and diabetic for the last two years. In order to measure the cardiac output in this patient using Fick's principle, estimation of which of the following is required?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

Direct fick method

  • Calculate cardiac output by measuring myocardial oxygen consumption. 
  • Named after Adolf fick and the fick's principle
  • Cardiac output =

    The correct answer is 4. All of the above.

    Explanation of Options:

  • O2 content of arterial blood: This is an essential component for measuring cardiac output using Fick's principle. The principle relies on the measurement of the difference in oxygen content between arterial and venous blood. By knowing the oxygen content of arterial blood, you can determine how much oxygen is being delivered to the tissues.

  • O2 consumption per unit time: O2 consumption is another critical factor in Fick's principle. This represents the rate at which oxygen is being extracted from the blood by the tissues. It is necessary to accurately determine how much oxygen the body is utilizing.

  • Arterio-venous O2 difference: This refers to the difference in oxygen content between arterial and mixed venous blood. It reflects how much oxygen is extracted by the tissues as blood circulates through the systemic circulation. It is an integral part of Fick's principle calculation.

  • All of the above: This is the correct answer. Fick's principle involves the measurement of oxygen content, oxygen consumption, and arterio-venous oxygen difference. All three factors are necessary to calculate cardiac output, which represents the volume of blood pumped by the heart per unit of time.

questions.text: A researcher studies a neuronal synapse that uses GABA as its neurotransmitter. He observes that input to its synapse makes the membrane potential even more negative than the normal intracellular potential leading to inhibition of the postsynaptic membrane. Which of the following electrical events is characteristic of this synaptic interaction?

choices.text: A neurotransmitter agent that selectively opens ligand-gated chloride channels is the basis for an inhibitory postsynaptic potential.
Because the Nernst potential for chloride is about -70 mV, chloride ions tend to move out of the cell along its electrochemical gradient.
A neurotransmitter that selectively opens potassium channels will allow potassium to move into the cell.
Increased extracellular sodium concentration usually leads directly to an inhibitory postsynaptic potential.

questions.solution:
Option A: A neurotransmitter agent that selectively opens ligand-gated chloride channels is the basis for an inhibitory postsynaptic potential.

  • An action potential is an electrical impulse moving along a neuron cell. The presynaptic neuron sends signals to the postsynaptic neuron by releasing chemical neurotransmitters in response to the incoming electrical impulses.
  • The postsynaptic action potential is the modification of the charge of the neuronal membrane as a result of receiving a chemical transmission of an action potential from the presynaptic neuron.
  • An inhibitory postsynaptic potential is a type of synaptic potential that reduces the action of a postsynaptic neuron. The influx of negatively charged ions causes a transient hyper-polarisation of the postsynaptic membrane and lowers the membrane potential of neurons. When the membrane potential becomes more negative than normal, the neuron is inhibited, and thus the neuron's action of transmitting signals is stopped. 
  • A neurotransmitter can influence postsynaptic cell activity via ligand-gated ion channels. It binds to these channels on the postsynaptic membrane and causes a conformational change, which leads to the opening of the ion channels, allowing them to flow across the cell membrane.
  • Various kinds of neurotransmitters can cause inhibitory postsynaptic potential. GABA and glycine are the two main inhibitory neurotransmitters.
  • GABA normally induces hyperpolarisation of the postsynaptic neuron, resulting in an inhibitory postsynaptic potential. It increases the conductance of chloride channels allowing the negatively charged ions to enter and causing the cell to hyperpolarize and become farther from generating an action potential.       

Option B: Because the Nernst potential for chloride is about -70mV, chloride ions tend to move out of the cell along its electrochemical gradient

  • The normal resting membrane potential of the neuronal cell is -65 mV. When chloride's Nernst potential/equilibrium potential is -70mV, the chloride ions leave the cell to move the membrane potential towards -65 mV. It would result in a depolarization of the membrane potential. However, the overall effect is still inhibitory because once the potential reaches -65 mV, the driving forces acting on chloride would keep them at that membrane potential. Thus, making it difficult for the cell to depolarise further and generate an action potential.  

Option C: A neurotransmitter that selectively opens potassium channels will allow potassium to move into the cell

  • When a neurotransmitter binds the ligand-gated potassium ion channel, it will cause the movement of positively charged potassium ions into the cell. It will depolarise the membrane making it more negative and farther from the action potential.

Option D: An increase in the extracellular sodium concentration usually leads directly to an inhibitory postsynaptic potential

  • The sodium ion is critical for the action potential in nerve cells. At rest, extracellular sodium concentration is much higher than its intracellular concentration. During this stage, the neuronal membrane exhibits a resting membrane potential of about -65mV with no movement of ions across the membrane. Hence, hyperpolarisation is absent, and the inhibitory potential is not attained.

questions.text: Which of the following endocrine disorder is a result of molecular Mimicry?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hashimotos’ thyroiditis

  • The cause of autoimmune thyroid disease is not completely known by medical science. However, genetic and environmental factors are thought to play a role.
  • Hashimoto thyroiditis is caused by an abnormal immune response that produces antithyroid antibodies against the thyroid follicular cells, microsomes, and TSH receptors.
  • Molecular Mimicry
    • A new theory explains how an immune system can be “tricked” into attacking the thyroid cells.
    • Yersinia resides in intestinal bacteria and has been found to share identical amino acid sequences when compared to the TSH receptor, thyroglobulin, thyroperoxidase [TPO], and Sodium Iodide symporter [NIS].
    • Borrelia burgdorferi has also been implicated
    • This explains the increased antibodies found on lab panels in Hashimoto's patients.
    • These are the antibodies to thyroglobulin and thyroperoxidase (TPO) commonly used by the doctor to confirm a diagnosis of Hashimotos Thyroiditis.

TSH Receptor Antibodies

Comes in 2 varieties.

  1. The first type, the TSH receptor, is stimulated → Grave’s Disease and hyperthyroidism.
  2. In the second variety, the TSH receptor is blocked → Hashimotos’s disease.
  • Although both Graves and Hashimotos have a common origin in the molecular mimicry theory
  • Grave's causes a hyperthyroid state, and Hashimoto's causes a hypothyroid state.
  • Graves and Hashimotos antibodies can coexist in the same patient, and one can transform into another.

Option A: Addison’s disease

  • Addison's disease occurs most frequently due to primary atrophy or injury of the adrenal cortices. Most cases are caused by autoimmunity against the cortices; however, gland hypofunctioning is also frequently caused by tuberculous destruction of the adrenal gland or invasion of the cortices by cancer.

Option B: Diabetes mellitus

  • Diabetes mellitus type II is caused by the development of insulin resistance to endogenous insulin. An autoimmune molecular mimicry does not cause it.
  • On the other hand, type I diabetes mellitus occurs due to a molecular mimicry-mediated autoimmune response leading to damage of the beta-cells of the islets of the pancreas.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option D: Hypoparathyroidism

  • Most commonly caused by surgical injury during thyroid surgery leading to decreased parathyroid hormone levels.

questions.text: A skeletal muscle cell is stimulated, and concentrations of different ions are recorded in the different compartments of the cell. It is observed that after the contraction phase, calcium ions move into the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Which of the following is true regarding the transport of Ca++ across a membrane?

choices.text: Maintains a high intracellular Ca++ concentration

questions.solution:
Option D: Requires hydrolysis of ATP

  • Calcium ions are maintained at a very low concentration gradient intracellularly. It is achieved by pumping calcium ions extracellularly or sequestration into the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  • Calcium ions are transported against the concentration gradient, and energy is required for this process.
  • For each molecule of hydrolyzed ATP, these pumps exchange one H+ for one Ca2+.

Option A: It is a passive transport

  • The transport of calcium ions involves the utilization of energy which is not a characteristic of passive transport.
  • Calcium transport occurs by secondary active transport.

Option B: It is a symport

  • In calcium pumps, calcium is the driven ion and always moves in a direction opposite to that of the driving ion. This type of transport is called antiport.
  • Symport involves the movement of driving and driven ions in the same direction.
  • It is an antiport or counter transport; occurring as Na+/ Ca++ exchanger. 

Option C: Maintains a high intracellular Ca++ concentration

  • Calcium is present in low intracellular concentrations for the physiological functioning of various cellular processes.
  • Calcium is extruded from the cell or pumped from the cytosol into the endoplasmic reticulum to maintain a low intracytoplasmic concentration of Ca++. It is primarily aimed at maintaining a low cytosolic Ca++.

questions.text: Which transporter is responsible for the absorption of fructose?
questions.solution:
Option D: GLUT-5

  • As the patient’s liver enzymes are normal and her symptoms seem to correlate with her intake of fruit juices, most likely her problem is an inability to absorb fructose.
  • Lactase deficiency can be ruled out since the removal of cow’s milk from her diet did not eliminate the problem.
  • The primary transporter of fructose in the intestine is GLUT-5 and a deficiency in GLUT-5 would cause inability to absorb fructose in the gut. The fructose accumulated in the intestine will be fermented upon by bacteria to produce various gases, including hydrogen, as well as organic acids.
  • The most common carbohydrate sources for infant formula include lactose, sucrose & corn syrup. Fructose is present in sucrose and corn syrup also.

Option A: GLUT-2

  • GLUT-2 is involved passive absorption of glucose in Liver, pancreas and intestine. And its deficiency causes Fanconi Bickel Syndrome (Glycogen storage disease type XI)
  • Clinical features of this disease are
    • Hepatorenal glycogen accumulation
    • Growth retardation
    • Polyuria and polydipsia
    • Fasting hypoglycemia but post prandial hyperglycemia resembling diabetes

Option B and C: SGLT-1 and SGLT-2

  • SGLT-1 and SGLT-2 are secondary active transporters of glucose and galactose in intestine and kidneys, hence will not affect fructose absorption.
  • Deficiency of SGLT-1 and SGLT-2 causes glucose–galactose malabsorption and familial renal glycosuria respectively.

questions.text: During a metabolic pathway, when the high concentration of the end product of the pathway inhibits its own synthesis, the method of regulation is known as:
questions.solution:
Feedback regulation

  • In feedback regulation, the end-product (thyroid hormones) directly controls its own rate of synthesis by suppressing earlier stimulating hormones. This is called a feedback loop.

Complementary regulation

  • Complementary regulation means several factors acting similarly (complementing each other) in regulating a pathway, which is not the case in this example.

Feed-forward regulation

  • Feed forward mechanisms reflect the availability of a precursor to activate a downstream step of a pathway, such as with toxin excretion pathways (only activated when toxin is present, and the rate of toxin excretion increases as the toxin level increases).

Compartmentation

  • Compartmentation is a collection of enzymes within a specific compartment of the cell (e.g. cytoplasm, mitochondria peroxisome, lysosome).

Negative regulation

  • Although negative regulation means inhibition of an enzyme, the best answer in this case is feedback regulation, as the end-product of the pathway is the effector that is regulating the pathway.

Learning Objective: An inhibition of activity of an enzyme upstream in a pathway by the end-product of the same pathway is called as feedback regulation. It is one of the most common method of regulation of metabolic pathway.

questions.text: A patient presented to casualty with nausea and vomiting. Intravenous glucose was given & the patient recovered. After a few months, the patient presented with the same complaints. Blood glutamine was found to be increased. Also, uracil levels were raised. what is the likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency:

  • In the urea cycle, ammonia combines with carbon dioxide and forms carbamoyl phosphate. The carbamoyl phosphate combines with ornithine and forms citrulline. The enzyme responsible for the reaction is carbamoyl phosphate synthase and ornithine carbamoyl transferase, respectively.
  • If the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase is deficient, it leads to elevated levels of ammonia in the blood and carbamoyl phosphate from in liver mitochondria .
  • The excess carbamoyl phosphate from mitochondria enters the cytoplasm and takes part in pyrimidine synthesis leading to increased uracil synthesis (see fig).
  • Orotic acid, OMP, and UMP are all increased in OTC defect.

  • Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency presents with the symptoms of refusal to eat, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, seizures, etc.
  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder. It is the most common urea cycle disorder.
  • It is characterized by decreased levels of blood urea nitrogen.
  • CPS-II (carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-II) is an enzyme involved in pyrimidine synthesis, not in the urea cycle.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CPS-I deficiency:

  • CPS-I enzyme is involved in the urea cycle. It is present in the mitochondria.
  • It leads to elevated ammonia levels in the blood, which can have toxic effects on the brain.
  • It does not lead to elevated levels of orotic acids in the blood.

Option B - Arginosuccinate synthetase deficiency:

  • Arginosuccinate synthase enzyme is a part of the urea cycle. It is involved in the synthesis of argininosuccinate via the enzyme argininosuccinate synthase.
  • If citrulline is increased, then it means that Arginosuccinate synthetase is the deficient enzyme.

Option C - CPS-II deficiency:

  • CPS-II is involved in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine.
  • It is activated by ATP and is inhibited by UMP.
  • Its deficiency is associated with the decreased synthesis of pyrimidine.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child had normal growth and development for the first few months, but growth started deteriorating gradually along with symptoms such as deafness, blindness, atrophied muscle, inability to swallow, and seizures. A cherry red macula was also noticed in both eyes during the fundus examination. Suspecting sphingolipidosis, the physician tested for globosides and gangliosides levels and found that both were increased. Based on this finding, what is the most accurate diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Sandhoff s disease

  • The child is exhibiting the symptoms of either Tay–Sachs or Sandhoff s disease, both of which are sphingolipidoses. However, in Tay Sach's disease, only gangliosides will be increased, and globosides degradation should be normal. But in Sandhoff's disease, both globoside and gangliosides will accumulate.

Option B: Tay Sach's Disease:  refer to explanation of A

Option C: Gaucher's disease 

  • Most common Lysosomal Storage Disease
  • Enzyme deficient – Gluco-cerebrosidase
  • Substrate accumulated: Glucosyl Ceramide
  • C/F
    • No cherry red spots
    • Bony pain, pathological fractures
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • No Mental Retardation

ERT (Enzyme Replacement Therapy) is available.

Option D: Fabry's disease

  • Fabry’s disease is a X-linked recessive disorder characterized by deficiency of alpha galatoceramidase enzyme resulting in accumulation of CeramideTrihexoside or Globotriosyl Ceramide.
  • Patient presents with symptoms such as Triad of peripheral neuropathy, Angiokeratoma and Hypohidrosis

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is inhibited by the drug allopurinol, prescribed for patients with gouty arthritis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Xanthine oxidase

Gout

  • Gout is caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals within the joints, mainly involving the big toe
  • It is caused by either overproduction of uric acid or under-excretion of uric acid crystals by kidneys.                     
  • Gout can be treated by decreasing the levels of uric acid production to prevent the formation of urate crystals in joints.  

Allopurinol

  • Allopurinol is an inhibitor of the xanthine oxidase enzyme.

  • The administration of allopurinol is an effective treatment of Gout because it decreases the amount of uric acid produced, which in turn alleviates the formation of sodium urate crystals.

Option A: Adenosine deaminase

  • Adenosine deaminase facilitates the conversion of deoxyadenosine to deoxyinosine.
  • ​​​​​​​Its deficiency causes severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

Option C: Uricase

  • Uricase is involved in the formation of Allantoin from uric acid.
  • It is not present in humans.

Option D: AMP deaminase

  • AMP deaminase is involved in purine metabolism, where it causes the deamination of amino acids.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents to the doctor's office complaining of fever and a greyish-white membrane on the pharynx. His immunization history is unknown. On examination significant cervical lymphadenopathy is found. After establishing the diagnosis, the physician explains that the causative organism for this patient's condition inhibits protein synthesis in the cell by ADP-ribosylation of the elongation factor. Which of the following is the source of ADP-ribose for the ADP-ribosylation reaction?
questions.solution:
ADP-ribosylation

  • NAD+ acts as the source of ADP-ribose.
  • Different bacterial toxins affect ADP ribosylation of different proteins. as shown below:

questions.text: A full-term female infant is brought to the outpatient department complaining of failure to thrive. On physical examination, she has hypotonia, small muscle mass, severe head lag, and decreased weight gain. Her lab finding denotes persistent acidosis (pH 7.0 to 7.2) and highly elevated lactate, pyruvate, and alanine levels. Thiamine administration did not alleviate the lactic acidosis. Which of the following enzyme is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pyruvate dehydrogenase

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is a mitochondrial enzyme complex linking glycolysis and the TCA cycle.
  • The elevated levels of pyruvate, lactate, and alanine in blood indicate that there is a block in the pathway leading from pyruvate toward the TCA cycle. It shows a most probable deficiency in pyruvate dehydrogenase which can cause a buildup of pyruvate.
  • Elevated pyruvate gets shunted to lactate and alanine via LDH and ALT. Thus, increased lactate and alanine levels in the blood would be expected as the pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency causes a buildup of pyruvate.
  • As the enzyme PDH is deficient, increasing its cofactor will be useless in treating the disease.
  • So, thiamine administration cannot make up for the enzyme deficiency.
  • Pyruvate has three fates other than conversion to acetyl-CoA by pyruvate dehydrogenase:

Options A and D: Glucose 6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase and Pyruvate kinase

  • Pyruvate kinase is glycolytic enzyme and its deficiency will cause hemolysis.
  • It is 2nd most common human enzyme deficiency (1st most common deficiency is Glucose 6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency of HMP pathway).
  • In both Pyruvate Kinase & G6PD deficient patients presents with hemolysis.

Options C and E: Pyruvate carboxylase and PEP carboxykinase

  • Both enzymes are involved in gluconeogenesis, so deficiency of these two will lead to fasting hypoglycemia

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes in the citrate shuttle provides the NADPH required for fatty acid and cholesterol biosynthesis reactions?
questions.solution:
Do not confuse malic enzyme with malate dehydrogenase.
Malate dehydrogenase Malic enzyme
  • Produces NADH
  • Produces NADPH

Malic enzyme is used in the citrate shuttle and provides NADPH for fatty acid synthesis. For details of citrate shuttle refer to attached treasure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the biochemical changes seen in patients with scurvy?

choices.text: Reduced hydrogen bond formation in collagen

questions.solution:
Option B: Reduced hydrogen bond formation in collagen.

This patient's signs and symptoms are highly consistent with vitamin C deficiency, also known as scurvy.

  • The patient developed scurvy due to a lack of vitamin C in his diet.
  • Vitamin C plays the role of a coenzyme in the hydroxylation of proline and lysine, while protocollagen is converted to collagen.
  • The hydroxylation reaction is catalyzed by lysyl hydroxylase (for lysine) and prolyl hydroxylase (for proline). This reaction is dependent on vitamin C, molecular oxygen, and alpha-ketoglutarate.

  • The lack of hydroxyproline reduces the stability of the collagen because of reduced hydrogen bonding capabilities within the collagen triple helix.
  • Apart from bleeding gums, vitamin C deficiency can also cause anemia, myalgia, bone pain, corkscrew hair, and poor wound healing.
  • The only effective treatment for scurvy is vitamin C supplementation.

Option A: Reduced synthesis of collagen

  • Reduced synthesis of collagen would result in diseases like osteogenesis imperfect.
  • It is due to a mutation in type 1 collagen.
  • It results in weak bones and irregular connective tissue.

Option C: Increased hydrogen-bond formation in collagen

  • Vitamin C deficiency results in decreased hydrogen bond formation in collagen.

Option D: Reduced disulfide-bond formation in collagen

  • The lack of vitamin C does not affect the disulfide-bond formation required to initiate triple-helix formation within the cell.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child is brought to the emergency department due to difficulty breathing and confusion for 2 hours. He worked on the farm alongside his father to spray pesticides onto plants. The clinician diagnoses him with cyanide poisoning. Which of the following citric acid cycle compounds is most likely to be depleted first due to cyanide poisoning?
questions.solution:
Option B: NAD

  • Cyanide inhibits complex IV of ETC. and is probably the most potent inhibitor of ETC.
  • It exerts its effect by binding to Fe3+ of cytochrome oxidase (Complex IV) and blocking its function.
  • ETC is involved in the oxidation of most cellular NADH to regenerate NAD. If ETC is inhibited, NADH accumulates.
  • NADH accumulation leads to the depletion of NAD.
  • As a result, the citric acid cycle (TCA) is affected because each TCA cycle requires 3 NAD (for Isocitrate Dehydrogenase, alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and Malate Dehydrogenase).

Option A: Aconitase

  • Aconitase is a TCA cycle enzyme that catalyzes the isomerization of citrate to isocitrate without NADH.
  • Fluoroacetate and fluorocitrate are competitive inhibitors of aconitase.

Option C: Citrate

  • Citrate is formed by condensing acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate in the first step of TCA by the enzyme citrate synthase.
  • It does not require any product of ETC.
  • Hence, its production will not be affected.

Option D: Acetyl-CoA

  • Acetyl-CoA is starting material for the TCA cycle and is produced from pyruvate by dehydrogenation reaction, using NAD as an electron acceptor.
  • However, acetyl CoA can also be produced from other substrates, such as amino acid catabolism and fatty acid oxidation.
  • Therefore, its production will not be affected much as compared to NAD.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the hospital with complaints of acute abdominal discomfort, nausea, and vomiting. Her family history revealed that the girl belongs to a family of potters, and she participates in the pottery process. Her father was also diagnosed as a case of lead poisoning. The patient's history revealed that she had severe abdominal pain about a year ago, was diagnosed with acute appendicitis, and underwent an appendectomy. However, the pain persisted, and the patient was diagnosed with lead poisoning due to a family history of lead poisoning. However, she did not receive the recommended therapy. Which of the following is the most likely pathogenesis of hypochromic anaemia due to lead poisoning in this patient?

choices.text: Lead blocks transferrin receptors of erythroid precursors
Binding of lead to transferrin, inhibiting the transport of iron
Inhibition of enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis
Inhibiting breakdown of ferritin into hemosiderin

questions.solution:
Option C: Inhibition of enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis

  • This patient is most likely suffering from lead poisoning from chronic exposure to lead from participating in pottery activities.
  • Lead poisoning is caused by the accumulation of lead in the body.
  • The spectrum of clinical presentation is variable, and the features range from:
    • Constipation
    • Symptoms of encephalopathy such as confusion, memory loss, and developmental delay
    • Fatigue
    • Weakness
    • Paresthesia and peripheral nephropathy
    • Microcytic anaemia.
    • Burton lines (a thin blackish-blue line along the gums)
    • Lines on long bones as shown in the x-ray below:

  • Inhibition of enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis is the exact mechanism for the development of microcytic anaemia.
  • The steps involved in the synthesis of the heme are summarized in the image below:

 

Option A: Lead blocks transferrin receptors of erythroid precursors

  • This is not the mechanism of microcytic anaemia due to lead poisoning.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect
  • Inhibition of enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis is the exact mechanism for the development of microcytic anaemia.

Option B: Binding of lead to transferrin, inhibiting the transport of iron

  • This is not the mechanism of microcytic anaemia due to lead poisoning.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect
  • Inhibition of enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis is the exact mechanism for the development of microcytic anaemia.

Option D: Inhibiting breakdown of ferritin into hemosiderin

  • This is not the mechanism of microcytic anaemia due to lead poisoning.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect
  • Inhibition of enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis is the exact mechanism for the development of microcytic anaemia.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 5-day history of fever, fatigue, and red spots on her body. Physical examination shows pallor, petechiae, and a maculopapular rash over the trunk and extremities. Laboratory studies show a haemoglobin concentration of  7 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 2000/mm3, a platelet count of 40,000/mm3, and a reticulocyte count of 0.2%. A bone marrow aspirate shows hypocellularity. Match the following based on the severity of different types of the pathology described above


	
		
			
			CRITERIA
			
			
			TYPES OF APLASTIC ANEMIA
			
		
		
			
			1. Absolute Neutrophil count < 200/µL
			
			
			A. Severe
			
		
		
			
			2. Only Hypocellularity (+)
			
			
			B. Very severe
			
		
		
			
			3. Absolute Neutrophil count < 500/µL
			
			
			C. Non-severe
questions.solution:
Option D: 1-B 2-C 3-A

  • Aplastic anaemia can be of three types:

    • Non-severe Aplastic anaemia –patients having only Hypocellularity in the bone marrow <25% with blood picture not meeting any criteria. 

    • Severe Aplastic anaemia - 

  • Criteria for diagnosing severe Aplastic anaemia:

    • Bone marrow cellularity<25%

    • BLOOD COUNT – Out of the three parameters, at least two should be present.

    • Reticulocyte <60,000/μL

    • Platelet <20,000/ μL

    • Absolute neutrophil count < 500/ μL

  • Very Severe Aplastic Anaemia-

    • Criteria for diagnosing Very Severe Aplastic anaemia:

      • Bone marrow cellularity<25%

      • Reticulocyte <60,000/μL

      • Platelet <20,000/ μL

      • Absolute neutrophil count < 200/ μL (MOST ESSENTIAL)

Option A: 1-B 2-B 3-C

  • These options do not match the criteria.

Option B: 1-B 2-A 3-C

  • These options do not match the criteria.

Option C: 1-A 2-B 3-C

  • These options do not match the criteria

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl who is a known case of thalassemia visits to undergo a blood transfusion. Post transfusion, the patient has mildly elevated body temperature and generalized pruritis. Ideally, which of the following should be transfused in children suffering from thalassemia?
questions.solution:
Option C: Saline washed packed RBC

  • Saline-washed RBCs are specially indicated in conditions requiring repeated transfusion.
  • It is advised that washed, leukocyte-poor red blood cells (RBCs) be transfused over 1-2 hours at a rate of 8-15 mL RBCs per kg of body weight.
  • It is preferred in the management of babies suffering from thalassemia and paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.

Option A: Packed RBC

  • It is generally indicated in patients with very low blood haemoglobin levels, but for those requiring repeated transfusion, the saline-washed form is far safer.

Option B: Platelet-rich plasma

  • Transfusing platelets to a patient with a very low haemoglobin level secondary to thalassemia is not an appropriate option and would not yield any benefit.

Option D: Whole blood

  • It is indicated in the following cases:
    • Massive haemorrhage
    • Coagulopathy
    • Rapid correction of anaemia

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying the infections causing overactivity of intracellular receptors like Nod Like Receptors causing inflammasome activation by activating Caspase 1 and Caspase 11, leading to fever and cell death, respectively. Other morphological features involve cellular swelling and inflammation. Which of the following processes is being studied by them?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pyroptosis

  • Pyroptosis is a highly inflammatory form of programmed cell death in cells infected by microbes.
  • It involves the activation of caspase-1, which cleaves the precursor form of IL-1 to generate biologically active IL-1.
  • Caspase-1, along with closely related caspase-11, also cause the death of the infected cell.
  • Also called caspase 1-dependent cell death.

Option A: Necrosis

  • Necrosis is an irreversible tissue injury that results in cellular death and inflammation.
  • Typically caused by cellular swelling and damage (oncosis) due to tissue ischemia.
  • In contrast to apoptosis, necrosis involves the rupture of the cellular membrane and is generally not considered physiologic.

Option B: Necroptosis

  • Necroptosis: - It is caspase-independent programmed cell death.
  • therefore this option is incorrect

Option C: Apoptosis

  • A process of programmed cell death.
    • Characterized by destroying cellular contents with an intact cell membrane and minimal inflammation.
    • The mitochondrial pathway (Intrinsic) leads to the activation of the initiator caspase-9, and the death receptor pathway (Extrinsic) to the initiator caspases-8 and 10.

  • Apoptosis is a type of programmed cell death that is carried out by a set of intracellular protease enzymes known as caspases, which are activated via two pathways:
    • 1. The extrinsic (death receptor) pathway involves the activation of caspases brought about either by the binding of certain ligands to their receptors (e.g., FasL to Fas) or by cytotoxic T cells introducing proteases (e.g., perforin, granzyme B) into cells. The ligand-receptor complex activates the initiator caspase 8, and the proteases activate the initiator caspase 10.
    • 2. The intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway involves the activation of caspases by a wheel-like structure known as an apoptosome. This pathway is initiated by DNA injury (e.g., radiation, toxins) or the withdrawal of proliferating cellular factors (e.g., IL-2), which activates pro-apoptotic factors (BAX and BAK) and inhibits anti-apoptotic factors (Bcl-2). Pro-apoptotic factors increase mitochondrial membrane permeability, thus releasing cytochrome C, which then binds to APAF-1 (apoptotic protease activating factor 1), forming an apoptosome that activates the initiator caspase 9.
    • 3. Common pathway: The initiator caspases activate the executioner caspases (3,6,7), which then cause nuclear fragmentation and cytoskeletal disintegration, resulting in cell shrinkage and membrane blebbing. These blebs carry disintegrated cellular material break away from the cell, forming apoptotic bodies phagocytosed by macrophages.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents in the outpatient department with the complaint of having a fever and begins expectorating large amounts of sputum, which is mucopurulent. Sputum cultures are positive for Gram-positive diplococci. Which of the given inflammation mediators provides potent chemotactic factors for the directed migration of inflammatory cells into the alveolar air spaces of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: N-formylated peptides

  • Chemotactic factors are substances that stimulate cell migration. The strongest chemotactic factors for leukocytes at the injury site are:

               1. Complementary proteins (e.g., C5a)

               2. low molecular weight N-formylated peptides

               3. Products of arachidonic acid (AA) metabolism (especially LTB4).

Option A: Bradykinin

  • Bradykinin involves in bronchoconstriction and vasodilation.

  • It mediates inflammation by increasing vascular permeability.

Option B: Histamine

  • Histamine is released by mast cells and is responsible for an allergic response.

  • It plays a role in airway obstruction through bronchial secretion, smooth muscle contraction and airway mucosal oedema.

 Option C: Myeloperoxidase

  • Myeloperoxidase is a leukocyte-derived enzyme.

  • It is responsible for catalyzing the formation of a number of reactive oxidant species.

questions.text: You're researching the prevention of reinfection from mutated Covid -19 by immune cells, and memory cells can protect the recovered patients. You decide to use a marker which is also known as a pan-T lymphocyte marker. Which of the following is that marker?
questions.solution:
Option B: CD 3

  • CD 3 is present in both B and T cells. It is also known as a pan-T-lymphocyte marker.

CD 3:

  • CD3 (cluster of differentiation 3) is a protein complex and T cell co-receptor that is involved in activating both the cytotoxic T cell (CD8+ naive T cells) and T helper cells (CD4+ naive T cells). It is composed of four distinct chains.
  • In mammals, the complex contains a CD3γ chain, a CD3δ chain, and two CD3ε chains.
  • These chains associate with the T-cell receptor (TCR) and the CD3-zeta (ζ-chain) to generate an activation signal in T lymphocytes.
  • The TCR, CD3-zeta, and the other CD3 molecules constitute the TCR complex.

Option A: CD 20

  • CD20 is a B cell marker.
  • It is not found in T cells.

Option C: CD 19

  • B-lymphocyte antigen CD19, also known as CD19 molecule, B-Lymphocyte Surface Antigen B4, T-Cell Surface Antigen Leu-12 and CD3, is a transmembrane protein that in humans is encoded by the gene CD19.
  • In humans, CD19 is expressed in all B lineage cells

Option D: CD 25

  • CD25 signalling regulates the function and stability of peripheral Foxp3+ regulatory T cells derived from the spleen and lymph nodes
  • Also known as Interleukin-2 receptor alpha chain.

questions.text: A 9 Yr old girl child came with complaints of thickening of the skin below the neck region and arms, which the parents noticed last week. The patient was started on Steroid therapy, and her condition was improving with it. Anti-topoisomerase I is a marker of the disease being described here. What is your Provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Systemic sclerosis

  • Scleroderma, also known as systemic sclerosis, is a groupof rare diseases that involve the hardening and tightening of the skin.It may also cause problems in the blood vessels, internal organs and digestive tract.
  • Scleroderma is often categorized as "limited" or "diffuse," which refers only to the degree of skin involvement. Both types can involve any of the other vascular or organ problems. Localized scleroderma, also known as morphea, affects only the skin.
  • While there is no cure for scleroderma, treatments can ease symptoms, slow progression and improve quality of life.

 

Option B: Classic polyarteritis nodosa

  • Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a rare disease that results from blood vessel inflammation ("vasculitis"), causing injury to organ systems. The areas most commonly affected by PAN include the nerves, intestinal tract, heart, and joints. PAN can also affect the blood vessels in the kidney resulting in high blood pressure and damage to kidney function.

 

Option C: Nephrotic syndrome

  • Nephrotic syndrome is a kidney disorder that causes your body to pass too much protein in your urine.
  • Nephrotic syndrome is usually caused by damage to the clusters of small blood vessels in your kidneys that filter waste and excess water from your blood. The condition causes swelling, particularly in your feet and ankles, and increases the risk of other health problems.
  • Treatment for nephrotic syndrome includes treating the condition that's causing it and taking medications. Nephrotic syndrome can increase your risk of infections and blood clots. Your doctor might recommend medications and dietary changes to prevent complications.

 

Option D: Rheumatoid arthritis

  • Rheumatoid arthritis, or RA, is an autoimmune and inflammatory disease, which means that your immune system attacks healthy cells in your body by mistake, causing inflammation (painful swelling) in the affected parts of the body.
  • RA mainly attacks the joints, usually many joints at once. RA commonly affects joints in the hands, wrists, and knees. In a joint with RA, the lining of the joint becomes inflamed, causing damage to joint tissue. This tissue damage can cause long-lasting or chronic pain, unsteadiness (lack of balance), and deformity (misshapenness).
  • RA can also affect other tissues throughout the body and cause problems in organs such as the lungs, heart, and eyes.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with complaints of loss of consciousness when he was performing household chores and was revived by his friend, who gave him some sugar candies. The patient has also complained of weakness and Flank pain for the past 1 month. He added that he vomits almost everything he had in the morning. Routine investigations have revealed hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypoglycemia. He was admitted and treated as a case of UTI in a tertiary care centre and sent home. 2 days later, the patient died. An autopsy was done, which revealed that a wedge-shaped area in the adrenal gland was affected. The nucleus is not seen on histopathology, but cellular outlines are intact. Which type of necrosis is being described?
questions.solution:
Option A: Coagulative necrosis

  • A type of necrosis caused by tissue ischemia, which denatures proteolytic enzymes. Occurs in most tissues except the brain.
  • Histopathologic examination shows preserved anuclear, eosinophilic cellular architecture.
  • Tissue ischemia in solid organs such as the heart, liver, spleen, and kidneys leads to coagulative necrosis (e.g., splenic infarction).
  • Reduced oxygen delivery, which characterizes ischemia, lowers the rate at which ATP is created through aerobic glycolysis. Acidosis results from the hypoxic cells switching to anaerobic metabolism, which raises lactic acid generation.
  • Acidosis results in the denaturation of proteins, particularly lysosomal and proteolytic enzymes, which inhibit the cell from dissolving (autolysis).
  • The absence of cell nuclei or the presence of nuclei still undergoing karyolysis are hence characteristics of coagulative necrosis.
  • Histologically, this is the most prevalent kind of necrosis. For at least a few days, the architecture of dead tissue remains retained. An infarct is a localized area of coagulative necrosis.

Option B: Liquefactive necrosis

  • A type of necrosis characterized by the partial or complete dissolution of dead tissue and transformation into a liquid, viscous mass.
  • Caused by neutrophilic release of lysosomal enzymes that digest tissue.
  • Characterized histologically by macrophages and cellular debris (early) followed by cystic spaces (late).
  • Seen in bacterial abscesses and brain infarcts.

  • Numerous cystic spaces and disintegration of the normal tissue architecture are visible. There is abundant cellular debris.
  • The extensive transformation of the tissue differentiates this case of liquefactive necrosis from coagulative necrosis.

Option C: Fibrinoid necrosis

  • A type of necrosis characterized by small blood vessel injury and accumulation of fibrin and other plasma proteins caused by malignant hypertension or vasculitis (type III hypersensitivity reaction).
  • Seen on histological examination of vessels in patients with polyarteritis nodosa, preeclampsia, and hypertensive emergency.

  • Microscopic image of arteriole in the lung tissues (H&E stain)
  • The arteriole wall exhibits annular deposition of amorphous and proteinaceous material and inflammatory infiltrates.
  • These are the typical features of fibrinoid necrosis.

Option D: Caseous necrosis

  • A type of necrosis characterized by granular debris results from macrophages walling off a pathogen.
  • Seen in tubercular, fungal, and Nocardia infections.
  • Histopathological examination shows cellular debris, lymphocytes, and macrophages that form granulomas.

  • The image shows a granuloma with necrosis in the center (green outline), a surrounding layer of immune cells such as macrophages ), and a peripheral layer that consists of epitheloid cells. A giant cell can also be seen.
  • This is the typical histopathological appearance of a caseating granuloma seen in tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 61-year-old alcoholic man is brought to the emergency room of the hospital with a fever (38.7°C/103°F) and foul-smelling breath.
