A chest X-ray shows a pulmonary abscess in the right lower lobe. The patient may subsequently develop acute bronchopneumonia and the patient dies. A microscopic examination of the lungs at autopsy is shown below in the image. Activation of phospholipase A2 in the intra-alveolar cells resulted in the formation of which of the following mediators of the inflammation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Arachidonic acid

  • Cellular sources of vasoactive mediators are;

  • They are derived from the metabolism of arachidonic acid (prostaglandins, thromboxanes, leukotrienes and platelet-activating factor).

  • Preformed and stored in the cytoplasmic granules (histamine, serotonin, and lysosomal hydrolases).

  • Generated as normal regulators of the vascular function (nitric oxide (NO) and neurokinins).

  • The IMAGE above shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes responding to bacterial pneumonia.

  • Free arachidonic acid in these acute inflammatory cells is derived from the membrane phospholipids (primarily phosphatidylcholine) by stimulus-induced activation of phospholipase A2.

Option B: cAMP

  • cAMP is involved in the regulation of sugar, glycogen and lipid metabolism.

  • It is used for intracellular signal transduction.

Option C: cGMP

  • cGMP is derived from guanosine triphosphate.

  • cGMP is a key regulator of cell differentiation, proliferation, and apoptosis.

  • It reduces the proinflammatory cytokines and oxidative stress.

Option D: Inositol trisphosphate

  • Inositol trisphosphate is generated by phosphatidyl inositol breakdown.

  • Inositol trisphosphate mobilizes calcium from storage organelles and regulates cell proliferation.

questions.text: For the past 6 months, a 49-year-old woman has had shortness of breath and easy fatigability. Aortic pallor and a diastolic murmur were discovered on physical examination. The aortic and mitral valves were thickened and calcified, there was substantial aortic regurgitation, and the ascending aorta was dilated on echocardiography.. Complete blood counts revealed hemoglobin: 7.7 gm/dl, mean corpuscular volume (MCV): 78 fl, mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH):23 pg, total white cell count: 9.0 × 109/L, and platelet count: 227 × 109/L. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was 100 mm/hr. In Anemia of chronic disease, which of the following is seen?
questions.solution:
Parameters in Anemia of chronic diseases:

  • Decrease in serum iron [d/t decrease in absorption by the interference of Hepcidin]
  • Decrease TIBC [d/t decreased amount of transferrin]
  • Decrease in % transferrin saturation
  • Increase in serum ferritin
  • S. TfR/ Log[ferritin] < 1.5
Test Iron deficiency Anemia of chronic disease Thalassemia minor Lead posioning
MCV ↓ ↓ ↓ N/↓
Serum iron ↓ ↓ N ↑
TIBC ↑ ↓ N ↓
Percent saturation ↓ ↓ N ↑
Serum ferritin ↓ ↑ N ↑
RBC count ↓ ↓ ↑ ↓

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the medical department with a history of vague abdominal pain and fatigue over several months. His physical examination reveals significant splenomegaly but no lymphadenopathy. He eventually succumbs to bacterial sepsis and dies. At autopsy, a bone marrow biopsy reveals numerous atypical megakaryocytes and significant marrow fibrosis (results shown in the image). Which of the following diagnosis is most suitable here?
questions.solution:
Option C: Primary myelofibrosis

  • The above-given case scenario is of myelofibrosis, a disease in which healthy bone marrow tissue is slowly replaced with a fibrous scar-like material leading to progressive bone marrow failure.

  • Features:

    • JAK 2 mutation > MPL mutation

    • No. of neoplastic megakaryocytes

    • Bone marrow fibrosis/ ↑ collagen

    • Ineffective erythropoiesis- Anemia

    • Extramedullary hematopoiesis- massive splenomegaly

  • Classical triad:

    • Teardrop RBC

    • Leuco erythroblasts

    • Abnormal platelets

  • Diagnosis:

    • Bone marrow aspiration- dry tap

    • Bone marrow biopsy- IOC

  • Clonal myeloproliferative disease in which marrow fibrosis is accompanied by prominent megakaryopoiesis and granulopoiesis.

  • Conditions associated with a dry tap on bone marrow examination:

    • CML

    • Myelofibrosis

    • Hairy cell leukaemia

    • Lymphoma

    • Metastasis

    • Acute leukaemia

Option A: Acute myelogenous leukaemia

  • The blast cells /immature cells found in bone marrow but do not circulate in the blood indicate acute myelogenous leukaemia.

Option B: Acute promyelocytic leukaemia

  • Acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APL) is a unique subtype of acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) in which cells in the bone marrow that produce blood cells do not develop and function normally

Option D: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia

  • Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow produces increased lymphocytes.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old male presents to the medical emergency department with chills, rigours, and a fever for the previous two weeks. His body temperature is 39.2 degrees Celsius. His CBC findings are shown below in the table. The figure displays a smear of peripheral blood. A bone marrow biopsy is done, and the specimen shows hyper-cellularity. Which of the following findings is more likely to be the cause?

Complete Blood Count (CBC) Report


	
		
			Haemoglobin
			13.9 g/dL
		
		
			Hematocrit
			40.5%
		
		
			MCV
			93µm3
		
		
			Platelet count
			210,000/mm3
		
		
			WBC count
			13,750/mm3
questions.solution:
Option D: Lung Abscess

  • The patient mentioned above's blood smear figure shows a neutrophilic leukocytosis and a "left shift" from increased band neutrophils.
  • Myeloid hyperplasia, a growth of the myeloid precursor pool in the bone marrow, can result from persistent inflammation and chronic infections, such as lung abscesses.
  • A lung abscess is defined as a defined area of ​​pus or necrotic debris leading to lung parenchymal cavities and the level of airflow in the cavities after a bronchopulmonary fistula has formed.
  • Depending on the mode of transmission, lung abscess can be transmitted bronchially (aspiration, inhalation) and hematogenously from other sources of infection.
  • Acute lung abscesses are usually characterized by poorly defined surrounding lung parenchyma filled with thick necrotic debris.
  • Histologically, in the centre of the abscess is necrotic tissue mixed with granulocytes and necrotic bacteria. Neutrophil granulocytes with dilated blood vessels and inflammatory edema are preserved around this area.
  • Treatment of lung abscesses includes IV antibiotics or oral antibiotics for less severely affected patients. However, percutaneous, endobronchial, or surgical drainage of abscesses is recommended for patients that are unresponsive to antibiotics.

Option A: Acute viral hepatitis

  • Contrary to acute bacterial infections, acute viral hepatitis does not result in neutrophilic leukocytosis.

  • Histological features of acute hepatitis following viral infection usually show intranuclear viral inclusions and surrounding neutrophils.

Option B: Chronic myelogenous leukaemia

  • The marrow is filled with myeloid cells throughout the maturation spectrum in chronic myelogenous leukaemia.
  • More immature forms of myeloid cells in the peripheral blood include metamyelocytes, myelocytes, and even a few blasts, along with increased eosinophils and basophils.

Option C: Glucocorticoid therapy

  • Glucocorticoids can decrease neutrophil extravasation into tissues while increasing the generation of cells from the marrow storage pool.
  • Vigorous exercise can produce neutrophilia transiently from the emargination of neutrophils.
  • A large spleen tends to sequester peripheral blood cells, reducing their circulating numbers.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with a complaint of red-coloured urine for the last few days. He had a throat infection 15 days back. He has no chronic medical condition and does not take any medications. There is no family history of such a disorder. The renal histopathology slide is given below. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis

  • This patient with hematuria 2 weeks after a probable group A streptococcal infection most likely has post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

     

  • The presence of diffuse involvement of glomeruli and histologically showing enlarged hypercellular glomeruli is suggestive of Acute infectious GN.
  • It can be both infectious and non-infectious (SLE), but the most common infectious acute proliferative GN is post-streptococcal GN.

 

 

Option A: Berger disease

  • It is characterised by the following:
  • Episodic hematuria
  • Hematuria occurs concurrently with a URTI or GI infection

 

Option B: Minimal change of disease

  • It is the most common pathology associated with nephrotic range proteinuria in children.

 

Option D: Diabetic nephropathy

  • It is characterised by the following in severe disease:
  • Nephrotic-range proteinuria, not hematuria
  • Eosinophilic nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented to the nephrology clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, hypertension, and hematuria for the last 15 days. On physical examination, he has flank pain and abdominal mass. Further workup and genetic analysis showed a mutation in thePKD2 gene on chromosome 4. Which of the following vascular complications is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Berry aneurysm

  • This is a case of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) that presents with abdominal pain, hypertension, hematuria, flank pain, and abdominal mass.
  • ADPKD is due to mutation in PKD1 and PKD2 genes on chromosome 16 and chromosome 4, which encodes for polycystin protein.
  • Berry aneurysm (lead to subarachnoid haemorrhage) is the most common vascular complication of ADPKD.
  • Berry aneurysm is also known as a saccular aneurysm.
  • Berry aneurysm typically occurs at a bifurcation in the circle of Willis (junction of an anterior communicating artery and anterior cerebral artery is the most common site).
  • Risk factors for berry aneurysms:
    • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.
    • Connective tissue diseases (Ehlers-danlos syndrome).
    • Advanced age.
    • African American population.
    • Hypertension.
    • Smoking
  • Berry aneurysm is clinically silent until it gets ruptured, which leads to subarachnoid haemorrhage.

Option A: Congenital hepatic fibrosis

  • Congenital hepatic fibrosis is the complication of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD)
  • ARPKD is characterized by cystic dilation of collecting ducts.
  • Complications of ARPKD systemic hypertension and portal hypertension.

Option C: Portal hypertension

  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease can lead to systemic hypertension, not portal hypertension.
  • Portal hypertension is a complication of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease.
  • Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease most often occurs in infants.

Option D: Renal artery stenosis

  • Renal artery stenosis (RAS) is most often caused by atherosclerotic plaque and fibromuscular dysplasia.
  • RAS presents as refractory hypertension (with no significant family history of hypertension) and asymmetrical kidney size.
  • RAS is not a complication of ADPKD.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with an oozing, reddish patch on her left nipple (as shown in the image). The patient believes an allergic reaction to her bra causes this issue because she has a history of skin rashes and food allergies. Cytologic examination of fluid oozing from the skin lesion reveals neoplastic cells. Excisional biopsy reveals large clear malignant cells in the epidermis of the areola. Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Paget disease

  • Paget's disease of the nipple refers to a rare variant of ductal carcinoma, either in situ or invasive.
  • It spreads to the epidermis of the nipple and areola.
  • A doctor usually treats this condition for eczematous changes in the skin of the nipple and areola.
  • Microscopic: Large cells with clear cytoplasm (Paget cells) are found individually or in groups within the epidermis.
  • Eczematous lesions on the nipple and areola are not characteristic of the other options.

Option A: Acute mastitis

  • Mastitis is an infection-related inflammation of the breast tissue that causes pain, swelling, warmth, and redness in the breasts.
  • Fever and chills may also be present.
  • Mastitis most commonly affects women who are breastfeeding (lactation mastitis).
  • The infection should clear up within 10 days but may last as long as three weeks.
  • Mastitis sometimes goes away without medical treatment.

Option B: Colloid carcinoma

  • Also called colloid carcinoma, mucinous carcinoma is an uncommon type of breast cancer.
  • It develops in the milk duct and spreads to other tissues.
  • The tumour comprises abnormal cells, and in this type of breast cancer, these cells float in mucin, a primary component of a slimy substance called mucus.
  • Like other forms of invasive ductal cancer, mucinous breast cancer begins in the breast's milk duct before spreading to the tissues around the duct.

Option C: Intraductal papilloma

  • Intraductal papilloma is a small, noncancerous (benign) tumour that grows in a milk duct of the breast.
  • Abnormal nipple discharge may be described as any discharge not associated with lactation.
  • The nature of the discharge may range in colour, consistency and composition and occur in one or both breasts.
  • These tumours are made of glands, fibrous tissue, and blood vessels.
  • They most commonly occur in women between ages 35 and 55. There are no known risk factors for intraductal papilloma.

questions.text: Patient came with complaints of weakness, easy fatigability. Past medical history reveals that he was previously admitted and treated as a case of Malabsorption syndrome a few months back. Which of the following is not involved in iron metabolism?
questions.solution:
Transthyretin- is not involved in iron metabolism.

  • It is a plasma protein responsible for transport of thyroid hormone(T4) & retinol.

Hepcidin- it acts as a negative regulator of iron, by decreasing iron absorption from the GI tract.

Ferroportin- Fe2+ iron is transported from enterocyte [on basolateral side] into circulation by ferroportin.

Ceruloplasmin- Causes oxidation of Fe2+ iron to Fe3+ iron & also involved in copper metabolism

questions.text: Which drug can cause both dose-dependent and dose-independent bone marrow suppression?
questions.solution:
Option B: Chloramphenicol

  • The patient's report shows decreased erythrocytes, leukocytes, and platelets.
  • It occurs due to the suppression of stem cell function in the bone marrow.
  • Chloramphenicol can cause both dose-dependent and dose-independent aplastic anaemia.
  • Dose-dependent aplastic anaemia associated with chloramphenicol is reversible after the medication is withdrawn.
  • Dose-independent anaemia is usually severe and may be fatal.

Option A: Gentamicin

  • Adverse effects of gentamicin include nephrotoxicity, neuromuscular blockade (absolute contraindication with myasthenia gravis), ototoxicity (especially with loop diuretics), and teratogenicity.

Option C: Doxycycline

  • Side effects of doxycycline are the same as those of tetracyclines, including nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, tooth discolouration in children, phototoxicity, teratogenicity, liver failure and Fanconi syndrome. 
  • Doxycycline is safe for renal failure

Option D: Vancomycin

  • Side effects include nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, thrombophlebitis, diffuse flushing (vancomycin infusion reaction preventable by pretreatment with histamines) and DRESS syndrome (drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms is a rare but potentially life-threatening drug-induced hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents at the physician's clinic with severe pain and paleness in his right foot. He received unfractionated heparin recently. His blood tests show Hb 13.2 g/dL, WBC 10,000/mm³, and Platelet 50,000/mm³. What should be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Argatroban

  • Direct thrombin inhibitors, like argatroban, are used to treat heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. It binds directly to thrombin and inactivates it without the need to combine with anti-thrombin III.
  • In this case, the patient has developed severe pain in the right foot and paleness of the right toe after receiving unfractionated heparin seven days back. Labs show thrombocytopenia. All these are suggestive of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia includes; venous thrombosis, thrombocytopenia, and the timing of heparin administration (5-14 days) before developing thrombocytopenia.
  • Discontinue heparin immediately, and low molecular weight heparin should be avoided.
  • The drug of choice for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is direct thrombin inhibitors like argatroban. Lepirudin can be used as an alternative.

Option A: High dose of heparin

  • Heparin is an anticoagulant. Side effects of heparin include; bleeding due to overdose, heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, and osteoporosis.
  • A high dose of heparin can exacerbate heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

Option B: Lidocaine

  • Lidocaine is a class IB anti-arrhythmic drug.
  • It is used to suppress ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.
  • It is effective in ventricular arrhythmias and ineffective in atrial arrhythmias.

Option D: Warfarin

  • Warfarin is an anticoagulant. It is mainly used for venous thrombosis prophylaxis (DVT and pulmonary embolism).
  • In heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, thrombosis is present. This leads to the consumption of PROTEIN C, so giving warfarin to this patient would further decrease PROTEIN C levels and cause skin necrosis. Therefore warfarin is avoided in such patients.

questions.text: Which medication is a selective MAO-B inhibitor that can be used for treating parkinson?
questions.solution:
Option A: Selegiline

  • Selegiline is in a group of medications called monoamine oxidase type B (MAO-B) inhibitors
  • It works by increasing the amount of dopamine (a natural substance that is needed to control movement) in the brain
  • Selegiline is used in combination with levodopa or levodopa and carbidopa combination to treat Parkinson's disease
  • This medicine works to increase and extend the effects of Levodopa and may help to slow the progress of Parkinson's disease

Option B: Clorgyline

  • Clorgyline is an aromatic ether
  • It was formerly used as an antidepressant

Option C: Moclobemide

  • Moclobemide is a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor
  • Used to treat certain types of mental depression
  • It works by blocking the action of a chemical substance known as monoamine oxidase (MAO) in the nervous system

Option D: Tranylcypromine

  • Tranylcypromine is used to treat certain types of depression
  • Tranylcypromine is used to treat depression in people whose other medications have not helped
  • It belongs to the group of medicines called monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOI)
  • This medicine works by blocking the action of a chemical substance known as monoamine oxidase (MAO) in the nervous system

questions.text: Which of the following insulins does not reach peak concentration in plasma?
questions.solution:
Option D: Insulin glargine

  • Insulin glargine is a long-acting insulin that is taken once daily and maintains a basal insulin level throughout the day. It is a type of insulin that has a longer duration of action.
  • Insulin glargine is prescribed to diabetic patients who either have type 1 or type 2 of the disease. Several therapies combine it with insulin, which starts working quickly in order to get the best possible control of the patient's blood sugar levels.
  • When it is given subcutaneously, the vast majority of the glargine stays in the subcutaneous area, and only trace amounts enter the bloodstream. However, it continues to enter the bloodstream over time even after it has been given subcutaneously (maintains basal level)
  • It prevents the levels of insulin in the plasma from ever reaching a high level.
  • The effects of a single injection of glargine last for one whole day.
  • Glargine is also known as insulin without a peak.
  • Insulins such as insulin Lispro, insulin aspart, and insulin glulisine all have a rapid onset of action once they begin to work.

Option A: Insulin lispro

  • Insulin lispro is rapid-acting insulin and reaches its peak quite quickly.

Option B: Insulin aspart

  • Insulin aspart is rapid-acting insulin and reaches its peak quite quickly.

Option C: Insulin glulisine

  • Insulin glulisine is rapid-acting insulin and reaches its peak quite quickly.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of loose, watery stools and vomiting for the past two days. There were eight episodes for the past two days. The stool was watery and yellowish, and did not contain blood or mucus content. There was no history of abdominal pain, fever, or jaundice. On examination, the patient was lethargic. His blood pressure measured 100/60 mmHg, and his pulse rate was 80 beats per minute. Abdominal examination was unremarkable. The patient was given intravenous fluid and was prescribed diphenoxylate and atropine. Which of the following is the mechanism of atropine in this particular case?

choices.text: Augment the anti-motility action of diphenoxylate
Discourage overdose and abuse of diphenoxylate

questions.solution:
Option D: Discourage overdose and abuse of diphenoxylate

  • This is a case of diarrhoea in which the patient presents with complaints of loose, watery stools and vomiting for 2 days.
  • Diphenoxylate/atropine combination is used in the management and treatment of diarrhoea. Diphenoxylate is an anti-motility drug. Large doses of diphenoxylate cause euphoria.
  • Diphenoxylate is an opioid agonist that acts on presynaptic opioid receptors (mu receptors) in the enteric nervous system.
  • It acts on presynaptic opioid receptors resulting in blockage in the release of acetylcholine. This results in the inhibition of peristaltic contractions and the secretory action of enteric cells.
  • The drug does not have analgesic effects at standard doses, but at higher doses, it can lead to euphoria-like states. Therefore, the drug can be misused.
  •  Atropine is added in combination with diphenoxylate to discourage overdosage.
  • Atropine is a competitive inhibitor of acetylcholine receptors, thus, preventing diphenoxylate overuse.
  • Atropine, when given in high doses, causes nausea, bloating, tachycardia, and dryness of mouth and eyes. These adverse effects are unpleasant and intolerable to the patient.

Option A: Suppress associated vomiting of gastroenteritis

  •  Drugs used for suppression of vomiting are:
    • Dopamine antagonists – metoclopramide, prochlorperazine
    • Serotonin antagonists – ondansetron
    • Corticosteroids – dexamethasone
    • Anticholinergics – hyoscine
    • Benzodiazepines – lorazepam
    • Antihistamines – doxylamine

Option B: Augment the anti-motility action of diphenoxylate

  • Drugs used for decreasing the motility of the gut are as follows;
    • Loperamide
    • Bismuth subsalicylate
    • Probiotics
    • Diphenoxylate/atropine

Option C: Block side effects of diphenoxylate

  • The adverse effects of diphenoxylate are;
    • Respiratory and CNS depression
    • Worsens dehydration and electrolyte imbalance in patients with pre-existing electrolyte imbalance.
    • Precipitates toxic megacolon in patients with ulcerative colitis.
    • Causes allergic reactions – anaphylaxis. Urticarial.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of breathing difficulty and high-grade fever. He also experiences a productive cough, and his condition deteriorates, necessitating ventilatory support. After receiving ventilatory support, a new infiltrate is observed on a chest x-ray six days later. Leukocytosis is noted on the complete blood count. Culture and sensitivity examination of the aspirate from the endotracheal tube reveal multidrug-resistant (MDR) Acinetobacter baumannii. What is the  best treatment option for managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Colistin

  • The patient has developed ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to acinetobacter baumannii. Acinetobacter baumannii is a gram-negative, aerobic bacillus that can cause opportunistic, hospital-acquired, multidrug-resistant infections.
  • Often found as a colonizer of the skin, oropharynx, and respiratory tract.
  • It is also associated with developing hospital-acquired, multidrug-resistant infections and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
  • The diagnosis is established by bacterial culture.
  • The preferred treatment for this multi-drug-resistant organism is third-generation cephalosporins such as cefotaxime,  carbapenems,  OR polymyxins (for resistant strains).
  • Polymyxins are a class of bactericidal antibiotics that disrupt the cell membranes of gram-negative organisms. They are used to treat multidrug-resistant, gram-negative infections. Examples include polymyxin B and polymyxin E (colistin).

Option A: Quinupristin and dalfopristin

  • In cases where other therapeutic options fail, Dalfopristin/Quinuprostin is reserved for treating severe vancomycin-resistant enterococcus faecium (VRE).

Option C: Levofloxacin

  • Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone that has excellent activity against most strains of bacterial pathogens responsible for gastrointestinal, respiratory, and urinary tract infections, including gram-negative, gram-positive, and atypical bacteria. However, it is not used against acinetobacter baumannii.

Option D: Tedizolid

  • It belongs to the oxazolidinones class of drugs, a class of antibiotics that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit. The clinical uses include multidrug-resistant gram-positive bacteria (VRE, MRSA). However, it is not used for the treatment of acinetobacter baumannii.

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male with diabetes mellitus type 2 and symptoms of episodic chest pain, shortness of breath, and easy fatigue, along with elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels, which medication is likely to provide benefit?
questions.solution:
Option D: Nicotinic acid

  • Based on the clinical features patient is likely suffering from stable angina. The most efficient vitamin, in this case, is nicotinic acid.
  • Niacin, also known as nicotinic acid, is an organic compound and a form of vitamin B₃, an essential human nutrient.
  • The mechanism of action of niacin to raise HDL is by decreasing the fractional catabolic rate of HDL-apo AI without affecting the synthetic rates.
  • It works by blocking the enzyme lipase, which is responsible for making cholesterol in the liver.
  • It has lipid-lowering properties.
  • Niacin improves "good" HDL cholesterol levels and lowers triglyceride levels.

Option A: Thiamine

  • It is vitamin B1, and it is essential in carbohydrate metabolism.
  • Its deficiency can cause Wernicke korsakoff syndrome, irritability, poor appetite, and sleep disturbances.
  • It has no role in lipid metabolism.

Option B: Biotin

  • Biotin makes Vitamin B-7 from the B-complex family and has a well-documented role in hair and nail health.
  • Although integral in carbohydrate, protein and fat metabolism, it has no lipid-lowering property.

Option C: Pyridoxine

  • Pyridoxine makes Vitamin B-6 of the B complex family.
  • It plays an important role in maintaining the health of nerve system.
  • Its deficiency can cause anaemia and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man fainted suddenly two hours ago after eating beef steak for the first time. His wife brought him to the emergency department. He has increased mouth secretions, mild breathing difficulty, and a heart rate of 52 beats/min. Sinus bradycardia was confirmed by ECG. Atropine was administered, initially worsening the bradycardia before improving the heart rate. What is the initial mechanism of action of the drug involved in this case?

choices.text: Blockade of M1 receptors of SA nodal cells
Blockade of muscarinic autoreceptor on vagal nerve endings

questions.solution:
Option D: Blockade of muscarinic auto receptor on vagal nerve endings

  • This is a case of anaphylactic reaction in which the patient is brought to the emergency department by his wife as he suddenly fainted on the road 2 hours ago. The wife gives the history that they were going home from the restaurant after eating beef steak for the first time in their life.
  • The patient has increased secretions from his mouth, mild difficulty in breathing and his heart rate is 52 beats/min.
  • ECG of the patient was done, which revealed sinus bradycardia, and the doctor noticed that the heart rate was slightly decreasing.
  • All these symptoms and findings of the patient suggest anaphylactic shock.
  • The doctor administered atropine to the patient, which caused bradycardia initially.
  • This result is due to the blockade of muscarinic receptors on vagal nerve endings.

Option A: Stimulation of the medullary vagal centre

  • The stimulation of the medullary vagal centre will immediately result in an increase in blood pressure.

Option B: Stimulation of vagal ganglia

  • The stimulation of the vagal ganglia doesn’t cause initial bradycardia.
  • It increases the activity of the brain’s area of mood control.

Option C: Blockade of M2 receptors of SA nodal cells

  • Blockade of M2 receptors of the SA node cells doesn’t cause bradycardia.
  • M2 cholinergic receptors are responsible for bradycardia, and blockade of these receptors can result in tachycardia.​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented to the OPD with sudden onset of pain, swelling and redness of the left first metatarsophalangeal joint. An aspiration of the joint showed needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals. The physician prescribed a drug for the patient, but he returned the next day with nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea after taking the medication. Which of the following is the most likely drug prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Colchicine

  • This patient’s acute onset pain and swelling of the right first metatarsophalangeal joint and joint aspirate showing needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals indicate that he most likely has acute gouty arthritis.
  • Colchicine is an effective anti-inflammatory agent in acute gouty arthritis. It does this without inhibiting the synthesis or promotion of excretion of uric acid.
  • It does not affect the phagocytosis of urate crystals but inhibits the release of chemotactic factors and the glycoprotein, thus suppressing the subsequent events
  • Binding to the fibrillar protein tubulin inhibits granulocyte migration into the inflamed joint and thus interrupts the vicious cycle.
  • Adverse effects and toxicity occur at high doses: nausea, vomiting, watery or bloody diarrhoea, and abdominal cramps.
  • Accumulating the drug in the intestine and inhibiting mitosis in its rapid turnover mucosa is responsible for the toxicity.
  • Other effects include kidney damage, CNS depression, intestinal bleeding and death due to muscular paralysis and respiratory failure.

Option A: Allopurinol

  • Allopurinol is a short-acting competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase to inhibit uric acid synthesis.
  • The adverse effects include hypersensitivity reactions (rashes, fever, malaise, muscle pain) which subsides on stopping the drug. Other effects include Stevens-Johnson syndrome, which is a rare but serious risk. Gastric irritations, headache, nausea and dizziness are infrequent and do not need withdrawal.

Option C: Steroids

  • The intraarticular steroid is employed and is effective for an acute episode.
  • Systemic steroids are rarely used for treatment, especially in those with peptic ulcer disease or renal failure (individuals who cannot take NSAIDs).
  • However, such rapid onset of gastrointestinal symptoms does not occur

Option D: Indomethacin

  • It is a non-selective NSAID that is more effective and tolerable than colchicine. Compared to colchicine, indomethacin causes peptic ulcer disease if used for a long duration due to loss of gastric mucosal protection by inhibiting the COX-1 enzyme. However, such symptoms do not develop so quickly as colchicine.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male with sneezing, coughing, and shortness of breath for two weeks, worse in the morning and at night, presents to the physician. Bilateral wheezes are heard on auscultation, and various drug treatments with different administration routes are being considered. Which statement about the routes of administration in this patient is true?

choices.text: Intravenous route should be avoided due to the risk of exacerbating wheezing symptoms.
Subcutaneous route is preferred for immediate relief of symptoms due to its rapid onset of action.
Oral route is contraindicated as it may worsen the patient's symptoms of sneezing and coughing.
Inhalation route is the most appropriate choice for delivering bronchodilators to relieve wheezing and shortness of breath.

questions.solution:
Option B: The first-pass effect is the result of the metabolism of a drug after administration and before it enters systemic circulation.

  • This is a case of acute asthma in which the patient presents with complaints of sneezing, coughing and shortness of breath for two weeks.
  • He gives no history of fever. He further explains that his symptoms are worse in the morning when he wakes up and at night. He has a history of similar symptoms in the past.
  • He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations are unremarkable. On auscultation of the lungs, there are bilateral wheezes.
  • The drug of choice for acute asthma is inhaled bronchodilators.
  • If it is not relieved by only bronchodilators, then inhaled corticosteroids are added.
  • The first-pass effect is the result of the metabolism of a drug after administration and before it enters systemic circulation.

 

 

Option A: Administration of a bronchodilator drug by inhaled aerosol is usually associated with more adverse effects than administration of the same drug orally

  • The inhalational route provides localized delivery to the respiratory system and thus is associated with lesser adverse effects than systemic routes like oral.

 

Option C: The bioavailability of most drugs is greater with rectal administration than with sublingual administration

  • When given by sublingual route, the drug bypasses the portal circulation and is thus protected from hepatic first-pass metabolism.
  • Drugs given by oral and rectal routes undergo first-pass metabolism in the liver. All the drug absorbed from the oral route is available for first-pass metabolism, whereas approximately 50% of the drug that is absorbed from the rectum will bypass the liver, thereby reducing hepatic first-pass metabolism.
  • However, rectal absorption can be irregular and incomplete.

​​​​​​​

Option D: Administration of a drug by the transdermal patch is often faster but is associated with more first-pass metabolism than oral administration

  • The micropore membrane of a transdermal patch is such that the rate of drug delivery to the skin surface is less than the slowest rate of absorption from the skin.
  • Thus, the drug is delivered at a constant and predictable rate. First-pass metabolism is avoided.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with a history of asthma and eczema presents to the emergency department with worsening wheezing and shortness of breath. His parents report that he missed his glucocorticoid inhaler for the past week while on vacation. The doctor advises him to continue his inhaler and avoid missing his doses. What is the most common side effect of the prescribed medication in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Oropharyngeal candidiasis

  • This patient has asthma. The long-term management of asthma involves the use of inhaled beta-agonist and inhaled corticosteroids.
  • The glucocorticoids reduce airway inflammation and can prevent asthma exacerbation. However, the long-term use of steroids is associated with serious complications such as ecchymosis, thinning and atrophy of the skin, acne, hirsutism, stria, delayed and impaired wound healing, thinning of hair, and perioral dermatitis.
  • Furthermore, glucocorticoids increase the risk of developing oropharyngeal candidiasis.

Option A: Pneumonia

  • This is not well established adverse effect of the use of inhaled corticosteroids.

Option C: Atrophic rhinitis

  • Atrophic rhinitis is not an adverse effect of the use of inhaled corticosteroids.

Option D: Pituitary adrenal suppression

  • This is not well established adverse effect of the use of inhaled corticosteroids.
  • However, the long-term use of ORAL corticosteroids can cause suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

questions.text: A 51-year-old patient visits the clinic again, expressing gastric irritation and diarrhea, despite recurrent duodenal ulcers and multiple treatments. After a secretin stimulation test shows elevated serum gastrin levels, which medication would the doctor prescribe to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Omeprazole

  • This is a case of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome with an increase in gastrin level after administration of secretin and recurrent ulcers in the duodenum. 
  • Zollinger Ellison syndrome:
    • It is a Pancreatic or duodenal gastrinoma, which leads to the secretion of large amounts of gastric acid causing severe ulcers and hyperchlorhydria. PPI is better than H2 blockers in this condition.
    • Omeprazole and all related "-prazoles" are irreversible and direct inhibitors of a proton pump (K+ /H+ antiport) in gastric parietal cells.
    • Other drugs in proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) include Esomeprazole, Pantoprazole, and Rabeprazole.
    • Rabeprazole is safe during pregnancy.
    • PPIs are more effective than H2  Antagonists like Cimetidine
    • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are the drugs of choice for peptic ulcer disease (PUD) due to any aetiology (even NSAID induced).
    • These are also the agents of choice for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome (ZES)

Option A: Cimetidine

  • Cimetidine is H2 Antagonist; other agents in this class include Ranitidine and Famotidine.
  • Mechanism of Action: Reversible blockage of histamine H2-receptors and ultimately decrease H+ secretion by parietal cells.
  • Uses: Peptic ulcers, GERD, and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
  • Overall less effective than PPIs in PUD.

Option C: Misoprostol

  • Mechanism of Action: Prostaglandin E1  (PGE1) synthetic analogue, which is cytoprotective and increases the secretion of bicarbonate and mucus and decreases the secretion of HCL.
  • Uses for NSAID-induced ulcers and termination of pregnancy with a mifepristone combination.

Option D: Aluminium hydroxide

  • Aluminium hydroxide is an antacid with constipation as the most common side effect in the antacid class; it also causes Hypophosphatemia, Proximal muscle weakness, and seizures.
  • All antacid, including Aluminium hydroxide, causes Hypokalemia and can delay gastric emptying.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents to the dermatology ward with an infective skin lesion of the leg from the last 20 hours. After examination, the doctor advised him on gram staining and culture of infective lesion specimens. Gram stain from the specimen shows pus cells with gram-positive cocci in chains, and culture is done, which shows hemolytic colonies. To confirm the organism after gram staining and culture. Which of the following is the confirmatory test?
questions.solution:
Option C: Bacitracin sensitivity

  • The patient here is most likely suffering from an infectious lesion.
  • Bacitracin sensitivity is used to confirm the organism. It is a confirmatory test, according to the above statement.
  • Infective skin lesions with Gram-positive cocci in chains and hemolytic colonies suggest infection of Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • Bile solubility:
    • Pneumococcus is bile soluble.
  • It is Gram-positive cocci in pairs. Hence, excluded.
  • Pneumococcus: Optochin sensitive.
  • Streptococcus Pyogenes
    • It is Gram-positive cocci in chains (as given in the Question above).
  • Culture:
    • Blood agar: Pinpoint colony with a wide zone of β-hemolysis (Refer to the image).

    • Biochemical: Catalase negative.
    • Bacitracin sensitive (Refer to the image).

    • Pyrrolidonyl Arylamidase (PYR) test is positive.
  • Catalase positive: Staphylococcus species.
  • Catalase negative: Streptococcus species.

Option A: Bile solubility

  • Pneumococcus is bile soluble.
  • It is gram-positive cocci in pairs.
  • The bile solubility test is the test that differentiates Streptococcus pneumoniae from alpha-hemolytic streptococci.

Option B: Optochin sensitivity

  • Pneumococcus: Optochin sensitive.
  • Optochin sensitivity helps presumptively identify alpha-hemolytic streptococci as S. pneumoniae; some are optochin-resistant strains.

Option D: Catalase positive

  • Catalase positive: Staphylococcus species.
  • Catalase negative: Streptococcus species.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, headache and neck rigidity for one week. The patient also had an episode of fits one day ago. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The patient's blood picture shows monocytosis. The organism cultivated from CSF gives a positive anton test. Which of the following statement is true regarding the organism involved in the patient's pathology?

choices.text: Most human infections are caused by serovar 2a or 2b
Ciprofloxacin is the drug of choice for this organism

questions.solution:
Option B: Most human infections are caused by serovar 2a or 2b

  • This is a case of meningitis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, headache and neck stiffness for one week. The patient also had an episode of fits one day ago.
  • Meningitis is usually accompanied by fits.
  • The causative organism of the given clinical condition is Listeria monocytogenes (positive Anton test).
  • The listeria monocytogenes usually cause meningitis in patients who are of old age or in neonates.

Listeria monocytogenes:

  • It is a Gram-positive coccobacilli.

  • Most human infections are caused by serovar 2a or 2b.

Culture:

  • Blood agar
  • Chocolate agar
  • Palcam agar: Selective culture media for Listeria

Tests:

  • CAMP test positive.

  • Anton test- Listeria culture is put into the eyes of the rabbit, and the rabbit develops keratoconjunctivitis.
  • Catalase positive

Option A: It is coccoid, Gram-negative bacillus

  • Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive coccobacilli.

Option C: It is non motile at 25ºC

  • Listeria shows tumbling motility at 25ºC but non-motile at 37°C.

  • Cold enrichment: 40C.

Option D: Ciprofloxacin is the drug of choice for this organism

  • Ampicillin is the drug of choice for Listeria monocytogenes.

  • Gentamycin is the second-line treatment for this organism.
  • Ciprofloxacin is not used in this case.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever & chills for 2 weeks after a louse bite. He gives no history of any other abnormalities. He has no history of any chronic illnesses. The patient is otherwise vitally stable. On examination, there was a maculopapular rash on the trunk, which spread peripherally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Epidemic typhus

  • This is a case of epidemic typhus in which the patient presents with complaints of fever & chills for 2 weeks after a louse bite.

  • On examination of the patient, there was a maculopapular rash on the trunk, which spread peripherally.

  • Among the option, the only louse-borne disease is Epidemic typhus.

  • Louse-borne diseases: Epidemic typhus, Brill Zinsser disease, Trench fever.

  • Epidemic typhus- causative agent Rickettsia prowazekii.

  • The appearance of a petechial (Refer to the image below) or macular rash on the fourth or fifth day, first starting on the trunk and then spreading over to the extremities but without affecting the face, palms, and sole is the characteristic feature of the condition.

Option A: Scrub typhus

  • Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.

  • The vector of the transmission of this disease is a mite, which is also known as trombiculid.

Option B: Ricketssiae pox

  • Causative agent- R. akari

  • Vector – Mite(gamasid)/Liponyssoides sanguineus

Option C: Endemic typhus

  • Endemic typhus is caused by R. typhi.

  • The vector for the transmission of this disease is a flea.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents to a regional hospital with shortness of breath and altered mental status for the last two months. The patient has a medical history significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and asplenia. The patient is taking chemotherapy sessions for her multiform glioblastoma. On examination, there is redness, swelling, itching, and whitish discharge from the vagina. Therefore a sample is withdrawn and sent to a laboratory for culture. On cornmeal agar, chlamydospores form at 200C, as given in the image below. Which of the following fungi exhibits the features mentioned above?
questions.solution:
Option A: Candida Albicans

  • Based on the symptoms such as redness, swelling, itching, and whitish discharge from the vagina and formation of chlamydospores on corn meal agar, the patient is suffering from candida Albicans infection.
  • The image above shows chlamydospore formation in Candida albicans.
  • Chlamydospores are thick-walled asexual spores produced by Candida albicans.
  • They are cultured on corn meal agar (nutrient-deficient medium).
  • C. albicans produces single terminal chlamydospores.
  • C. dublinensis produces terminal chlamydospores in clusters.
  • The microorganisms typically reside in or on our bodies or our natural microflora, including Candida albicans. It can be detected in the vagina, mouth, and GI tract.

  

Option B: Candida dublinensis

  • The fungus Candida dubliniensis is an opportunistic infection first discovered in AIDS patients. Sometimes, it is also isolated from immunocompetent people.
  • The organism is a dimorphic yeast of the genus candida, closely related to Candida albicans but forming a different phylogenetic cluster in DNA fingerprinting.
  • The oral cavity is where it is most frequently isolated from, while it can also occasionally be discovered in other anatomical places.

Option C: Candida glabrata

  • The haploid yeast species Candida glabrata, formerly Torulopsis glabrata, belongs to the genus candida.
  • Due to its naturally high resistance to antifungal medications, particularly the azoles, Candida glabrata is particularly significant in nosocomial infections.
  • Using cultures, it is possible to recognise non-albicans vaginal infections. In this technique, urinalyses are less precise. Even though the culture may take several days to develop, it is easy to identify the species once the yeast has been separated.

 

Option D: Candida kefyr

  • Ascomycetous yeast of the genus Kluyveromyces, Kluyveromyces marxianus. Atelosaccharomyces pseudotropicalis, often known as Candida kefir, is at this sexual stage.
  • A respiro-fermentative yeast called Kluyveromyces marxianus can produce energy from both fermentation of ethanol and respiration via the TCA cycle at the same time.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents in the outpatient clinic with the complaint of fever, malaise, diarrhoea, dark-coloured urine and jaundice. The physician thought these symptoms were likely to be associated with hepatitis A virus (HAV) and ordered labs for confirmation, but all the tests for HAV-IgG and HAV-IgM are non-reactive. What is the other possible cause of this infection?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hepatitis E

  • A possible cause of this infection is the Hepatitis E virus.
  • Hepatitis A and E both present acutely with complaints of fever, fatigue, malaise, and jaundice, as described in the above case.
  • HAV and HEV lack an envelope and are not destroyed by the gut.
  • Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is a single-stranded RNA virus.
  • It is transmitted enterically, and the disease is often referred to as Enteric Hepatitis.
  • Diagnosis is clinical and also one of exclusion: Hepatitis A and E are enterically transmitted diseases, and both have the faecal-oral route of transmission as the tests for Hepatitis A are non-reactive. So, the answer is Hepatitis E.
  • Mode of transmission of Hepatitis viruses:
    • HAV -Feco-oral
    • HBV -Blood (MC), Sexual, Vertical
    • HCV -Blood (MC), Sexual (+/-), Vertical (+/-)
    • HDV -Blood (MC), Sexual(++), Vertical(+)
    • HEV -Feco-oral
  • HBV is the only DNA virus among hepatitis viruses, the family Hepadnaviridae.
  • All other hepatitis viruses are single-stranded RNA viruses.
  • The p gene of HBV is the largest and codes for polymerase (P) protein, having 3 enzymatic activities:
    • DNA polymerase activity,
    • Reverse transcriptase activity and
    • RNase H activity.

Option A: Hepatitis B

  • Hepatitis B infection is also known as silent infection.
  • The people who get infected don't show acute symptoms, mostly.
  • It silently infects and runs a chronic course.

Option C: Hepatitis C

  • Hepatitis C also runs a chronic course.
  • It doesn’t show any signs and symptoms of infection for the first one to three months post-exposure.
  • Individuals are sorted out based on risk factors for the development of hepatitis C.

Option D: Hepatitis D

  • Hepatitis D only occurs in the presence of Hepatitis B.
  • If an individual already has a known case of Hepatitis B and shows acute signs of Hepatitis, then its presence must be confirmed.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to emergency with facial swelling and trouble breathing which began this morning and progressively worsened. On examination, HR-110/min, BP-128/70 mmHg, RR-22/min, and SpO2-96%. Physical study reveals non-pitting oedema of the face, tongue, and mucus membranes of the mouth and pharynx. The patient reports several episodes of mild facial swelling that occurred during childhood. There is no history of any medical illness in this patient. The patient most likely has which of the following underlying abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Option D: Deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor

  • The patient, in this case, presents with the symptoms of facial swelling and shortness of breath. Upon examination, non-pitting oedema is present.

  • The given scenario in the case suggests that the patient has hereditary angioedema. In this condition patient typically presents with recurrent attacks of swelling. It mainly affects the upper part of the body.

  • The cause of the disease occurs by the deficiency or improper functioning of a protein called a C1 esterase inhibitor.

  • Hereditary angioedema is an autosomal dominant disorder and is more common in females than males.

  • Deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor causes increased complement activation with the release of C3a/ C5a causing Hereditary angioedema.

Option A: MHC class I deficiency

  • This protein class is vital in adaptive immunity in the human body.

  • Deficiency of MHC class I can cause recurrent bacterial infections affecting the immune system's balance.

Option B: Defective lysosomal storage proteins

  • Lysosomes are tiny sacs of enzymes that digest the molecules and pass on the fragments for recycling.

  • Defects in them can cause defective lysosomal storage disorder. A deficiency in lysosomal storage proteins characterizes Chediak-Higashi syndrome.

  • It is an autosomal recessive syndrome.

Option C: Lack of NADPH oxidase

  • Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate oxidase is an enzyme that is a critical regulator of antimicrobe host defense and inflammation also.

  • A lack of NADPH oxidase leads to chronic granulomatous disease and recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms.

questions.text: A 27-year-old G2P1 female presents to her gynaecologist for a prenatal visit. She delivered her first child four years ago at 39 weeks with no complications. The patient is vitally stable, and other general physical examinations are unremarkable. Her blood group is A -ve, and her husband is B +ve. The probable diagnosis of Rh incompatibility is made. The doctor explains to the patient that erythroblastosis fetalis can be a probable outcome, which is an example of which of the following hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Option B: Type-II

  • Erythroblastosis fetalis is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

  • Erythroblastosis Fetalis: This condition develops when maternal antibodies specific for fetal blood group antigens cross the placenta and destroy fetal RBCs.

  • This condition is seen in cases where a pre-sensitized Rh-negative mother mounts an immune response against Rh-positive RBCs of the fetus.

  • This results in severe hemolysis, leading to anaemia and hyperbilirubinemia, which can even be fatal.

Other Examples of Type II hypersensitivity:

  • Myasthenia gravis

  • Good pasture syndrome

  • Pernicious anaemia

  • Transfusion reaction

  • Grave’s disease

Option A: Type-I

  • Commonly called an allergic or immediate hypersensitivity reaction.

  • It occurs in 2 phases: Sterilization and the effector phase.

Option C: Type-III

  • Type-III hypersensitivity reactions result from the excess formation of immune complexes (Ag-Ab complexes), which initiate an inflammatory response through activation of the complement system leading to tissue injury.

 

Option D: Type-IV

  • It is delayed-type (after 48–72 hours of antigen exposure).

  • Cell-mediated: Characteristic cells called TDTH cells (Th cells involved in the delayed hypersensitivity) are the principal mediators.

questions.text: A 29-year-old middle school teacher presented to the OPD with lower abdominal pain, laterally irradiated, and dysuria. In urine examination, eggs with terminal spines were seen. Eosinophilia was noted in her bloodwork. Computerized tomography (CT) scans revealed extensive calcifications of the urinary tract. A probable diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder was made on histopathological examination. Which of the following parasite lives in the bladder plexus?
questions.solution:
Option A: Schistosoma

  • Schistosoma (Blood fluke)  lives in the bladder plexus.

S. Haematobium:

  • Resides in the Vesical plexus

  • causes squamous cell carcinoma of the Urinary bladder > Transitional cell Ca

  • Causes Terminal Hematuria

  • The egg has a Terminal spine and is excreted in urine

S. Mansoni:

  • Resides in the Inferior Mesenteric plexus

  • Causes Swimmer’s itch & Katayama fever

  • Eggs are excreted in faeces.

S. Japonicum:

  • Resides in Superior Mesenteric plexus

  • Causes Katayama Fever & Eosinophilic diarrhoea

  • Eggs are excreted in faeces

Symptoms:

  • Initially, people usually do not show any symptoms.

  • After some days, they may develop a rash or itchy skin. Within 1-2 months of infection, symptoms may develop, including fever, chills, cough, and muscle aches.

  • Without treatment, schistosomiasis can persist for years. Signs and symptoms of chronic schistosomiasis include abdominal pain, enlarged liver, blood in the stool or blood in the urine, and problems passing urine. Chronic infection can also lead to an increased risk of liver fibrosis or bladder cancer.

  • Rarely, eggs are found in the brain or spinal cord and can cause seizures, paralysis, or spinal cord inflammation.

Diagnosis:

  • Microscopic observation of eggs in urine or stool.

  • Serology can detect antibodies against schistosomal antigens in the blood.

  • Cystoscopy and endoscopy for visualisation of the lesion.

  • Radiologic techniques allow the visualisation of calcification of the ureter and bladder wall due to the presence of calcified eggs in the submucosa.

Treatment:

  • Praziquantel, as a single dose, is effective for urogenital schistosomiasis.

 

Option B: Echinococcus

  • Echinococcus is also called a hydatid worm, causing hydatid cysts in the liver, lungs and other organs.

  • Although most infections in humans are asymptomatic.

  • Imaging techniques detect cysts, such as CT scans, ultrasonography, and MRIs.

  • Surgery is the most effective way to remove the cyst. Although Chemotherapy, cyst puncture, and PAIR (percutaneous aspiration, injection of chemicals and respiration) have been used to replace surgery as effective treatments for cystic echinococcosis.

Option C: Fasciola

  • It is also called the liver fluke, primarily found in domestic and wild ruminants (their main definitive hosts).

  • Initial symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain/tenderness. Fever, rash, and difficulty breathing may occur.

  • A stool examination of an infected person shows eggs of fasciola.

  • Treat with triclabendazole.

Option D: Ascaris

  • Ascaris lumbricoides cause ascariasis.

  • Most infections are asymptomatic. Ascaris usually causes pneumonia with fever, cough, and Eosinophilia and also intestinal blockage and peroration can occur with a heavy larval burden.

  • Diagnosis: Microscopically detecting eggs (eggs with rugosity) in the stools.

  • Treatment: Albendazole, mebendazole, and ivermectin are effective.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents in the outpatient department with complaints of fever and abdominal pain for 2 days associated with diarrhoea, anorexia, and weight loss. On abdominal examination, there is abdominal distension and hepatomegaly. The sample from the abdominal abscess contained thick chocolate brown pus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Amoebic liver abscess

  • In the above-given case, the presence of fever, with abdominal pain, diarrhoea, hepatomegaly, and thick chocolate brown pus, is suggestive of an Amoebic liver abscess.
  • Amoebic liver abscess is the most likely diagnosis.
  • Entamoeba histolytica causes an amoebic liver abscess.

Extra intestinal amoebiasis:

  • Trophozoites secrete Cysteine proteinase → Erode intestinal layers → Flask Shaped Ulcers →Via portal circulation → Liver.
  • Most common site → Liver > Lungs > Brain.
  • Chocolate pus/Anchovy sauce pus formed due to damage to hepatocytes.
  • It is bacteriologically sterile & free of Amoeba.
  • The right lobe (superior posterior portion) is involved.
  • A liver abscess may be multiple on, more often, solitary, usually located on the upper right lobe of the liver.
  • Investigation of choice → ELISA.

Signs of amoebic liver abscess are:

  • Painful hepatomegaly, fever, anorexia, nausea, and weight Loss.

Option A: Amoebic colitis

  • It is caused by Entamoeba histolytica.
  • It is a common cause of diarrhoea.
  • A colonoscopy with histological examination is used for the diagnosis of this disease.

Option B: Amoebiasis cutis

  • It occurs due to the amoebic dysentery complication.
  • It is also caused by Entamoeba histolytica.
  • It causes primary cutaneous amoebiasis from pre-existing wound contamination.

Option D: Pulmonary amoebiasis

  • It can occur with bacterial pneumonia, which causes long illness and death.
  • It causes the haematogenous spread from the colon, and then it involves the lungs and brain.
  • It causes serious, exudative and reactive pleural effusion.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of fever and loose motion for 2 days. She further gives a history of foul-smelling fatty stools for 3 days. She has no history of any chronic illness. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities Analysis of stool reveals the causative organism, which is shown in the image below. Which of the following organism is the cause of the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option C: Giardia

  • This is a case of giardiasis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, loose motion, and foul-smelling stools for 2 days.
  • This is trophozoite with 4 pairs of flagella which are seen in trophozoite of giardia.
  • It has a characteristic tennis racquet appearance/teardrop shape.
  • Motility – falling leaf-like motility (due to 4 pairs of flagella.)

        1. Giardia causes noninvasive diarrhoea, so there will be no RBCs.

        2. In acute giardiasis, diarrhoea is often foul-smelling with fat and mucus without blood. It causes G.I. disturbances

        3. Microscopy: Demonstration of either trophozoite (active infection) or cyst (carrier) sample by iodine and saline wet mount preparations.

Option A: Entamoeba histolytica

  • In Entamoeba histolytica, no flagella were seen.

                                  

Option B: Trichomonas

  • In Trichomonas, 5 pairs of flagella are seen in trophozoite.
  • Out of five flagella, four of which are oriented anteriorly and one of which is directed posteriorly along the undulating membrane's outer membrane.

                                          

Option D: Naegleria fowleri

  • In  Naegleria fowleri - no flagella were seen
  • It causes primary amoebic meningoencephalitis.

Naegleria fowleri | CDC" src="https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/naegleria/images/NagleriaStages.jpg?_=97743" />

questions.text: A 27-year-old man, skidded off the highway while taking his new bike for a ride to test its speed limits. In his excitement to have himself videotaped during the act, he chose to avoid using a helmet. Immediately after the fall, he remained unconscious for 5 mins and was revived by the bystanders. As he did not show signs of any other injury, he was helped back to his house by his friend. After a few hours, his family noticed him becoming drowsy, seemingly confused and also not obeying commands. What is the most probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Extradural hematoma

  • The history suggests LUCID INTERVAL, which is a feature seen in extradural hemorrhage.
  • A lucid interval is a state of consciousness between two episodes of unconsciousness.
  • Head trauma → Unconsciousness → Consciousness → Unconsciousness → Coma or death.
  • In a typical case, there is a history of head injury which starts the bleeding and mostly causes temporary unconsciousness. In some cases, there could be no unconsciousness in the beginning, which is followed by a period of normal consciousness, i.e. "Lucid Interval" and can range from a few hours (2 to 4) to a week.
  • Due to hemorrhage as the pressure on the brain increases, the patient becomes confused and may appear to be drunk. With further increase in pressure, sleep or coma occurs.

Option B: Subdural hematoma

  • SDH is caused due to acceleration-deceleration injury in which there is significant primary damage to brain parenchyma.
  • Hematoma is often not associated with a fracture of the skull. Commonly seen in the elderly and alcoholics.
  • The location of an SDH does not necessarily correlate to the location of the blunt force impact site.
  • In infants < 1 year, the subdural space is narrower and less tolerant of space-occupying lesions.
  • SDHs are classified in clinical terms as acute, subacute, chronic or acute on chronic depending on the length of history, the neuroimaging findings, and the appearance of the blood when the hematoma is drained.

Option C: Subarachnoid hematoma

  • SAH is common in TBI. Even in minor head trauma, a small amount of localized SAH over the cerebral convexities is almost invariably seen.
  • Like SDH, the location does not correlate with the site of impact in blunt force trauma, but usually, SAH is most prominent close to its source.
  • SAH is extensive because CSF and un-clotted subarachnoid blood flow freely in the subarachnoid space.
  • Types:
    • Immediate.
    • Delayed/reactionary hemorrhage—until the initial contraction and retraction of vessels have subsided (delayed post-traumatic SAH).

Option D: Cerebral edema

  • Cerebral edema is also known as brain swelling. It’s a life-threatening condition that causes fluid to develop in the brain.
  • Features: Flattening of the surface of the gyri and narrowing, effacement of the sulci causing a smooth, flat outline on the normal undulations of the surface of the cerebral hemisphere. Brain swelling also causes narrowness of the cerebral ventricles, and when it is localized, it may cause a herniation.

questions.text: When the body of the 26-year-old woman was brought in for an autopsy, it appeared to be in rigor mortis, helping the doctor understand that the time of death was at least 6 to 8 hours prior. Rigor mortis, the postmortem rigidity, is the third stage of death. It is one of the recognizable signs of death, characterized by stiffening of the limbs of the corpse caused by chemical changes in the muscles postmortem. It follows all of the following rules, except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Morrison

  • Rule of Morrison: This rule states that the crown heel length of the fetus in centimetres, divided by five gives the age in months.
  • It does not relate to rigor mortis.

Option A: Shapiro

  • Rigor mortis is a biochemical process which is occurring simultaneously in all the muscles.
  • In small muscles, rigidity appears earlier
  • In larger muscles, rigidity appears later

Option B: Nysten

  • Nysten's rule: Rigor mortis occurs in a specific sequence
  • Eyelid →Neck →Jaw →Face →Thorax →Upper Limb → Abdomen →Lower Limb →Fingers / Toes.

Option D: Rule of 12

  • Rule of 12: 
    • Rigor mortis starts in 60 minutes and reaches a maximum in 12 hrs.
    • Rigor mortis stays in the body for 12 hrs and disappears from the body in another 12 hrs.

questions.text: The body of the 55-year-old businessman has been found in his beach house. Autopsy findings reveal the presence of Simon's hemorrhage, which provided the forensic team with evidence of the possible cause of death. Which among the following statement is true about Simon's hemorrhage?

choices.text: Bleeding onto outer layers of intervertebral discs

questions.solution:
Option B: Bleeding onto outer layers of intervertebral discs

  • Simon's bleedings are hemorrhages into the anterior aspect of the intervertebral discs of the lumbar region and are usually considered a classic sign of vitality in cases of hanging with full suspension of the body.

Option A: Seen in cases of drowning

  • Simon’s hemorrhages are seen in the case of hanging.

Option C: Seen in thoracic region

  • Simon’s hemorrhages are seen in the lumbar region.

Option D: Pathognomic sign of asphyxia

  • Simon's bleedings, in cases of asphyxiation, most likely occur due to agonal convulsions and forced movements in the lumbosacral part of the spinal column.

questions.text: A teenage girl was found dead in her room. On postmortem examination following appearances were found. Images show the appearance of the neck on external examination and findings of neck dissection. Which of the following is the most probable cause of death in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Throttling

  • Externally contusion marks on fingernails are seen and internally severe contusion marks on soft tissue are present.
  • This is characteristic of manual strangulation or throttling.

Option B: Strangulation

  • Neck constriction by any means with no body suspension is known as strangulation.
  • Strangulation will cause a ligature mark over the neck. So this option is wrong.

Option C: Hanging

  • It is a form of asphyxia, caused by the suspension of the body by a ligature which encircles the neck.
  • Constricting force is the weight of the body.
  • Hanging and strangulation will cause a ligature mark over the neck. So it is excluded.

Option D: Traumatic asphyxia

  • Asphyxia resulting from respiratory arrest due to mechanical fixation of the chest, so that the normal movements of the chest wall are prevented.
  • One man does smothering while another seating over his chest causing traumatic asphyxia.

questions.text: Driving while drunk is a universally punishable act. Not only is the driver putting his own life at risk, but also puts the lives of others on the road at high risk. The permissible level of blood alcohol for driving in India is 30mg%. What is the critical level of alcohol in blood above which there is impairment in driving?
questions.solution:
Option A: 0.1%

  • 0.05% - 0.10%: Slight impairment
  • 0.10% - 0.15%: Under the influence.
  • Acute alcohol Poisoning Stages
    • Excitement: 50-150mg%
    • Incoordination: 150-250mg%
    • Coma: > 300mg%
  • The permissible level of blood alcohol for driving in India = 30mg%

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman was rescued from near the highway in the early hours of the morning. She was nearly unconscious but was able to record her statement while being treated by the doctors. She was allegedly abducted and raped by 2 unidentified men. The doctor was able to demonstrate presence of Spermine. Which of the following test was done by the doctor?
questions.solution:
Option A: 3 hours

  • When semen is kept at room temperature, full motility persists for about three hours; fifty percent are motile by eight hours, and ten percent for 24 hours. If the specimen is kept at body temperature, motility persists for several hours. In living persons, motile sperms are usually seen up to six hours and rarely 12 hours after ejaculation into the vagina.

questions.text: A rural PHC of 50,000 population needs multipurpose workers. Which of the following committee will recommend Multipurpose workers under health and family planning?
questions.solution:
Option C: Kartar Singh committee

  • "Multi-purpose Workers" was introduced by Kartar Singh Committee and is also known as ‘Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning.
  • Recommended ‘female health supervisor’ and ‘Male health supervisor’.
  • 1 PHC per 50,000 population

 

Option A: Bhore committee (1946)

  • School Health was first recommended by the Bhore committee.
  • Bhore committee: ‘Health survey and Development committee’.
    • Short-term measure: 1 PHC per 40,000 population, 30 beds, 3 subcenters, and 2 medical officers.
    • Long-term measures (3 million): Primary health units with 75- bedded hospitals per 10,000- 20,000 population, secondary health units with 650- bedded hospitals, and Regional health units with 2,500 beds.
    • Prepare ‘Social Physicians’ (3 months of training in preventive and social medicine in medical education).
    • School Health
    • Comprehensive health care concept:
      • Promotive - Primordial level
      • Preventive - Primary level
      • Curative - Secondary level

Option B: Chadha committee

  • Constituted to study arrangements necessary for the ‘Maintenance Phase of the National Malaria Eradication Programmme (NMEP).
  • 1 Basic Health Worker per 10,000 population (for malaria vigilance, collection of vital statistics, and family planning).
  • Family Planning Health Assistants to supervise 3-4 basic health workers.

Option D: Shrivastava Committee (1975)

  • Group on Medical Education and Support Manpower.
  • Create ‘Bands of Paraprofessionals and Semi-professional health workers’ from within the community.
  • Establish Health Assistants.
  • Development of ‘Referral Services Complex’ (Primary - Secondary - Tertiary).
  • Establishment of ‘The Medical and Health Education Commission.
  • Reorientation of Medical Education (ROME) Scheme.
  • ‘Village Health Guide (Community Health Worker) Scheme’.
  • ‘3-tier system of Health care delivery – Subcentre, PHC, CHC.

questions.text: 50 people are suffering from cholera in a population of 5000. Out of 50 suffering from cholera, 10 died. But the total number of deaths is 50. What is the death rate?
questions.solution:
Death rate is calculated as the total number of deaths per 1000 population.

Death rate = Total number of death / Total population

= 50 / 5000

= 10 / 1000

Since 50 persons died in 5000 population, the death rate would be 10 per 1000.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with her baby presented to the hospital with the inability of her baby to suck breastmilk, fever, inability of open mouth, excessive crying and stiffness. The physician diagnosed this condition as neonatal tetanus. Neonatal tetanus prevention is best done by _____________ antenatal measure?
questions.solution:
Neonatal tetanus is referred to as 8-day disease because the 1st sign appears on the 8th day of life.

  • Period of communicability: None
  • Herd Immunity: Does not protect
  • Vaccine: TT (Tetanus toxoid) given as DPT at
    • 6w, 10w, 14w
    • 1st Booster: 16-24 months
    • 2nd Booster: 5 years age
    • TT at 10 yrs. of age
    • TT at 16 yrs. of age
    • During pregnancy
  • TT given at 10y, 16y, pregnant females is replaced with Td vaccine.
  • Neonatal tetanus can be prevented by giving:
    • Primigravida: 2 doses of td as soon as possible.
    • Multigravida: If pregnancy occurs within 3 years of 1st pregnancy -1 dose of td booster is given.
    • If pregnancy occurs after 3 yrs of 1st pregnancy: 2 doses should be repeated.

questions.text: A 23-Year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain, vomiting, nausea and loss of appetite. The physician examined bulbar conjunctiva for yellowness in the patient, which is a test for Jaundice and for which he is been trained during his graduation. Which of the following is true for this kind of method for detecting Jaundice?

choices.text: Lacks both validity as well as reliability
Has both, adequate validity as well as reliability

questions.solution:
Answer

Option A: Lacks validity

  • This method of detecting jaundice is not valid (accuracy is close to true/actual value) since there will be lots of false positives and false negatives.
  • Examining the bulbar conjunctiva for yellowness is not a highly valid diagnostic method for jaundice because it may not accurately identify the presence or severity of jaundice. Validity in this context refers to the extent to which the test accurately measures what it is intended to measure. It lacks reliability as well, as the results may vary based on factors such as lighting conditions and the examiner's experience.

Other options

Option B: Lacks reliability

  • The method may be reliable (precision is repeatability), as she is well-trained in it and will always detect discoloration of the conjunctiva.

Option C: Lacks both validity as well as reliability

  • This method is not valid but reliable.

Option D: Has both, adequate validity as well as reliability

  • This method of detecting jaundice is not valid (accuracy is close to true/actual value), but it may be reliable (precision is repeatability).

questions.text: A screening test was positive in 50% of the diseased and 10% of the healthy population. What is the specificity of the test?
questions.solution:
Option B: 0.9

Screening Test

 

Gold Standard/  Disease 

 
Positive/present  Negative/ Absent 
Positive 50 (a) 10  (b)
Negative 50  (c) 90   (d) 
  • As seen in the table above,
  • The screening test was positive for 50% diseased meaning true positive is 50%, and therefore false negative should also be 50%.
  • The test was also positive in 10% of healthy patients. That means a false positive is 10%, and therefore a true negative will be 90%.

Specificity = d/(b + d) x 100 

=90/ (90 + 10) x 100

= 90%

= 0.9

questions.text: An intern was posted on duty in the delivery ward where he examined all the pregnancy cases. All of the following are considered as High-risk pregnancy except:

choices.text: Short statured primi (150 cm and below)
History of previous caesarean or instrumental delivery
Prolonged pregnancy (14 days after expected date of delivery)

questions.solution:
Short-statured primi (150 cm and below)

  • Short-statured primigravida of height 140 cm and below are considered the high-risk case.
  • The central purpose of antenatal care is to identify "high-risk" cases as early as possible from a large group of antenatal mother and arrange skilled care while continuing to provide appropriate care for all mothers.
  • High-risk cases:
    • Elderly primigravida (30 years and over).
    • Short-statured primigravida (140 cm and below).
    • Malpresentations (breech, transverse lie, etc.)
    • Antepartum hemorrhage, Threatened abortion.
    • Pre-eclampsia and eclampsia.
    • Anemia
    • Twins, hydramnios
    • Previous stillbirths, intrauterine death, manual removal of placenta.
    • Elderly grand multiparas.
    • Prolonged pregnancy (14 days after the expected date of delivery).
    • History of previous cesarean or instrumental delivery.
    • Pregnancy associated with general diseases (cardiovascular disease, kidney disease, diabetes, tuberculosis, liver disease, malaria, convulsions, asthma, HIV, RTI, STI, etc.)
    • Treatment for infertility.
    • Three or more spontaneous consecutive abortions.

questions.text: These are homes where children are placed under the supervision of doctors and psychiatrists. What are they called?
questions.solution:
Remand Homes:

  • The child is placed in a medical facility.
  • Psychiatrists and other qualified individuals to promote mental and physical health the child's physical well-being.

Foster Homes

  • In Foster Homes there are several different types of facilities for raising children compared to natural families.

Orphanages

  • Orphanages is for children who have no home or whose parents are unable to care for them.

Child guidance clinics

  • Child guidance clinics are specialized clinics for children with normal and abnormal intelligence, behavior and psychological problem.
  • Adoption: Adoption grants legal rights on both the kid and the adoptive parents. Parents have the same rights and duties as natural parents.

questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to compare rapid and slow sand filters by his senior. All of the following are true for Rapid sand filters except?

choices.text: No preliminary storage of raw water is required
Can be gravity type or pressure type

questions.solution:
Option C: Frequent washing is not required

  • A slow sand filter does not require frequent washing, but a Rapid sand filter requires frequent washing.

Rapid Sand filter

  • No preliminary storage of raw water is required.
  • Operation requires highly skilled persons.
  • Can be gravity type or pressure type.
  • Required frequent washing.
  • Suitable in big cities.

Option A: No preliminary storage of raw water is required

  • No preliminary storage of raw water is required for a rapid sand filter.

Option B: Operation requires highly skilled persons

  • Operation requires highly skilled persons in the rapid sand filters.

Option D: Can be gravity type or pressure type

  • Rapid sand filters can be gravity type or pressure type.
