questions.text: Mass chemoprophylaxis is indicated for a rural village in an outbreak of some disease. In which of the following disease chemoprophylaxis is not indicated?
questions.solution:
Option A: Typhoid

  • The primary cause of typhoid fever is S.typh, which is exclusively found in humans. Clinical signs of the illness include a characteristic, prolonged fever lasting three to four weeks, relative bradycardia with lymphoid tissue involvement, and significant constitutional symptoms.
  • Typhoid and paratyphoid fevers are both referred to as an enteric fevers. Disease outbreaks can be sporadic, epidemic, or endemic.
  • There is no role of Chemoprophylaxis in Typhoid.

Option B: Meningococcal meningitis

  • Cerebrospinal fever, often known as meningococcal meningitis, is an acute contagious illness brought on by N.meningitidis. In most cases, it starts out with a severe headache, vomiting, and stiff neck and quickly develops into a coma.
  • Meningitis is a septicemic process component. About 80%of typical untreated cases end in death.
  • Rifampicin, Ciprofloxacin & Ceftriaxone are used for chemoprophylaxis in meningococcal meningitis.

Option C: COVID-19

  • It may require mass prophylaxis

Option D: Plague

  • Rodents and fleas are involved in the plague, which is essentially and fundamentally a zoonosis caused by Y pestis. It exists in natural foci and is spread to people who live in or trespass into the same ecological habitat by infected flea bites.
  • Tetracycline is used to treat cholera.
  • Chemoprophylaxis: Tetracycline for pneumonic plague contacts.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male bitten by a tick presented to the hospital with headache, nausea, muscle aches, and a blackened crusted rash on the site of the bite. The physician sent him for performing an indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA) with the R.rickettsii antigen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: RMSF

  • Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF) is a bacterial disease spread through the bite of an infected tick.
  • Signs and symptoms can include Fever, Headache, Rash, Nausea, Vomiting, Stomach pain, Muscle pain, and Lack of appetite.
  • Doxycycline is the most effective antibiotic for the treatment of suspected rickettsial infections, including Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF).

Other options

Option A: Epidemic typhus

  • Epidemic typhus is transmitted by louse.

Option B: Endemic typhus

  • Endemic typhus is transmitted by rat flea.

Option C: Scrub typhus

  • Scrub typhus and Rickettsial pox are transmitted by mites.

questions.text: An urban area population reported many cases of malaria. Which among the following is the most efficient anti-larval measures to prevent urban malaria?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cover overhead tanks properly

  • Lids of overhead tanks must be checked and maintained monthly basis; any leakage is repaired immediately.
  • Cover-up of underground and open tanks.

Learning Objective

  • Recommended measures for urban malaria control:
    • Lids of overhead tanks must be checked and maintained monthly basis; any leakage is repaired immediately.
    • Cover-up of underground and open tanks.
    • Open tanks used for animals should be dead-dried once in week.
    • Never throw any containers in the open which are capable of holding water.
    • Building by-laws be implemented to prevent fault in designs, water flow on roof, gully traps.
    • Open tanks are treated with larvicides on weekly basis.
    • Unused wells either be closed or treated with larvicides.
    • Ornamental tanks and fountains are checked periodically & larvivorous fishes are introduced.
    • Proper drainage, periodic flushing of waterlogged areas and drainage.

questions.text: The National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) is a centrally sponsored Health Scheme and it has been implemented with the major objective of reducing the disease burden, preventing disability, and improving awareness among the mass about Leprosy and its curability. What does ‘Accompanied MDT’ in NLEP imply?

choices.text: A patient will be given MDT only in the presence of an MDT provider
MDT should be accompanied by steroids / Clofazimine to help fight reversal reactions
Any responsible person from the family or village can collect MDT if the patient is unable to come
MDT prescription should be accompanied by all the precautions to be observed by the patient

questions.solution:
Option C: Any responsible person from the family or village can collect MDT if the patient is unable to come

  • ‘Accompanied MDT’ in NLEP imply If the patient is unable to come to collect his/her MDT from the clinic, any responsible person from the family or village can collect it.

Option A: A patient will be given MDT only in the presence of an MDT provider

  • If the patient is unable to come to pick up his or her MDT from the clinic, any responsible member of the family or village may collect it, according to the NLEP definition of "accompanied MDT."

Option B: MDT should be accompanied by steroids / Clofazimine to help fight reversal reactions

  • ‘Accompanied MDT’ in NLEP does not imply this statement.

Option D: MDT prescription should be accompanied by all the precautions to be observed by the patient

  • The phrase "associated MDT" in the NLEP does not mean that a patient's prescription for MDT should also include a list of all the precautions they should take.

questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to explain different types of correlation. Which among the following is the true statement regarding Correlation COEFFICIENT?

choices.text: Percentage change in one variable that can be explained by change in another variable
In a perfectly negative correlation, a rise in one variable leads to a proportionate rise in other
Percentage change in many variable that can be explained by change in another variable
In a perfectly positive correlation, a rise in one variable leads to a proportionate fall in other

questions.solution:
Option A: Percentage change in one variable that can be explained by change in another variable

  • Percentage change in one variable that can be explained by change in another variable is the correct answer

  • Example: 1

    r height & Wt = +0.7

    · It implies positive correlation (increase ht.weight should increase)

    · If ht. increase by 1 unit, wt. is expected to increased by 0.7 unit

    r2 = (+0.7)2 =+0.49

  • Interpretation

    · 49% increase in wt. of person, can be due to increase in ht.

Other options

Option B: In a perfectly negative correlation, a rise in one variable leads to a proportionate rise in other

  • In a perfectly negative correlation, a rise in one variable leads to a proportionate fall in another.
  • In a perfectly positive correlation, a rise in one variable leads to a proportionate rise in other.

Option C: Percentage change in many variable that can be explained by change in another variable

  • This option is incorrect 
  • Percentage change in one variable that can be explained by change in another variable is correct answer 

Option D: In a perfectly positive correlation, a rise in one variable leads to a proportionate fall in other

  • In a perfectly positive correlation, a rise in one variable leads to a proportionate rise in other.
  • In a perfectly negative correlation, a rise in one variable leads to a proportionate fall in another.

questions.text: The “P” value of a randomized controlled trial comparing operation A (new procedure) & Operation B (Gold standard) is 0.04. From this, we conclude that:

choices.text: Type II error is small & we can accept the findings of the study
The probability of a false negative conclusion that operation A is better than operation B when in truth it is not, is 4%
The power of the study to detect a difference between operations A & B is 96%
The probability of a false positive conclusion that ‘Operation A is better than Operation B’, when in truth it is not, is 4%

questions.solution:
Option D: The probability of a false positive conclusion that  ‘Operation A is better than Operation B’, when in truth it is not, is 4%

  • In the given question, the “p” values of a randomized controlled trial comparing operation A (new procedure) & operation B (Gold standard) is 0.04
  • Thus, the probability of committing a type I error is 0.04 or 4% i.e., the Probability of declaring a false positive conclusion that ‘operation A is better than operation B’, when in truth it is not, is 4.

questions.text: A nominal variable is a type of variable that is used to name, label, or categorize particular attributes that are being measured. Which of the following is an example of a Nominal variable?
questions.solution:
Option B: Black hair color

  • Black hair color is an identity in the class ; Hence it is an example of a nominal variable.

Other options

Option A: Temperature

  • Ratio scale (Presence of absolute zero; thus ratios are possible).
  • Examples: Weight, Height, Blood glucose, Hemoglobin level, Serum cholesterol, Mid-arm circumference, Blood pressure, Pulse rate, and Kelvin temperature scale.

Option C: TNM staging

  • Ordinal scale: Based on ORD (order); grading into categories.
  • Examples: TNM staging (cancers), Severity of disease, Social classes.

Option D: Mid-arm circumference

  • Ratio scale (Presence of absolute zero; thus ratios are possible).
  • Examples: Weight, Height, Blood glucose, Hemoglobin level, Serum cholesterol, Mid-arm circumference, Blood pressure, Pulse rate, Kelvin temperature scale.

questions.text: The National TB Programme (NTP) was launched by the Government of India in 1962 in the form of District TB Centre model involved with BCG vaccination and TB treatment. Which of the following is the most peripheral laboratory under RNTCP?
questions.solution:
Option D: Designated microscopy centre

  • Most peripheral Laboratory under RNTCP is Designated microscopy center (DMC’s).
  • Plains - 1/100,000 population
  • Hilly / Tribals - 1/50,000 population
  • It is maintained by a trained lab technician
  • 1 TB unit - 1/5,00,000 pop. (i.e.. 5 DMC’s)
  • Maintained by senior TB lab supervision.

Option A: Tuberculosis unit

  • A subdistrict supervisory unit called the tuberculosis unit was created for the 500,000 people living there (250,000 in tribal and hilly areas).
  • Each TU has received a Senior Tuberculosis Lab Supervisor from the programme on a contract basis for the purpose of conducting External quality assessment activities, including on-site evaluation visits to DMCs and random blinded rechecking of standard Designated Microscopy Centre slides, both of which are organized by the District TB officer at the District TB Centre level.

Option B: Peripheral reference laboratory

  • Most peripheral Laboratory under RNTCP is Designated microscopy center (DMCs).

Option C: Intermediate reference laboratory

  • Each state has at least one Intermediate reference laboratory (IRL), which is either located on the State Tuberculosis Demonstration and Training Centre campus or in a specific area of a government hospital.
  • The IRL was initially created to serve as a Culture and Drug Susceptibility Testing facility for the State's smear External Quality Assessment Program and to conduct state-wide TB Drug Resistance Surveillance.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presents with complaints of gradually increasing dyspnea on exertion over the past 2 years. On examination, she has an apical diastolic murmur. On further workup with echocardiography, a hockey-stick appearance is seen. Which of the following is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mitral stenosis

On Echocardiography:

  • The mitral valve's normal, biphasic, and rapid motion is altered because it opens only partly and as a single unit.
  • The posterior leaflet becomes immobile, and the anterior mitral leaflet tethering produces a "hockey stick" appearance.
  • These changes obstruct the blood flow from the atrium to the ventricle

Option B: Digoxin effect

  • Here Downslopping ST depression with characteristic 'reverse tick' or 'Salvador Dali sagging' appearnace or 'hockey stick sign', shortened QT interval, flattened, inverted or biphasic T waves are seen

Option C: Aortic stenosis

  • The key findings on TTE are thickening, calcification, reduced systolic opening of the valve leaflets and LV hypertrophy. 
  • Eccentric closure of the aortic valve cusps is characteristic of congenitally bicuspid valves.
  • TEE imaging can display the obstructed orifice extremely well, but it is not routinely required to characterise AS accurately.
  • The valve gradient and aortic valve area can be estimated by Doppler measurement of the transaortic velocity.

Valve size

Grade of AS
  • < 1.5 – 2 cm2
  • Mild AS
  • < 1.0-1.5 cm2
  • Moderate AS
  • < 1.0 cm2
  • Severe AS
  • The echo in AS does not show a hockey stick sign.

Option D: Aortic regurgitation

  • ECHO is the investigation of Choice in AR, but it does not show a hockey stick sign.
  • LV size increases in chronic AR, and systolic function is normal or even supernormal until myocardial contractility declines, as signalled by a decrease in ejection fraction (EF) or increase in the end-systolic dimension.
  • A characteristic finding is a rapid, high-frequency diastolic fluttering of the anterior mitral leaflet produced by the impact of the regurgitant jet.
  • The echocardiogram is also useful in determining the cause of AR by detecting dilation of the aortic annulus and root, aortic dissection

questions.text: A 68-years-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of dyspnea and symmetrical swelling of both legs. On examination, his JVP is 10cm. Diagnosis of heart failure is suspected. 2D-Echo is done, which reveals LVEF>50%. Which of the following drug is effective in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: ARB with a neprilysin inhibitor

  • In HFpEF (heart failure with preserved ejection fraction), ARBs and Neprilysin inhibitors are given.
  • In HFrEF (heart failure with reduced ejection fraction), ACE inhibitors and Beta Blockers are given.
  • Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, or HFpEF for short, is a clinical syndrome in which patients have signs and symptoms of heart failure (HF) as the result of high left ventricular (LV) filling pressure despite having normal or near normal left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF> 50%).
  • The majority of individuals diagnosed with HFpEF also have normal left ventricular sizes but an aberrant diastolic filling pattern, i.e., diastolic dysfunction. 
  • The goals of treatment for individuals who have HFpEF are to lessen the severity of HF symptoms, improve their functional level, and lessen the likelihood that they may require hospitalization. 
  • If the patient's blood pressure is not at the target despite using the highest tolerable dosages of diuretics and a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist, antihypertensive medications such as ARBs and Neprilysin inhibitors are normally considered to be safe for use in individuals who have HFpEF.

Option A: Digoxin

  • Digoxin has no role in the treatment of HFpEF.
  • Digoxin is ineffective, increases oxygen demand of the heart and can be detrimental.

Option C: Isosorbide mononitrate

  • In the NEAT-HFpEF trial, no improvement in QOL or submaximal exercise capacity in patients with HFpEF was seen.

Option D: Phosphodiesterase inhibitor

  • RELAX trial: No improvement in functional capacity, quality of life (QOL), or other clinical and surrogate parameters in patients with HFpEF was seen.

questions.text: A 24 years old fourth-year medical student is attending round in the pulmonology ward. Due to a lack of PPE, a doctor contracted a COVID-19 infection. He has been started on Azithromycin and Hydroxychloroquine. He has five pack-year smoking history. He does not use alcohol or any other illicit drug. His father died of cardiac disease at the age of 35. A few days after starting the medication, he felt uneasy and collapsed. He also complained of dizziness, racing heart, and lightheadedness. He has also experienced cold sweats during this period. He was rushed to ER, where the following ECG recording was obtained. The ECG is shown below. Which of the following is correct about the condition shown?

choices.text: Triggered by early after depolarization during phase 3 of repolarization
Triggered by drug induced shortening of QT interval

questions.solution:
Option B: Triggered early after depolarization during phase 3 of repolarization

  • The above scenario depicts torsades de pointes triggered by a combination of azithromycin and hydroxychloroquine.
  • Torsades de pointes is polymorphic ventricular tachycardia characterized by oscillatory changes in the amplitude of QRS complexes around the isoelectric line. It may also progress to ventricular fibrillation. Long QT interval predisposes to torsades de pointes.
  • The ECG of torsades de pointes is shown below.

  • Drugs responsible for torsades de pointes include antiarrhythmics, macrolides, fluoroquinolones, haloperidol, chloroquine, tricyclic anti-depressants, ondansetron, fluconazole, protease inhibitors, methadone, etc.
  • Prolongation of QT interval due to metabolic abnormalities like hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalcemia. Whenever the QT interval is prolonged, there can be fatal arrhythmia in the form of torsades de pointes
  • Erythromycin and hydroxychloroquine also cause QT interval prolongation and lead to Torsade de Pointes. Torsades de pointes due to the alternation of phase 3 of repolarization, which is mediated by activation of the delayed rectifier potassium current (IK) moving outward while the inward positive current decays.
  • During this phase 3, early depolarization occurs, which triggers this arrhythmia.
  • Early afterdepolarizations (EADs) can induce ventricular arrhythmias such as torsades de pointes.
  • The first step in managing torsades de pointes is preventing its onset by targeting the modifiable risk factors.
  • This includes discontinuing any QT interval prolonging drug and correcting the electrolyte profile of the patient.
  • The treatment of torsades de pointes includes isoproterenol infusion, cardiac pacing, and intravenous atropine.
  • Magnesium sulfate is used in the management of torsades de pointes. It suppresses early afterdepolarizations and terminates the arrhythmia. It decreases the calcium influx and lowers the amplitude early after depolarization. Magnesium is also being shown to stabilize the cardiac membrane.

Option A: Supraventricular tachycardia with aberrant conduction

  • Aberrant conduction means conduction through the AV node with delay or block.
  • Any tachycardic rhythm with a left or right bundle branch block that is NOT ventricular tachycardia is considered supraventricular tachycardia with aberrancy.

Option C: Bidirectional tachycardia

  • It is a rare form of tachycardia.
  • It is characterized by surface electrocardiogram by dual QRS morphologies alternating on a beat-to-beat basis.
  • It is caused by digitalis toxicity or channelopathies.

Option D: Triggered by drug-induced shortening of QT interval

  • Mallotoxin, levcromakalim, and nicorandil have all been reported to shorten APD and QT intervals significantly
  • Mutations in the KCNH2, KCNJ2, and KCNQ1 genes can cause short QT syndrome.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female comes to the diabetic clinic for a routine checkup. She was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type-2 and hypertension 12 years back. Her body mass index is 32kg/m2. Dietary and lifestyle modifications such as exercise failed to provide adequate glycemic control. She is currently on insulin and antihypertensive therapy. On examination, her face looks puffy, and her legs and feet show bilateral oedema. Estimated glomerular filtration rate is 26 ml/min/1.73m2, urine albumin to creatinine ratio is 270mg/g. She was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease stage G4A2 (CKD stage 4). Which of the following is the most appropriate insulin dose adjustment required in this patient with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Option B: Decrease insulin.

  • Diabetes mellitus (DM) is a disease of beta cells of the pancreas.
  • It is characterized by polydipsia, polyphagia, polyuria, fatigue, weight loss, blurred vision, fungal infections, numbness and tingling of hands and feet, diabetic ketoacidosis, and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state.
  • This patient has diabetes mellitus and hypertension, which are the most common risk factors for developing chronic kidney disease.
  • Chronic kidney disease (CKD) :
    • It is defined as decreased kidney function (low glomerular filtration rate(GFR) <60ml/min) for at least 3 months. It is classified based on glomerular filtration rate, urine albumin to creatinine ratio, and the underlying pathology. 
  • The kidneys play an important role in insulin degradation and removal from circulation.
  • The plasma half-life of insulin can rise in patients with chronic kidney disease in both fasting and postprandial states.
    • Because of decreased renal degradation of plasma insulin, patients on insulin therapy may need a progressive reduction in their dose as their renal function decreases.
    • Oral hypoglycemics such as sulfonylureas and metformin are contraindicated when the glomerular filtration rate is less than normal. Others, such as DPP-4 inhibitors (sitagliptin), may require dose reduction in renal failure.
  • Glucose metabolism is impaired in CKD. However, fasting blood glucose is usually normal or only slightly elevated, and mild glucose intolerance does not require specific therapy.

Option A: Increase insulin.

  • In chronic kidney disease, insulin dosage should be reduced due to impaired clearance of insulin by the kidneys.

Option C: No adjustment.

  • Dose adjustment of insulin is required in patients with chronic kidney disease.

Option D: Add DPP-4 inhibitors.

  • The kidneys clear DPP-4 inhibitors such as sitagliptin, so they should not be used to treat a patient with chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A 41-year-old diabetic woman comes to her endocrinologist after she has found that her random finger-stick blood glucose level has been high on various occasions. She is already on a single drug, metformin therapy. Her temperature is 98°F, blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg and pulse is 90 beats per minute. Her HbA1c is found to be 7.2. Her BMI is 34, and she wants to lose the weight, but she has gained. She has a history of pancreatitis and a family history of bladder cancer in her mother. The physician talks to her regarding an additional anti-diabetic therapy. The patient does not want to take injections. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Option C: Canagliflozin

  • Metformin is the first-line oral therapy for patients with T2DM. Diabetic patients are started on single-drug therapy based on their blood glucose levels.
  • She does not want to take any injection drug, so the selected drug should be available in an oral formulation. Moreover, she is already morbidly obese and is trying to lose weight, so the drug should not have any side-effect of weight gain.
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors inhibit the Na+ - Glucose cotransporter in the kidneys and decrease the renal uptake of glucose, thereby decreasing the blood glucose levels. So, Canagliflozin is a good choice for this patient as it can be given orally, reduces cardiovascular risk, and does not cause any weight gain.

Option A: Sitagliptin 

  • Sitagliptin is a DPP4 inhibitor that reduces glucose by various mechanisms, including increasing insulin sensitivity, pancreatic cells' sensitivity to glucose, and increasing gastric emptying.
  • It has a risk of causing acute pancreatitis. Therefore, it should be avoided in this patient.

Option B: Repaglinide ​​​​​​​

  • Repaglinide increases the release of insulin.
  • It also causes weight gain.
  • Therefore, it is contraindicated in already obese patients. 

Option D: Liraglutide

  • Liraglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 agonist.
  • It stimulates the glucose-dependent release of insulin.
  • It is given in Injection Form, so avoided.
  • Also, it increases the risk of pancreatitis.

questions.text: A CKD patient has to undergo dialysis. His Hb is 5.2gm%, so two blood transfusions are to be given. The first bag gets completed in 2 hours. Second is started, and midway he develops shortness of breath and hypertension. His blood pressure is 180/120 mmHg, and his pulse rate is 110 beats/min. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
Option B: Transfusion-related circulatory overload (TACO)

  • A typical transfusion reaction known as a transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) occurs when pulmonary oedema develops predominantly as a result of circulatory overload or volume excess following a blood transfusion. Patients who receive a significant volume of a transfused substance over a short period of time are most likely to get TACO. This is especially true for patients who already have an underlying cardiovascular or renal illness.
  • This patient with chronic kidney disease has acquired severe anaemia, which is a symptom of compensated heart failure.
  • The first unit of blood was administered to the patient two hours earlier than the recommended four hours, despite the fact that he was already in compensated heart failure.
  • Because of the abrupt decompensation brought on by volume overloading, the patient will develop pulmonary oedema and experience difficulty breathing as a result of what has happened. This condition is referred to as circulatory overload linked with transfusion.
  • In order to prevent patients with CKD from developing severe anaemia, erythropoietin injections should ideally be administered to these individuals.

Option A: Allergic

  • Hypertension and shortness of breath are not due to allergic reactions.

Option C: TRALI

  • Hypertension and shortness of breath are not due to TRALI.

Option D: FNHTR

  • Hypertension and shortness of breath are not due to FNHTR.​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 58 year old male presented to opd with complaints of Headache, swelling on both ankles and difficulty in breathing. O/E - BP = 150/110 mm Hg, Pulse = 88 bpm, +ve Puddle sign, B/L mild basal crepts. Urine analysis reveals nephrotic range proteinuria. He is prone to develop all of the following complications except -
questions.solution:
Metabolic consequences of the nephrotic syndrome include the following:
  • Infection
  • Hyperlipidemia and atherosclerosis
  • Hypocalcemia and bone abnormalities
  • Hypercoagulability
  • Hypovolemia

questions.text: A 34 year female presents with complaints of difficulty in swallowing solid and liquid foods for past few months along with nausea and the symptoms have worsened for the past few weeks. Endoscopy was done. Identify the endoscopic finding shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Option B: Eosinophilic esophagitis

The endoscopic view shows corrugation or ring appearance, which suggests the diagnosis of eosinophilic esophagitis. To confirm the diagnosis of eosinophilic esophagitis

  1. Presence of 15 or more eosinophils per high power field (HPF) on oesophagal biopsy
  2. Exclusion of other disorders associated with similar clinical, histological, or endoscopic features, especially GERD.

Option A: Caustic burn

  • Caustic burn causes necrotic lesions.
  • The above picture shows the trachealization of the oesophagus, which is seen in eosinophilic esophagitis.

Option C: Pseudomembranous colitis

  • Pseudomembranous colitis affects the colon.
  • It causes the formation of pseudomembranes.
  • The above picture is of the oesophagus consistent with eosinophilic esophagitis.

Option D: Normal oesophagus

  • The oesophagus is about 8 inches long and is lined by moist pink tissue called the mucosa.
  • It does not contain rings.
  • The above picture is consistent with eosinophilic esophagitis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male complains of hot flushes each time he bathes. On investigation his Hb is 20 g/dL, Platelet: 1,89,000/μL, WBC: 30,000/μL, Investigation revealed JAK2 mutation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Polycythemia Vera

Polycythemia Vera:

  • It is the most common myeloproliferative disorder associated with JAK2 mutation.
  • It is characterized by increased white blood cells and basophils.  
  • Increased histamine release from basophils contributes to hot flushes or itching every time the patient takes a bath (aquagenic pruritis)
  • Serum erythropoietin level below normal.
  • The first investigation of choice is serum erythropoietin (JAK2 mutation is NOT specific, it can occur in Essential thrombocytosis )
  • Treatment is hydroxyurea which controls cell count.

other options

Option A: Progressive massive fibrosis

  • In progressive massive fibrosis, there is pancytopenia, whereas here Hb is 20 g/dL, Platelet: 1,89,000/μL, and WBC: 30,000/μL.

Option B: Chronic myeloid leukaemia

  • In CML, white blood cells are up to 100,000/uL.
  • CML is associated with BCR-ABL fusion, not JAK2 mutation.

Option D: Essential thrombocytosis

  • In Essential thrombocytosis, there is an increase in platelet count. 
  • It is associated with mild splenomegaly.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia & underwent allogenic stem cell transplantation a year ago. In her follow-up visit, she has manifestations of chronic graft-versus-host disease but otherwise is doing well & has no evidence of recurrence. Which of the following vaccines should not be administered to this patient at this point in time?
questions.solution:
Option C: Measles, mumps, and rubella

  • Patients who have undergone allogenic stem cell transplantation remain at risk for infectious complications
  • Graft versus host disease (GVHD) requires immunosuppression, increasing infectious risk.
  • Measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine is a live virus vaccine so avoided in transplantation patients with a history of GVHD
  • It can be safely given after 24 months if the patient does not have GVHD

Option A: Diphtheria-tetanus

  • The diphtheria-tetanus vaccine is administrated after one year of allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

Option B: 23-Valent pneumococcal polysaccharide

  • 23-Valent pneumococcal polysaccharide is administrated after one year of allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

Option D: Poliomyelitis via injection 

  • Poliomyelitis via injection is administrated after one year of allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to the Emergency department with seizures, which were common on her face, hands, and toes. She has a history of similar episodes at her residence. Subsequently, her (EEG) shows a spikes-sharp wave pattern. Which of the following would be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Focal Seizures

    • Focal seizures, also called partial seizures, result from a localized organic lesion or functional abnormality of brain tissue.
    • Clinically, manifestation reflects the function of the affected brain area.
    • Seizures can spread from focus to the contralateral cortex or subcortical areas.
    • They are classified as:
      • Simple partial (when there is no major change in consciousness).
      • Complex partial (when consciousness is impaired).
  • EEG in simple partial seizures shows:
    • Spikes or sharp waves unilaterally or bilaterally or a multifocal spike pattern.
  • EEG in complex partial seizure shows:The excitatory focus is usually around the Rolandic (motor) cortex.
    • Spikes or sharp waves in anterior temporal lobes.
  • The video below shows focal seizures.
    • They are more common on the face, hands, and toes because these areas have disproportionately large cortical representations.
    • The excitatory focus is usually around the Rolandic (motor) cortex.

Option B: Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizure

  • It is also called as grand mal
  • It diffusely affects the brain.
  • These seizures are characterized by the following
    • Alternating stiffening and movement
    • Postictal confusion
    • Urinary incontinence
    • Tongue biting

Option C: Absence Seizures

  • It is also called as petit mal
  • They are a type of generalized seizures which are characterized by 3Hz spike and wave discharges, short (usually 10 seconds) and frequent episodes of a blank stare.
  • No postictal confusion is present.

Option D: Myoclonic Jerks

  • It refers to brief, isolated, random, non-purposeful jerks of muscle groups in the limbs.
  • EEG shows fast spike-wave complexes of 2.5 Hz & a normal background.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with SLE presents to the emergency department with complaints of headache and fatigue. Her past manifestations of SLE have been arthralgias, hemolytic anemia, mouth ulcers, and malar rash, and she has high titers of antibodies to dsDNA. She currently is taking prednisone, 5 mg daily, and hydroxychloroquine, 200 mg daily. On examination, she is found to have a BP of 190/110 mmHg with an HR of 98 bpm. Urinalysis shows 25 RBCs per HPF with 2+ proteinuria. No RBC casts are identified. Her BUN is 90 mg/dL, and creatinine is 2.8 mg/dL (baseline 0.8 mg/dL). She has not previously had renal disease related to SLE and is not taking NSAIDs. She denies any recent illness, decreased oral intake, or diarrhea. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Initiate cyclophosphamide, 500 mg/m2 body surface area intravenously (IV), and plan to repeat monthly for 3–6 months
Initiate high-dose steroid therapy (IV methylprednisolone, 1000 mg daily for 3 doses, followed by oral prednisone, 1 mg/kg daily) and mycophenolate mofetil, 2 g daily

questions.solution:
Option C: Initiate high-dose steroid therapy (IV methylprednisolone, 1000 mg daily for 3 doses, followed by oral prednisone, 1 mg/kg daily) and mycophenolate mofetil, 2 g daily.

  • Urinalysis shows active nephritis with proteinuria and hematuria.
  • Even in the absence of red blood cell (RBC) casts, therapy should not be withheld to await biopsy results

Introduction:

  • Lupus nephritis is a kind of kidney disease caused by SLE.
  • Lupus Nephritis is the most common cause of death in patients with SLE.
  • Hence it should be managed as an emergency.

Cause:

  • Lupus nephritis occurs when lupus autoantibodies affect structures in your kidneys that filter out waste.

Clinical Features:

  • Typically, patients present with subacute disease and haematuria, hypertension, and variable renal impairment accompanied by heavy proteinuria that often reaches nephrotic levels. 

Histology:

  • In severely affected patients, the most common histological pattern is an inflammatory, diffusely proliferative glomerulonephritis with substantial deposits of immunoglobulins on immunofluorescence

Diagnosis:

  • Blood and urine tests
  • Kidney biopsy

Factors governing progression to lupus nephritis:

Increased Progression Decreased Progression
  1. Hypertension
  2. Proteinuria
  3. Increase ds-DNA titer
  4. Low C3 complement
  5. Thrombocytopenia
  1. Anti-RO antibody
  2. Anti-LA antibody

Treatment:

  • For severe lupus nephritis, medications that slow or stop>

Option A:

  • Cyclophosphamide is recommended in patients with Lupus Nephritis but alongside steroidal therapy.
  • It can also be used in combination with Mensa.
  • The drugs work by slowing or stopping the growth of malignant cells, such as WBCs, that attack your body during a lupus flare.

Option B:

  • Hemodialysis will be recommended if kidney failure is evident.
  • The patient will be presenting with deranged Urea and Creatinine. 
  • Both hemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis may obtain good results in lupus patients, although the risk of infection is more elevated in peritoneal dialysis.

Option D:

  • Plasmapheresis replaces that unhealthy plasma with healthy plasma
  • Plasmapheresis of a person with lupus containing immune complexes and autoantibodies that attack the body's healthy tissue will remove the complexes.
  • It will not be of benefit in an acute attack

questions.text: A 28-year-old male who had a history of throat infection a few weeks back is now presenting to the OPD with fever, headache, and unilateral swelling of the parotid gland. On examination, there are vesicles on the tympanic membrane and lymphadenopathy. He is also complaining of multiple joint pain and cough with very low sputum expectoration. What is the next best test for the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: PCR of respiratory secretions

  • The Given clinical scenario is a case of Mycoplasma pneumonia.
  • It is the classic cause of atypical pneumonia, also called silent pneumonia.
  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a pleomorphic organism and lacks a cell wall.
  • It has a selective affinity for respiratory epithelial cells and damages the lining of the respiratory system.
  • Outbreaks are more common in military recruits, prisons, and colleges.
  • It is transmitted from person to person via respiratory droplets.
  • The patient's symptoms may include fever, malaise, persistent worsening cough that can last for weeks to months, indolent dull headache, chills, and pharyngitis.
  • Many extrapulmonary infections are attributed to mycoplasma pneumoniae infections, including immune thrombocytopenia purpura, acute hepatitis, acute hemolytic anemia, arthritis, and macular/vesicular rash.
  • Neurological and dermatological extrapulmonary manifestations are the most common.
  • Acute infection can be diagnosed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) detection of the organism in respiratory tract secretions.
  • Oropharyngeal, nasopharyngeal, and pulmonary specimens are acceptable for diagnosing M. pneumoniae pneumonia.
  • PCR allows rapid & specific diagnosis earlier in the course of clinical illness.

Option B: Gram stain of transtracheal aspirate

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae will not be visible on gram stain because it lacks a cell wall.

Option C: Culture of transtracheal aspirate

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae culture requiring special media is not recommended for routine diagnosis because the organism may take weeks to grow and is often difficult to isolate from clinical specimens.

Option D: Chest X-ray

  • Interstitial infiltrate will be present on chest x-ray.
  • The x-ray of this disease is worse than the presentation of the patient.
  • But these findings may resemble other pathologies.

questions.text: A 48-year-old obese male accompanied by his wife presents to the OPD with a history of loud, chronic snoring and gasping episodes during Sleep. He also complains of impaired concentration and memory, which interferes with his work. He always feels unrefreshed during his work. Which of the following tool is useful in assessing sleep apnea in such patients?
questions.solution:
Option C: Epworth scale

  • The Epworth sleepiness scale has been validated primarily in obstructive sleep apnea, though it has also shown success in detecting narcolepsy and idiopathic hypersomnia.
  • It is used to measure excessive daytime sleepiness and is repeated after the administration of treatment (e.g. CPAP) to document an improvement of symptoms.
  • The Epworth scale is a questionnaire that consists of 8 questions and is self-administered. On a scale ranging from 0 to 3, respondents are asked to rate how likely they are to nod off or fall asleep while participating in one of eight distinct activities.
  • The vast majority of individuals participate in such pursuits at least periodically, though not necessarily on a daily basis. The Epworth scale score, which is a total of eight item ratings ranging from 0 to 3, can range anywhere from 0 to 24.
  • The average sleep propensity in daily life (ASP), also known as a person's "daytime sleepiness," is positively correlated with their Epworth scale score.
  • The higher the score, the greater the ASP.
  • Responding to the questionnaire should take no more than two or three minutes of your time. 
  • It is obtainable in a great number of linguistic varieties.
  • In narcolepsy, the Epworth sleepiness scale has both a high specificity (100%) and sensitivity (93.5%).

Option A: Fisher grading scale

  • The Fisher scale is used to calculate the risk of cerebral arterial vasospasm.

Option B: Modified Rodnan score

  • The modified Rodnan score is used in systemic sclerosis to measure skin thickness.

Option D: Gleason score

  • Gleason score is used in prostate cancer screening.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presented to the emergency room with a complaint of sudden-onset pleuritic right-sided chest pain. Chest radiograph shows a mild, right-sided pleural effusion. Which of the pulmonary change won't you expect in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Increased vital capacity (VC)

  • Pleural effusion is a Restrictive lung disease of extrinsic cause.
  • Vital capacity is sum of expiratory reserve volume + tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume (ERV + TV + IRV). 
  • All these lung volumes are decreased in pleural effusion.
  • Therefore, vital capacity is decreased in patients with pleural effusion.

Option A: Increased FEV1/FVC

  • The FEV1/FVC ratio is also called timed vital capacity.
  • It is increased in restrictive lung diseases.

Option B: Decreased (TLC)

  • Total lung capacity is decreased in restrictive lung diseases.

Option C: Decreased residual volume (RV)

  • Residual volume is decreased in restrictive lung diseases.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with complaints of dyspnea and cough for 1 week. He also developed chest pain 5 days back. Doctor orders a chest X-ray (PA view) erect and supine position, which is given below. Based on the given X-ray, what is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hydro-pneumothorax

  • Above the erect chest, radiography shows an air-fluid level.
  • Furthermore, a sharp pleural line is surrounded by increased opacity in the pleural space on supine radiography.
  • When there is both air and fluid in the pleural area, it is known as hydropneumothorax.
  • On physical examination, the afflicted side exhibits diminished breath sounds and an audible succession splash, along with the symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath.
  • An upright or decubitus chest X-ray is used to diagnose the condition.
  • In order to notice an air-fluid level, which should be completely horizontal on an upright film, air must also be present in the pleural space and pleural fluid.
  • On plain film, simple fluid, blood, and pus all have the same density. Thus the nature of the fluid must be inferred from previous radiographic results or history.

Option B: Pleural effusion

  • The term "pleural effusion" is frequently used to refer to any abnormal fluid buildup in the pleural cavity.
  • The pleural effusion appears as a meniscus along the chest wall with obliteration of the hemidiaphragm on the chest X-ray, which is a distinctive feature. Because the trapped air causes an increase in intrathoracic pressure that obliterates the fluid interface, a meniscus is not visible in a hydropneumothorax.

Option C: Lung abscess

  • Circumscribed pus accumulation in the lungs is known as lung abscesses.
  • A cavity with a gas-fluid level is how a pulmonary abscess is typically seen.
  • Abscesses often have a rounded form and similarities in lateral and frontal projections. Additionally, while nearby consolidation may make it challenging to analyse, all margins are equally well observed.

Option D: Collapse

  • A complete lung lobe collapse is referred to as a lobar collapse.
  • To denote air space opacification, bending or displacing a fissure/s towards the collapsing lobe must result in a sizable volume loss.
  • The triangular or pyramidal collapsed lobe has an apex that faces the hilum.
  • The costal parietal pleura and the collapsed lung remain in peripheral contact, with the following exception:
  • When an RML collapses, the lobe collapses next to the mediastinum, pleural effusion, and pneumothorax.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with a productive cough and dyspnoea. The CT chest of the patient is given below. Which of the following findings is shown in the CT scan?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ground glass pattern

  • Ground-glass opacity (GGO) is a non-specific term defined the as the presence of a hazy increase in lung density on high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) that is not associated with obscuration of the underlying vessels or bronchial walls; if vessels are obscured, the term "consolidation" is preferred.
  • GGO is produced by filling the alveolar gaps (by cells or fluid) or the thickening of the alveolar walls or interstitium.
  • It represents the presence of various lung disorders, such as alveolar collapse, interstitial thickening, or air-space disease.
  • GGO is difficult to identify radiographically, especially in moderate instances, because the differential diagnosis of GGO mostly relies on HRCT.

Option B: Honeycomb pattern

  • The term "honeycomb lung" refers to the appearance of variously sized cysts on a backdrop of heavily scarred lung tissue.
  • Microscopically, there are increased air spaces surrounded by fibrosis and hyperplastic or bronchiolar-type epithelium.
  • These alterations, however, are generic and common in various end-stage interstitial lung illnesses (ILDs).
  • In Usual Interstitial Pneumonitis, a honeycomb pattern is seen on HRCT along with traction bronchiectasis and ground-glass opacities.

Option C: Crazy pavement pattern

  • In pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, the X-ray shows bilateral, diffuse opacities, and the high-resolution computerized tomography (HRCT) shows a crazy-paving pattern.
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) is caused by impaired surfactant clearance that leads to its accumulation in the alveoli.
  • It produces chunky, gelatinous sputum stains with periodic-acid Schiff (PAS) stains.
  • There is little or no lung inflammation, and the underlying lung architecture is preserved.

Option D: Normal Scan

  • It is not a normal CT scan as haziness in the lung fields can be observed instead of air which is usually black on CT.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman complains of calf pain and swelling in the leg for the last 2 days. She developed these symptoms after total knee implant surgery. Later she complains of breathlessness and dies suddenly in the ward. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pulmonary embolism

  • A postoperative acute pulmonary embolism is a complication that can arise as a result of surgical procedures. The likelihood of this complication resulting in death is extremely high.
  • A diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism should be made as quickly as possible and computed tomographic pulmonary angiography is the diagnostic procedure that is regarded as the gold standard for acute pulmonary embolism.
  • It is recommended that a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism be made as soon as possible.
  • Anticoagulants and thrombolytic therapy have both been shown to be quite effective in treating acute pulmonary embolisms in patients.
  • By administering subcutaneous fondaparinux, patients who have recently undergone total hip or knee replacement can avoid developing PE and DVT.
  • A patient with DVT will have a history of cramps in the lower calf that lasts for several days, becoming increasingly uncomfortable as time goes on, and is indicative of the condition.
  • Patients who have PE have the most prevalent history of dyspnea that cannot be explained.

Option B: Myocardial infarction

  • Myocardial infarction has no history of postoperative breathlessness and such presentation.

Option C: Stroke

  • Stroke has no history of postoperative breathlessness and such presentation.

Option D: ARDS

  • ARDS is being ruled out as the presentation is acute, with a decrease in PCWP <18mmHg with B/L pulmonary infiltration on CXR.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male comes to the emergency department with his wife with features of confusion, eye-movement disorder, and ataxia. The patient is a chronic alcoholic, hypertensive and non-diabetic. There is no history of accidents or falls. His blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, and his pulse is 60 beats/min. Initial investigations are made, and the patient is given IV thiamine as a part of his treatment plan. Which of the following would be the first symptom to respond to IV Thiamine in such patients?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ophthalmoplegia

  • The above clinical history and features suggest Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency.
  • Ophthalmoplegia is oculomotor dysfunction that occurs due to damage to the oculomotor nerve.
  • It includes nystagmus, lateral rectus palsy and diplopia.
  • These symptoms resolve immediately after an IV infusion of thiamine.

Other options

Option B: Sensory Ataxia

  • Sensory ataxia occurs due to the impairment of the somatosensory system.
  • There is a loss of sensory input to control the movements.
  • The coordination will be almost normal with open eyes, but there will be a marked decrease in coordination when eyes are closed; the Romberg sign is positive.
  • It mostly occurs due to the lesion of the dorsal columns.

Option C: Vestibular ataxia

  • In Wernicke’s encephalopathy, ataxia occurs due to the damage of the cerebral cortex and vestibule nuclei, known as Vestibular ataxia.
  • It takes time to resolve and sometimes can remain permanently.

Option D: Global confusion

  • Global confusion can occur in Wernicke’s encephalopathy, which responds to medication but takes time.
  • But still, after medication, memory and learning abnormalities exist.
  • Some patients develop Korsakoff Syndrome leading to amnesia and confabulation.

questions.text: A 40 -year-old woman has relapsing/remitting multiple sclerosis. She has previously experienced two attacks of disease that have left her with residual lower extremity weakness. She was initially treated with glucocorticoids, with some improvement in her symptoms. However, she can only walk with a rolling walker for about 100 m. An initial antibody test shows that she is negative for reactivity to the J.C. virus. You are planning to start a disease-modifying therapy. Which of the following drug causes a maximum reduction in the appearance of new lesions and change in disease severity?
questions.solution:
Option A: Natalizumab

Treatment of Multiple Sclerosis-

  • An acute attack of optic neuritis = IV methylprednisolone
  • Natalizumab:
    • Highly effective in reducing attack rate
    • S/E = J.C. virus (John Cunningham virus) activation leading to P.M.F. (Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy)- worsening of neurological features.
  • Ocrelizumab = acts by attacking mature B cells, which expresses CD 20. Is allowed for management of P.P.M.S
Drugs are given in MS:
HIGHLY EFFECTIVE Moderately effective
  • Natalizumab
  • Ocrelizumab
  • I.F.N. ß
  • Glatiramer
  • Fingolimod
  • Dimethyl Fumarate

Option B: Glatiramer

  • Glatiramer is used but is moderately effective for multiple sclerosis

Option C: Interferon beta la

  • Interferon beta 1a is used in the treatment  of multiple sclerosis but  is not as effective as natalizumab

Option D: Interferon beta lb

  • Interferon beta 1b is used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis but is not as effective  as natalizumab

questions.text: A twenty-five years old female presents to the emergency department with the complaint of severe abdominal pain. The pain is on the upper right side and is not associated with nausea or vomiting. Examination findings include jaundice, tender hepatosplenomegaly and mild ascites. She does not have a history of any illness or trauma. What is the probable diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Budd-Chiari Syndrome

  • Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is a very rare condition.
  • This is caused by the occlusion of the hepatic veins draining the liver. 
  • BCS classically presents as a triad of abdominal pain, ascites, and liver enlargement.
  • Primary Budd–Chiari syndrome (75%) is caused by hepatic vein thrombosis.
  • Causes of primary BCS include:
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Pregnancy
    • Postpartum state
    • Use of oral contraceptives
    • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
    • Hepatocellular carcinoma
    • Lupus anticoagulants
  • Secondary Budd–Chiari syndrome (25%) is due to compression of the hepatic vein by an outside structure.

Other options

Option B: Acute Viral Hepatitis

  • Acute viral hepatitis is characterized by fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain.
  • The patient's symptoms and history suggest a diagnosis of Budd-Chiari Syndrome.

Option C: Acute Pancreatitis

  • Acute pancreatitis is characterized by fever and epigastric pain radiating to the back.
  • The patient's symptoms and history suggest a diagnosis of Budd-Chiari Syndrome.

Option D: Acute Cholecystitis

  • Acute cholecystitis is characterized by fever, chills, and right-sided abdominal pain.
  • The patient's symptoms and history suggest a diagnosis of Budd-Chiari Syndrome.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient with a history of schizophrenia has been on a first-generation antipsychotic medication for the past few months. He presents to the clinic complaining of stiffness, tremors, and difficulty with movement. The symptoms started approximately two weeks after initiating the antipsychotic medication. On examination, the patient exhibits coarse tremors in both hands, rigidity in the limbs, and a shuffling gait. His facial expression appears mask-like. There is no evidence of resting tremors or pill-rolling movements. The patient denies any history of similar symptoms in the past or a family history of Parkinson's disease.

Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is C: Drug-induced Parkinsonism

 

Incorrect options:

Option A: Tardive Dyskinesia is characterized by abnormal involuntary movements, typically involving the face, lips, tongue, and extremities, and it usually occurs after prolonged use of antipsychotic medications.

Option B: Acute Dystonia presents with sudden muscle contractions, including oculogyric crisis, torticollis, and trismus.

Option D: Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome presents with severe muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, autonomic instability, and altered mental status, and it is a potentially life-threatening condition.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female without known significant past medical history had, for the past year, persistent psychiatric illness, facial puffiness, and a Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) score of 40 on admission. Her thyroid profile was: Thyroid stimulating hormone – 65.71 mIU/L, Free tri-iodo threonine (FT3) – 2.2 pg/ml, free tetra iodo thyronine (FT4) – 0.5 ng/ml with normal ultrasound-thyroid. The patient was started on thyroxin 100 μg with a low dose of risperidone 2 mg. Risperidone was withdrawn over a week, and the patient was discharged on thyroxine alone with a BPRS score of 8. What does her psychiatric illness include?
questions.solution:
Option A: Auditory hallucinations and paranoia

  • It is a true statement.
  • Hypothyroidism is a widespread condition where the thyroid doesn't establish and discharge enough thyroid hormone into your bloodstream.
  • Hashimoto's disease, an autoimmune disorder, is the vastly common reason for hypothyroidism. With this disorder, your immune system assaults the thyroid. The thyroid becomes swollen and can't make sufficient thyroid hormones.
  • There is a generalized slowing of metabolic cycles. This can lead to abnormalities such as exhaustion, slow action and hindered speech, cold intolerance, constipation, weight gain (but not morbid obesity), halted relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, and bradycardia.
  • Effects of hypothyroidism on the Brain include myxedematous madness, depressed mood, sympathy, and impaired memory.
  • Myxedematous madness has been described in a small number of patients with hypothyroidism.
  • The characteristic symptoms include auditory hallucinations and paranoia (persecutory ideas).
  • Thyroid hormones are important for normal brain development. They influence neurogenesis, neuronal and glial cell differentiation and migration, synaptogenesis, and myelination.
  • Imaging shows that brain structure and function are modified in hypothyroid patients, with decreased hippocampal volume, cerebral blood flow, global processes, regions mediating scrutiny, visuospatial processing, helping memory, and motor speed.
  • Ultrasound is usually the first choice for diagnosis. MRI can give very comprehensive images.
  • Treatment of patients with brain fog includes a supportive doctor-patient relationship. In expansion, lifestyle changes like further rest and exercise can assist.

Option B: Visual hallucinations and depression

  • It is a false statement.
  • Her illness does not have any signs of visual hallucinations.

Option C: Auditory hallucinations and depression

  • It is a false statement.
  • Hypothyroidism affecting the Brain can cause paranoia but not depression.

Option D: Auditory hallucinations and depression

  • It is a false statement.
  • Hypothyroidism's effects on the Brain do not include depression.

questions.text: A 25-year-old married woman was sent to OPD after experiencing sleepwalking episodes two to three times every night since infancy. The majority of the time, the patient would jump out of bed and cry "Help!" or "I'm going to die!" Occasionally, the patient would tumble off the bed, striking her head or limbs. The patient's husband described these experiences. Which age group is most likely to experience somnambulism?
questions.solution:
Somnambulism

  • Sleep walking, seen in stage 4 and 3 of NREM sleep.
  • It is mostly seen in children and is mostly prevalent in ages 4 to 8 years.

HOW TO REMEMBER : Most parasomnias occur in stage 3+4. Most of them occur during 4-8 years of age.

questions.text: The senior resident reprimands an intern posted in the medicine ward as he had forgotten to send a patient's blood samples in the morning. Sometime later, the same intern is heard shouting at the family member of a patient, who has come to inform him that the normal saline drip given to his patient needs to be changed. What defines the mechanism the intern is using here?
questions.solution:
Option A: Displacement

  • The intern is displacing the anger of the senior resident towards the patient's family member.
  • This is a classic example of Displacement.
  • It is the process by which interest and/or emotion is shifted from one object onto another less-threatening one so that the latter replaces the former.

Option B: Projection

  • Transfer of feelings about a person onto that person.

Option C: Intellectualization

  • Excessive use of intellect to avoid painful emotions

Option D: Reaction formation

  • Transforming an impulse into its exact opposite behavior

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents at the emergency department with a family member who is unconscious after hitting his head on the floor. He is a truck driver and mostly eats processed meat with low fiber, his occult blood test is positive; he has lost 3.5 kg (7 pounds) in the past two months. His mother died of endometrial cancer at age 59, and his elder brother died of colorectal cancer. He is admitted to the hospital, and a blood test reveals a very low Hb of 3.5 g/dl. Genetic testing reveals microsatellite instability. What is the most common site of single-strand mutation present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Mismatch repair

  • This is a case of lynch syndrome, genetic testing reveals a defective mutation in mismatch repair proteins.
  • Mismatch repair proteins do DNA repair jobs where mismatched nucleotides in the newly synthesized strands are removed, making a gap filled and resealed with correct nucleotides, most commonly in the S phase of the cell cycle.
  • These mismatch repair proteins are defective in lynch syndrome, preciously hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer.

Option A: Nonhomologous End joining repair

  •  Nonhomologous end joining repair is a double-stranded DNA repair mechanism that brings together two ends of DNA fragments to repair double-stranded breaks.
  • This double-stranded repair mechanism is defective in ataxia-telangiectasia, which presents with Ataxia-telangiectasia, and IgA deficiency. These patients are sensitive to radiation exposure.

Option C: Base excision repair

  • Base excision repair is single-stranded DNA repair in which a specific defective base is removed by Glycosylase, which creates an AP site, and one or more nucleotides are removed by AP-Endonuclease, which cleaves 5 ′ ends. Ap-Lyase cleaves 3′ ends. Polymerase beta then fills the gap. And DNA ligase then reseals it.
  • Base excision repair is important for spontaneous deamination.

Option D: Nucleotide excision repair

  • The nucleotide excision repair mechanism is a single-stranded DNA repair mechanism.
  • Endonucleases release defective bases, and DNA polymerase and ligase fill and seal the gap.
  • Defective in xeroderma pigmentosum presents photosensitivity, skin rashes and skin cancer.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presented with painless swelling in the right testis for 4 months. Clinical examination revealed an enlarged, firm to hard right testis. Blood tests showed normal ranges of serum tumor markers. Ultrasonography and CT scan revealed a tumor in the right testis with multiple cystic areas and an ill-defined mass. A right-sided orchidectomy was performed. Histopathological examination revealed thickened tubule walls filled with small and intermediate-sized cells. The stroma in between the tubules contained numerous dilated blood vessels and edematous stroma. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Intratubular germ cell neoplasia

Intratubular germ cell neoplasia (ITGCN)

  • In the above-given case, the sign and symptoms of painless swelling of the right testes, bulky right testis measuring 5.8 cm × 4.7 cm × 5.0 cm, thickened tubular walls and stroma are suggestive of the diagnosis of Intratubular germ cell neoplasia.
  • With the exception of spermatocytic tumors, postpubertal invasive germ cell tumors arise from a precursor lesion known as intratubular germ cell neoplasia (ITGCN) or germ cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS).
  • Exceptions to this are prepubertal germ cell tumors (which can rarely occur after puberty), ovarian cystic teratomas, dermoid cysts and spermatocytic tumors (previously referred to as spermatocytic seminomas).
  • GCNIS consists of undifferentiated germ cells that have the appearance of seminoma that are located basally within the seminiferous tubules. The tubules usually show decreased or absent spermatogenesis and normal constituents are replaced by GCNIS.
  • GCNIS is diagnosed by a testicular biopsy that is performed for the investigation of infertility, contralateral testis biopsy in a patient with germ cell tumor or within the affected testis in a patient undergoing testis-sparing surgery.
  • GCNIS is associated with a 50% risk of developing an invasive germ cell tumor within 5 years. Radical orchiectomy or low dose (> 20 Gy) radiation therapy is an effective treatment option for GCNIS, of which radical orchiectomy is the most definitive therapy.
  • Patients with GCNIS show reduction (but do not eliminate) in the risk of developing germ cell tumors on receiving cisplatin-based chemotherapy.

Option A: Seminoma

  • Most seminomas do not produce tumor markers, but the presence of syncytiotrophoblastic giant cells in a minority of cases accounts for modest elevations of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).
  • Seminomas never produce alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).
  • Immunohistochemistry is usually positive for placental alkaline phosphates (PLAP); negative for CD30, AFP and epithelial membrane antigen (EMA).

Option B: Testicular teratoma

  • Teratomas contain more than one cell type with components derived from ectoderm, endoderm and mesoderm.
  • It is present with painless swelling of the testes.

Option D: CA Scrotum

  • It is a squamous cell carcinoma that may present as an ulcer with an everted edge.
  • The growth starts as a wart or ulcer, and as it grows, it may involve the testis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the hospital after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. He was an unrestrained passenger in a vehicle that was hit when another vehicle ran a red light. He is unconscious and was intubated on the scene. He presents to the hospital with a pulse of 120/min and a blood pressure of 85/40 mm Hg. Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) is positive for blood within the peritoneum. He is rushed to the operating room for an exploratory laparotomy. Prior to the procedure, the anesthesiologist places a central venous catheter to assist with rapid fluid and blood product administration. Which of the following is the best technique to place a subclavian central venous catheter?

choices.text: Insert the needle lateral to the carotid artery pulsation, pointing the needle towards the contralateral nipple
Insert the needle inferior to the midpoint of the clavicle, pointing the needle laterally
Insert the needle inferior to the midpoint of the clavicle, pointing the needle medially
Insert the needle medial to the sternocleidomastoid, pointing the needle laterally

questions.solution:
Flail chest – 2 or more consecutive ribs at 2 or more than 2 places

Treatment –

  • Oxygen inhalation
  • Adequate analgesia
  • Physiotherapy

If flail chest + respiratory failure: IPPV

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient with breast cancer underwent breast conservation surgery and chemotherapy for a 1.5 × 1.2 cm estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) breast cancer with one positive axillary lymph node. She is now on the chemotherapy drug Tamoxifen. What is the best recommended follow-up for this patient?

choices.text: Routine clinical examination 3 monthly in 1st year with an annual mammogram
Routine clinical examination of 3 monthly and 6 monthly liver function tests

questions.solution:
Option C: Routine clinical examination 3 monthly in 1st year with an annual mammogram

  • In the past, patients with breast cancer were advised to follow up with no standardized interval for life to detect recurrence and dissemination.
  • This led to an overburden of hospital services and cost of care to patients with no added benefit
  • Therefore, it was necessary to make a standardized follow-up routine to maximize the benefit to patients while at the same time reducing the cost of care. Therefore, a standardized follow-up protocol was formulated.
  • Arranging annual or two–yearly mammography of the treated and contralateral breast was recommended.
  • Currently, no routine repeated tests of tumour markers or imaging other than mammography are recommended for surveillance of treated breast cancer under remission, as it has not been shown to improve life expectancy or lead to early diagnosis of cancer recurrence in patients.

 

Option A: Annual bone scan

  • An annual bone scan is not recommended for routine surveillance for breast cancer recurrence.

Option B: Assessment of tumor markers 6 monthly

  • Six monthly assessments of tumor markers have no proven benefit in leading to early diagnosis of recurrence.
  • Regular assessment of tumor markers is used as a screening tool in postmenopausal ovarian cancer patients and also for prostate cancer patients

Option D: Routine clinical examination of 3 monthly and 6 monthly liver function tests 

  • Routine LFTs have no role in the surveillance of breast cancer recurrence.

questions.text: A 13-year-old male presents to the surgery OPD with complaints of soft swelling in front of his neck associated with difficulty swallowing for the last 5 months. He also reports pain in the skin around the swelling. His neck examination reveals a soft midline swelling in front of the neck, which moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following statements is true about the given condition?

choices.text: The most common location is sub-hyoid
Follicular carcinoma is seen in 1% of patients

questions.solution:
Option A: The most common location is subhyoid

  • In the case discussed above, the patient's clinical features of soft midline swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue suggest a thyroglossal cyst. Its most common location is the subhyoid region.
  • The image given in the question above shows a thyroglossal cyst.
  • It is a congenital cystic remnant of the thyroglossal duct.
  • Most commonly found in the subhyoid region, always close to the midline. Mostly asymptomatic unless infected.
  • It is congenital, but the usual presentation age is 15 to 30.
  • There is an increased risk of malignancy (1%), usually papillary carcinoma (85%). Squamous cells, Hurthle cells, and anaplastic cancers have also been reported.
  • The cyst moves with deglutition, and it is the only swelling that moves up on tongue protrusion.
  • The treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst is surgical removal.
  • Infected thyroglossal duct cysts require immediate antibiotic treatment before surgery.

Option B: Occurs due to Trauma

  • A thyroglossal cyst is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.
  • It is the most commonly encountered congenital cervical anomaly.

Option C: Follicular carcinoma is seen in 1% of patients

  • Follicular cancer is frequently present in the goitrous thyroid.
  • Papillary carcinoma is seen in 1% of patients with thyroglossal cysts.

Option D: Treated by Total Thyroidectomy

  • Total thyroidectomy (thyroid gland removal) is indicated in thyroid cancer, toxic multinodular goitre, toxic adenomas, goitre with compressive symptoms, and Graves’ disease.
  • Treatment of Thyroglossal cyst is done by Sistrunk operation:
    •  En bloc excision of the central part of the hyoid bone along with the cyst to minimize recurrence.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of hematemesis and melena. He has been suffering from abdominal discomfort and vomiting for many months. His blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, and his pulse is 60/min. On physical examination, he is pale and thin. There are also swollen lymph nodes in the left supraclavicular region. On further evaluation with endoscopy and imaging modalities, the patient is diagnosed with a case of locally advanced gastric carcinoma. Which of the following is an investigation of choice to know the depth of cancer?
questions.solution:
Option D: EUS

  • EUS (endoscopic ultrasound) is a minimally invasive procedure to assess the digestive tract and nearby organs.
  • It uses a thin, flexible tube inserted into the gastrointestinal tract and a device that uses sound waves to create images.
  • This endoscopic tube also has a small needle to remove fluid or tissue samples for biopsy.
  • The best way to stage the tumour locally is via EUS, which gives fairly accurate (80%) information about the depth of tumour penetration into the gastric wall and can show enlarged (>5mm) perigastric and celiac lymph nodes.

Option A: CECT

  • CECT is Contrast-enhanced Computed tomography.
  • It is used for imaging the different structures, and the contrast helps to improve the visualisation.
  • In this procedure, a beam of x-ray moves all around the body and different images are taken to form a dimensional image.
  • During surgeries, it is used to place a needle at a specific point for biopsies or aspiration.
  • It helps to visualise the tumours or other diseases before or after treatment.

Option B: MRI

  • MRI (magnetic resonance) is an imaging test that uses powerful magnets and radio waves.
  • These waves create images of the inside of the abdomen and do not use radiation.
  • Single MRI images are called slices stored on a computer and viewed on a monitor.
  • MRI is mainly used for brain and spinal cord injuries (stroke, tumour, aneurysms)
  • MRI of the abdomen is mainly used for the following:
  • Blood flow in the abdomen
  • Blood vessels in the abdomen
  • Lymph nodes
  • Masses in the liver, kidney, pancreas, and spleen.

Option C: Barium

  • Different types of barium x-ray examinations are used to determine different parts.
  • A barium swallow is used to study the pharynx and esophagus.
  • A mixture of barium is swallowed in the supine position, and images are taken.
  • A barium meal is used to study the lower esophagus and stomach.
  • Barium follow-through is used to study the small intestine.
  • A barium enema is used to study the large intestine and rectum.
  • It is used for the following purposes:
  • Diagnosis of tumour
  • Location of tumour
  • Ulceration
  • Strictures

questions.text: Which of the following is the first symptom manifesting in acute small intestinal obstruction?
questions.solution:
Option B: Colicky pain

  • Colicky pain is often the first symptom of low small bowel obstruction.
  • Pain:
    • Pain is the first symptom encountered; it occurs suddenly and is usually severe
    • It is colicky and is usually centered on the umbilicus (small bowel) or lower abdomen (large bowel)
    • The pain coincides with increased peristaltic activity
    • The development of severe pain is indicative of the presence of strangulation
    • Pain may not be a significant feature in postoperative simple mechanical obstruction and does not usually occur in paralytic ileus

Option A: Constipation

  • Absolute constipation is a cardinal feature of complete intestinal obstruction.
  • However, this is a relatively late manifestation of the disease.

Option C: Vomiting

  • The more distal the obstruction, the longer the interval between the onset of symptoms and the appearance of nausea and vomiting
  • As obstruction progresses, the character of the vomitus alters from digested food to feculent material
  • It is not an early symptom.

Option D: Distension

  • In the small bowel, the degree of distension is dependent on the site of the obstruction and is greater the more distal the lesion
  • Distension is a late feature in colonic obstruction and may be minimal or absent in the presence of mesenteric vascular occlusion

questions.text: A 20-year-old male has an injury to the hilum of the spleen, with devascularization of the spleen noted. The patient underwent an emergency splenectomy. Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomy of the specimen?

choices.text: The spleen lies in front of the left 9th, 10th, and 11th ribs
The splenic artery arises from the SMA
The inferior mesenteric vein empties into the right gastric vein
The tail of the pancreas lies in the gastrosplenic ligament

questions.solution:
Option A: The spleen lies in front of the left  9th, 10th, and 11th ribs

  • Splenic trauma is one of the most common indications of emergency splenectomy.
  • The weight of a normal adult spleen is 75-250 g and measures 7 to 11cm in length.
  • It lies in the left hypochondrium, with its long axis along the 10th rib.
  • The spleen lies in front of the left 9th, 10th, and 11th ribs. Therefore, the splenic injury should be suspected in a fracture of these ribs.
  • It is suspended by the following peritoneal reflections and ligaments: splenocolic ligament and gastrosplenic ligament.
  • It lies between the fundus of the stomach and the diaphragm

Option B: The splenic artery arises from the SMA

  • The tortuous splenic artery arises from the coeliac axis and runs along the upper border of the pancreas body and tail, giving it small branches.
  • The main splenic artery divides into superior and inferior branches into segmental branches.

Option C: The inferior mesenteric vein empties into the portal vein

  • The splenic vein is formed from several tributaries that drain the hilum
  • The vein runs behind the pancreas, receiving small tributaries from it before joining the superior mesenteric veins at the neck of the pancreas to form the portal vein
  • The inferior mesenteric vein drains into the splenic vein

Option D: The tail of the pancreas lies in the gastrosplenic ligament

  • The hilum sits at the angle between the stomach and kidney and is in contact with the tail of the pancreas, which lies in the lienorenal ligament
  • The inner (visceral) surface of the spleen has gastric, colic, renal, and pancreatic impressions

questions.text: In the case of acute appendicitis, pain is illustrated in the right hip on the extension of the right thigh. What is the term used to refer to this examination finding?
questions.solution:
Option C: Psoas sign

  • Psoas sign: this sign is present when an inflamed appendix lies over the psoas muscle.
    • Flexing the right hip with stretched leg against resistance produces pain in the right iliac fossa
    • Passive extension of the right hip when the patient is positioned on the left side produces pain in the right iliac fossa.
    • As a result, the patient will lie with the right hip flexed for pain relief
    • This sign is positive in the inflamed retrocecal appendix.
    • Inflammation in this area irritates the iliopsoas muscle, thereby producing spasms.

Option A: Dunphy’s sign

  • In appendicitis, any abdominal wall movement may elicit right lower abdominal pain.
  • Increased right iliac fossa pain with coughing is called Dunphy’s sign.
  • This happens because a cough jostles the inflamed peritoneum.

Option B: Obturator sign

  • The Obturator sign is positive when the internal rotation of the right hip with a flexed knee and hip produces right lower quadrant pain.
  • It is present when the inflamed appendix is in contact with the obturator internus muscle.
  • The given clinical finding is not consistent with the obturator sign

Option D: Rovsing’s sign

  • Rovsing’s sign is the pain in the right iliac fossa that elicits deep palpation of the left iliac fossa.
  • This is a referred pain due to inflamed peritoneum

questions.text: A 44-year-old female patient presents a progressive bloating sensation in the abdomen. She has a family history of tuberous sclerosis. Ultrasound reveals a 10cm hyperechoic mass in the left abdominal area, originating from the left kidney. CT examination reveals a mass with mixed density. Immunohistochemistry is done after a mass biopsy, which is positive for HMB-45. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Angiomyolipoma

  • Clinical sign: Progressive bloating sensation in the abdomen, family history of tuberous sclerosis running, hyperechoic mass with mixed density, and positive for HMB-45, indicating the diagnosis of angiomyolipoma.
  • Angiomyolipoma
  • Angiomyolipoma is a benign disorder composed of matured blood vessels, muscles, and fat.
  • More common in females and is associated with tuberous sclerosis.
  • Has positive immunoreactivity for HMB-45.
  • The presence of microaneurysm (detected on angiography) increased the risk of retroperitoneal bleeding in 10 % of patients, known as Wunderlich syndrome.
  • Any mass in the kidney rules out renal cell carcinoma using CECT.
  • The investigation of choice of most of the renal group is CECT except for Wilms tumour, where MRI is used.
  • CT findings
