  • The presence of fat and absence of calcification is highly suggestive of angiomyolipoma (In RCC → presence of calcification; this feature is used to differentiate between RCC & Angiomyolipoma).
  • Asymptomatic tumours up to 4cm in size are kept under observation.​​​​​​​

Option A: Secondary to malignant melanoma

  • The kidney is a common location for micrometastases in patients with malignant melanomas.
  • These lesions are usually small, multiple, asymptomatic, and bilateral and associated with a known primary lesion.
  • Not associated with tuberous sclerosis and is not immunoreactivity for HMB-45.

Option B: Renal cell carcinoma

  • Five Histological subtypes are Clear cell carcinoma, Papillary carcinoma, Chromophobe type, Bellini Duct tumour, and Medullary carcinoma. Male: Female–2:1 .Risk factors are age, sex, hypertension, obesity, and tobacco smoking.
  • Clinical presentation includes loin pain, loin mass, and hematuria (the most common presentation). The most common route of spread-hematogenous.

Option D: Carcinoma of the renal pelvis

  • Cancer of the renal pelvis starts in the cells of the renal pelvis. It is a Urothelial carcinoma(also called transitional cell carcinoma).
  • Not associated with tuberous sclerosis and is not immunoreactivity for HMB-45.

questions.text: A 38-year old female presents with a picture of rectal bleeding, elimination of purulent drainage associated with a perianal tumor, pain, and weight loss. On physical examination, a large ulcerated, hard and brittle lesion was noted, which extended up to 2 cm from the anal margin, occupying the entire right Hemi-circumference, with the presence of pus, blood, and cellulitis in the gluteal region. The patient was hospitalized and underwent the endovaginal USG, which revealed a bulky mass to the right of the anal canal measuring 4.1 cm×2.4 cm with no signs of an abscess. What is the feature of this tumor?
questions.solution:
Option B: Malignant transformation in anogenital wart

Buschke - Lowenstein tumor (verrucous carcinoma):

  • In the above-given case, the presence of rectal bleeding, elimination of purulent drainage, large ulcerated, hard and brittle lesion, and bulky mass is suggestive of the diagnosis of Buschke - Lowenstein tumor (verrucous carcinoma).
  • Tumors destroy adjacent tissue by compression.
  • No metastasis usually (Locally malignant).
  • Verrucous carcinoma is a locally aggressive form of condyloma acuminata.
  • The treatment of choice is the wide local excision.
  • Topical immunomodulators- Imiquimod (Aldara) can be given.
  • Very large lesions may respond to external beam radiation, but resection is almost always required.

Option A: Malignant transformation in plantar wart

  • Buschke - Lowenstein tumor is a malignant transformation in the anogenital wart.
  • It is not a malignant transformation in a planter wart.

Option C: Malignant transformation in common wart

  • The malignant transformation in common warts is not the feature of Buschke - Lowenstein tumor.
  • A biopsy can be done to evaluate the malignancy of warts.

Option D: Malignant transformation in seborrheic wart

  • Seborrheic wart can be caused by seborrheic keratosis.
  • Seborrheic keratosis is benign skin growth.

questions.text: A 9-year-old female patient was brought to the clinic because of skin color changes from white to blue to red in symmetrically in bilateral hands and feet with six months of progress. Symptoms occur once or twice a week, sometimes fortnightly, and are triggered by cold. They usually last from 10 to 15 min with spontaneous resolution. What would be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Raynaud’s disease

  • Episodic vasospasm of extremities and triphasic color response makes Raynaud's disease the best probable diagnosis.
  • It is a medium-sized vessel vasculitis affecting digital vessels in fingers and toes.
  • It is caused by episodic vasospasm triggered by cold or stress.
  • It affects young women below the age of 30.
  • It has a classic clinical presentation of triphasic color response.
  • The triphasic color response includes three stages
    • Blanching (stage of local syncope):   
      • With exposure to cold, digital arterioles go into spasm.
      • Decreased flow is evidenced by pallor, or blanching digits may appear white.
    • Cyanosis (stage of local asphyxia)    
      • Capillaries and venules dilate, and digits appear blue.
    • Red Engorgement (stage of recovery)          
      • With rewarming or passing of attack, the digital vasospasm resolves.
      • Blood flow into dilated arteries and capillaries increases dramatically.
      • Reactive hyperemia imparts bright red color to the digits.

Option B: Acrocyanosis

  • It refers to peripheral arterial disease caused by vasospasm of small blood vessels.
  • It presents as painless, non-episodic skin color changes in fingers or toes.
  • Digits show bluish discoloration and may appear as mottled cyanosed fingers or toes.
  • It is also triggered by cold or stress.

Option C: Arteriovenous Fistula

  • It refers to abnormal communication between an artery and a vein.
  • The vein becomes tortuous, dilated, and thick-walled.
  • It can cause high-output cardiac failure.
  • It will present as pulsatile swelling in the superficial lesion and may give machinery murmur on palpation.

Option D: Subclavian Seal Syndrome

  • It refers to the subclavian artery stenosis proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery leads to hypoperfusion distal to the stenosis.
  • Clinical presentation: Arm ischemia, pain, paresthesia, vertebrobasilar insufficiency (dizziness, vertigo).
  • Associated with arteriosclerosis, Takayasu's arteritis, and heart surgery.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the surgical outpatient department with complaints of palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities from the last 1 month. She underwent a near-total thyroidectomy for diffuse toxic goiter in the past and remained well for a year until similar symptoms started again. Her recent thyroid function tests are consistent with hyperthyroidism. What would be the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Radioiodine

  • The thyrotoxicosis recurrence following a subtotal thyroidectomy may occur due to persistent and latent disease. In addition, Graves’ disease may recur due to thyroid tissue present in aberrant and ectopic sites, including the thyroglossal duct remnants, anterior neck, mediastinum, and lateral neck.
  • Indications of Radioactive iodine include:
    • Individuals who have relapsed after medical or surgical treatment.
    • Individuals in whom surgery of anti-thyroid drugs is contraindicated.
    • Elderly patients with small or medium-sized goitre.
    • Radioactive iodine results in an acute decline of thyroid hormone release and inhibit further synthesis. It inhibits the organification of iodine in the thyroid gland, inhibiting hormone biosynthesis. This phenomenon is called the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.
    • Radioactive iodine therapy is the best line of management in this case.

Option A: Further surgery

  • A redo thyroidectomy may result in injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
  • In a patient with recurrent thyrotoxicosis after thyroid surgery, nerve injury occurs due to fibrosis and loss of tissue planes.
  • Therefore, doing a repeat surgery will not be an appropriate next step in this case.

Option B: Radioiodine followed by surgery

  • Although radioiodine is the best treatment for this patient, doing a follow-up surgery is not the right plan.
  • A repeat surgery will result in injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve
  • Nerve injury occurs due to fibrosis and loss of tissue planes.

Option D: Observation and follow-up

  • It is not a good strategy not to do anything when the patient is symptomatic.
  • Observation and follow-up will result in the worsening of symptoms and patients.
  • The patient should be managed immediately and put on a treatment plan.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents with a cystic lesion in the distal body of the pancreas. On abdominal examination, no mass is palpable. Serological examination revealed serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) to be 2.5 ng/dL, and serum carbohydrate antigen (CA) 19.9 to be 6.7 IU/dL. Triphasic CT abdomen shows a 4.5 × 3.2 cm cystic lesion in the body of the pancreas with calcifications. The diagnosis of a mucinous cystic neoplasm is made, and the patient is admitted for laparoscopic distal pancreatectomy. Which of the following is not an advantage of advising this patient a minimal access surgery?
questions.solution:
↑ heat loss is not an advantage of minimal access surgery.

Minimal access surgery:

Minimal access surgery is performed with one or more small incisions instead of a large incision in regular surgeries. Laparoscopic surgery is a minimal access surgery that is performed through small incisions. A telescope with a video camera inserted through one incision into the abdominal cavity provides visualization of the operation on a TV monitor. Surgical instruments are then passed through additional small incisions, and the entire operation takes place completely within the patient's body in this procedure. When the telescope is used to operate on the abdomen, then the procedure is called laparoscopy. When it is used in the chest, then the procedure is called thoracoscopy.

Advantages of minimal access surgery
  • Decrease in wound size
  • Reduction in bleeding, wound infection, dehiscence, herniation & nerve entrapment
  • Decrease in wound pain
  • Improved mobility
  • Decreased wound trauma
  • Decreased heat loss
  • Improved vision
  • Faster recovery & shorter hospital stay

↑ heat loss is not an advantage of minimal access surgery. Instead decreased heat loss is an advantage.

Learning objective:

In minimally access surgery, a variety of techniques have been used to operate with less damage to the body than with open surgery. In general, minimally invasive surgery is associated with less pain, a shorter hospital stay, faster recovery, and fewer complications. Laparoscopy surgery is performed through one or more small incisions, using small telescopes and tiny cameras, and surgical instruments. It was one of the first types of minimally invasive surgery. Decreased heat loss is an advantage of this minimal access surgery.

questions.text: A 29-year-old blind patient presents to the emergency department after sustaining a fall from a height of 5 m over a standing barrier in a stadium during a cricket match. The pulse is 104/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 38/min, and the GCS is 3/15. On systemic examination, diminished breath sounds are noted on the right side. Which of the following ratios of RBCs, fresh frozen plasma, and platelets should be given to this patient for transfusion?
questions.solution:
Option B: 1:1:1

  • In a trauma-related transfusion, the ratio of RBCs, FFP, and platelets should be 1:1:1.
  • Because most patients do not require more than 6 units of PRBCs, most do not receive FFP.
  • For patients who require more PRBCs, 7 to 12 units of PRBCs should be delivered along with 6 units of FFP and 1 unit of apheresis platelets.
  • Preferably, the FFP and platelets should be transfused before the next 6 units of PRBCs are transfused.

Option A: 1:1:3

  • The ratio of RBCs, FFP, and platelets should be 1:1:1 for transfusion in trauma-related patients.

Option C: 1:1:2

  • RBCs, FFP, and platelets should be transfused in a ratio of 1:1:1 in trauma-related patients, not 1:1:2.

Option D: 1:1:4

  • A 1:1:1 ratio of RBCs, FFP, and platelets are to be followed while administering transfusions in a trauma-related patient.

questions.text: A 2-hour-old boy is evaluated in neonatal intensive care for a large-sized mass present at the sacrococcygeal region of the newborn. The infant is born to a 27-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks gestation by cesarean section. The mother did not seek prenatal medical care. On examination, his temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 90/70 mmHg, heart rate is 118/min, and respiratory rate is 24/min. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Examination reveals a large-sized solid mass at the sacrococcygeal with flaccid lower extremities. A CT scan reveals a sacrococcygeal mass with a suggestion for the intraspinal extension to level L1. Subsequent MRI confirms this finding with extension to the upper lumbar spine with mass effect on ureters. The condition of the newborn is shown below in the image. Which of the following is true regarding the condition of this newborn?
questions.solution:
Option B: Primitive streak remnants

The condition shown in the above image is a sacrococcygeal teratoma. It originates from the primitive streak remnants.

Sacrococcygeal teratoma:

  • Sacrococcygeal teratoma usually presents as a large mass extending from the sacrum and coccyx in the newborn. They are believed to originate from the pluripotent cells in the Hensen node of the primitive streak.
  • Sacrococcygeal teratomas are rare tumours that develop at the base of the spine by the tailbone (coccyx), known as the sacrococcygeal region. Although most of these tumours are non-cancerous (benign), they may grow quite large and, once diagnosed, always require surgical removal. It is likely that all sacrococcygeal teratomas are present at birth (congenital) and most are discovered before birth by a routine prenatal ultrasound examination or an exam indicated for a uterus too large for dates. In rare cases, sacrococcygeal teratomas may be cancerous (malignant) at birth and many will become malignant if surgical resection is not performed.
  • The size of the mass may be as small as a few centimetres in diameter or as massive as the size of the infant.
  • The tumour is further classified based on the location and degree of intrapelvic extension. Lesions that grow predominantly into the presacral region are often present later in childhood. The differential diagnosis includes neural tumours, lipoma, and myelomeningoceles. Diagnosis may be established by prenatal Ultrasonography. Ultrasound performed in the first trimester has a high rate of detection of sacrococcygeal teratoma

This image shows sacrococcygeal teratoma

Treatment:

  • Complete surgical excision through a chevron-shaped buttock incision. Complete resection of the tumour as early as possible is essential for life. The rectum and genital structures are often distorted by the tumour but can be preserved in the course of resection. There is an excellent cure rate if the tumour is excised completely.

Option A: Notochord

  • The notochord is a rod-like cartilaginous skeleton that supports the body. Notochord comes out from the body from the cells called epiblast and hypoblast during the time of gastrulation. These cells develop the central nervous system. Sacrococcygeal teratoma does not originate from the notochord.

Option C: Neural tube

  • The neural tube is the primordium of the brain and spinal cord, and the process of its formation is called neurulation. Neural tube defects are birth defects of the brain, spine, or spinal cord that usually happen in the first month of pregnancy. The two most common neural tube defects are spina bifida and anencephaly. Sacrococcygeal teratoma does not originate from the neural tube.

Option D: Allantois

  • The allantois is a hollow sac-like structure that is filled with transparent fluid, which is involved in the concept of developing an amniotic membrane. It is present in all embryonic and extra-embryonic tissues. Sacrococcygeal teratoma does not originate from the allantois.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital with severe hemorrhagic shock due to polytrauma with a hip fracture; she developed acidosis, coagulopathy, and hypothermia. Which of the following is the first line of therapy for this patient of trauma?
questions.solution:
Option A: Crystalloids

  • The first line of therapy in shock in the patient of trauma is crystalloids.
  • Most patients of shock, regardless of the cause, benefit from a trial of fluid resuscitation given in the form of a crystalloid bolus.
  • Resuscitation following blood loss in trauma patients begins with the administration of 1 litre of isotonic crystalloid immediately to restore blood pressure and peripheral circulation.
  • Lactated ringer (RL) solution is generally preferred over 0.9% NaCl (normal saline) as it is a balanced salt solution designed to mimic extracellular fluid.

Option B: Colloids

  • Resuscitation with colloids is no more effective than crystalloids but is more expensive.

Option C: Inotropes

  • Vasopressors and inotropes are drugs used to create vasoconstriction or increase cardiac contractility, respectively, in patients for shock or any other reason for extremely low blood pressure.

Option D: Blood transfusion

  • For actively bleeding patients, blood and blood products should remain the best therapy in resuscitating bleeding patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department after an accidental shotgun trauma to the abdomen. The entry wound is at the umbilical region. The pulse is 122 bpm, the systolic blood pressure is 95 mmHg, and the respiratory rate is 32/min. Which of the following measures should be taken in this patient in accordance with the CRASH-2 Trial?

choices.text: The dose of tranexamic acid to be administered is 5 gm IV over 10 minutes followed by 5 gm over 8 hours
Alteplase should be administered within 3 hours of injury
Tranexamic acid should be administered within 6 hours of injury
Tranexamic acid should be given to all trauma patients suspected to have a significant hemorrhage, including SBP  110/min

questions.solution:
Option D: Tranexamic acid should be given to all trauma patients suspected to have a significant hemorrhage, including systolic blood pressure <110 mm Hg or pulse rate > 110/min

  • This patient has a pulse of 122 bpm and systolic blood pressure of 95 mmHg and should be administered tranexamic acid in accordance with the CRASH-2 Trial.

Option A: The dose of tranexamic acid to be administered is 5 gm IV over 10 minutes followed by 5 gm over 8 hours

  • According to the CRASH-2 Trial, the dose of tranexamic acid to be administered to this patient is as follows:
  • 1 gm IV over 10 minutes followed by 1 gm over 8 hours

Option B: Alteplase should be administered within 3 hours of injury

  • Alteplase is fibrinolytic, and its administration will further worsen this patient’s hemodynamic status.

Option C: Tranexamic acid should be administered within 6 hours of injury

  • According to the CRASH-2 Trial, tranexamic acid should be administered within 3 hours of injury.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient underwent bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing’s disease, after which the patient developed gradual loss of vision, hyperpigmentation of the skin, and headache. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Option B: Nelson’s syndrome

  • 30% of patients who undergo bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing’s disease are at risk of developing Nelson’s syndrome (corticotroph tumor progression)
  • Nelson syndrome is defined as an enlarging pituitary tumor (new mass or an increase of at least 2 mm in diameter) on MRI
  • Due to the progressive growth of pre-existing pituitary tumors due to loss of feedback inhibition from cortisol.
  • Characterized by
    • Increased ACTH levels
    • Hyperpigmentation
    • Visual field defects
    • Headaches
    • Extraocular muscle palsies
  • Initial mode of therapy: Transsphenoidal pituitary resection
  • This surgery can be performed endoscopically or microscopically
  • The prognosis is good if surgery is performed.
  • If left untreated, it can prove deadly.
  • External beam radiotherapy is used in patients with residual tumors or extracellular invasion

Option A: Addison’s disease

  • Addison’s disease is characterized by adrenal insufficiency.
  • The patient can develop hyperpigmentation of the skin, but headaches and the gradual loss of vision suggest the growth of the pituitary gland in the context of bilateral adrenalectomy. These features are not seen in Addison’s disease.

Option C: Cushing’s disease

  • Cushing disease is characterized by signs and symptoms of hypercortisolism.
  • This patient had Cushing syndrome and underwent bilateral adrenalectomy.
  • His current symptoms are due to excessive ACTH and growth of the pituitary gland.

Option D: Hypopituitarism

  • Instead of hypopituitarism, this patient's pituitary gland is secreting excessive ACTH.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient has a segmental fracture of the right fibular shaft. After stabilization and wound debridement, the patient is taken to the theatre, where vacuum-assisted negative pressure is applied. Which of the following is associated with this procedure?

choices.text: Due to negative pressure, bacterial counts decrease, and cell proliferation increases in the wound
Continuous pressure of +125 mm hg is applied.
It causes interstitial edema, thereby increasing blood flow and better healing.
Suitable to be used over malignancy if present over wound.

questions.solution:
VACUUM ASSISTED CLOSURE/NEGATIVE PRESSURE WOUND THERAPY(NPWT)

  • NPWT promotes wound healing by applying a vacuum through a special sealed dressing.
  • Continued vacuum draws out the fluid (interstitial fluid) from wound and increase blood flow to the area.
  • As a result, bacterial counts decrease and cell proliferation increases, thereby creating a suitable bed for graft or flap cover.
  • Intermittent negative pressure of -125 mm Hg appears to hasten debridement and formation of granulation tissue in chronic wounds and ulcers.
Contraindications for NPWT Use
  • Malignancy in the wound
  • Untreated osteomyelitis
  • Non-enteric & unexplored fistula
  • Necrotic tissue with eschar

questions.text: A 61-year-old male was brought to the emergency department due to confusion, fatigue, lethargy, and anorexia for 1 day. He also complained of right upper quadrant abdominal discomfort. On examination,  pruritus, icterus and hand tremors were noted. Laboratory values show blood glucose 80 mg/dL and an INR of 1.7. Which of the following values of liver enzymes would be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: AST 1100: ALT 1230 

  • The patient presents with fatigue, lethargy, anorexia, right upper quadrant pain, hypoglycemia, and Jaundice due to hyperbilirubinemia, most likely acute liver failure.
  • There are three diagnostic requirements for acute liver failure:
    • Elevated liver enzymes, especially more than 1000 U/L
    • Signs of hepatic encephalopathy, confusion asterixis
    • Synthetic liver dysfunction, e.g., INR more than 1.5
    • Renal insufficiency and thrombocytopenia can also be seen.

Option A:  AST 200: ALT 300

  • There is a marked elevation in AST, and ALT in acute liver failure, usually more than 1000 U/L.
  • A slight elevation in liver enzymes is seen in fatty liver.

Option B: AST 850: ALT 900

  • There is a marked elevation in AST, and ALT in acute liver failure. Usually, more than 1000 U/L, show this option is wrong.

Option C: AST 500: ALT 250

  • A marked elevation in AST, and ALT in acute liver failure, usually more than 1000 U/L, shows this option is wrong.

questions.text: A 5-day-old newborn baby is admitted to the hospital in an agonal state with pale mucosa and acute respiratory failure. The child's mother did not have a prenatal follow-up. She reports the non-existence of disease in the family. An X-ray of the child is given below. Which of the following is not true about the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cataract

Cataract

  • The given radiograph shows bowing of long bones due to multiple transverse fractures in the femur, humerus right 3rd, 4th, and 6th posterior ribs.
  • The most common cause of fracture in childhood is Osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • A cataract is not seen in Osteogenesis Imperfecta

Osteogenesis Imperfecta

  • Bone fragility (brittle "wormian" bone)
  • Short stature
  • Scoliosis
  • Tooth defects (Dentinogenesis imperfecta)
  • Hearing defects
  • Blue sclerae in Types I and II
  • Ligamentous laxity
  • Classification: Four types have been identified
Type Inheritance Sclerae Features
1A,1B A.D. Blue

Onset at preschool age (Tarda); hearing loss; involvement of

teeth (type I.A. only)
II A.R. Blue Lethal; concertina femur, beaded ribs
III A.R. Normal

Fractures at birth, progressively short stature

I.V.A., IVB AD Normal

IV-A,

IV-B		 AD Normal Milder form; normal hearing, involvement of teeth (type I.V.A. only)
  • Treatment:
    • Fracture management
    • Bracing
    • Bisphosphonates

Option A: Blue sclera

  • Because of collagen defects in the blood vessels of the sclera, the scleral vessels become thin.
  • This causes the underlying choroidal vasculature to be seen, giving the sclera a blue appearance

Option B: Multiple Fractures

  • Type I collagen is the major part of the bone.
  • It provides tensile strength to the bone.
  • A defect can lead to weak bone that results in multiple fractures.

Option D: Hearing loss

  • Osteosclerosis or fracture of the bones of the middle ear may result in hearing loss.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female nurse presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of left arm pain 25 minutes ago. She first noted this pain after straining to lift a patient. Over the next several months, the pain and paresthesia progressed slowly to the left shoulder and neck. Upon neurological and musculoskeletal examination of the patient, the cranial nerves II-XII are grossly intact, and the higher cerebral functions are normal. Loss of sensory sensation, pain, and temperature sensation is noticeable in the C3-T1 dermatomes. The vibration and proprioception are normal bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Syringomyelia

  • The given case has paresthesias in the neck and shoulders, along with the loss of crude touch, pain, and temperature in the left upper extremity (dissociative sensory loss), which are classical features of syringomyelia.
  • Syringomyelia classically presents as a loss of pain and temperature sensation in the neck, shoulder, and bilateral upper extremities with the preservation of fine touch, vibratory sense, and proprioception.

  • It is often associated with Chiari I malformation.
  • CT scan may reveal an expanded cord, and the syrinx can be defined on MRI.
  • Deterioration may be slowed down by decompression of the foramen magnum.

Option A: Tuberculosis of the spine

  • Predominantly motor involvement.

Option B: Disc Prolapse

  • In the lumbar region, it commonly affects the nerve roots, thus involving all five sensory modalities.

Option C: Tabes dorsalis (tertiary syphilis):

  • Involvement of posterior column, thus involving fine touch, proprioception, and vibration.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a profound drop in his wrist and some paresthesia to the dorsal of his hand. When taking history, he gives the classic story of having too many drinks the night before and falling asleep on a chair in an uncomfortable position, with his arm draped over the edge of the chair. When he woke up the next day, he felt a dull pain in their upper arm and could not extend his wrist. The patient attempted to neglect the problem and tried to do some exercises to alleviate the pain. However, two hours later, his arm remained quite flaccid to extension. This is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Neuropraxia

  • Seddon coined the term 'neuropraxia' in 1942 to describe a reversible physiological nerve conduction block in which there is loss of some types of sensation and muscle power (due to blocked nerve conduction in the injured area) followed by spontaneous recovery after a few days or weeks.
  • Saturday night palsy refers to a compressive neuropathy of the radial nerve that occurs due to prolonged and direct pressure to the upper medial arm by an object or a surface. It is also called ''Crutch palsy''.
  • It is due to mechanical pressure causing segmental demyelination. It is seen typically in 'crutch palsy', pressure paralysis in states of drunkenness ('Saturday night palsy') and the milder types of tourniquet palsy.

Option A: Neurotmesis

  • Neurotmesis is a complete anatomic section of the peripheral nerve.
  • There is no recovery without surgical intervention, so that surgery would be indicated. Secondary or Wallerian degeneration occurs distal to injuries.
  • Primary or retrograde degeneration occurs in the proximal segment.
  • At the proximal end, the neuroma is usually formed, and at the distal end, glioma is formed.
  • Tinel's Sign is positive and non-progressive.

Option B: Axonotmesis

  • Axonotmesis is an axonal breakdown.
  • Tinel's Sign is positive and progressive.
  • Motor March is seen.
  • Its recovery is usually not complete.
  • It is seen in closed fractures and dislocations.

Option D: Wallerian degeneration of radial nerve

  • It is an active process of retrograde degeneration of the distal end of an axon which results in a nerve lesion.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with dull hip pain, which worsens at night. NSAIDs failed to reduce the pain. He has no history of trauma. The X-ray given below signifies a malignant tumor. It has the best prognosis among all other malignant tumors. It is also radio and chemo-resistant. Identify the commonest site of occurrence of the given tumor.
questions.solution:
Option B: Femur

  • The given case scenario points toward chondrosarcoma.
  • They can occur in any location. However, most are located in a proximal location such as:
    • The proximal femur (most common)
    • Proximal humerus
    • Pelvis
    • Ribs
  • Has dense calcification.
  • Associated with hyperglycemia.
  • Best prognosis amongst malignant tumors.
  • Chondrosarcoma (Best prognosis) > Osteosarcoma >>> Ewing's sarcoma (worst prognosis).
  • Usually metaphyseal and central, i.e., arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification (described as punctate, comma, popcorn calcification).
  • Solitary osteochondroma in <1% can turn into malignant chondrosarcoma.
  • Multiple osteosarcomas in <6% can turn into malignant chondrosarcoma.
  • It occurs over a broad age range:
    • Peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma.
    • Between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma.
  • It is a slow-growing tumor and most common in age over 50 years.
  • It presents with dull pain, which worsens at night.
  • Localized pain and tenderness are also present on palpation.
  • X-ray findings are mouth-eaten or lytic and popcorn-like calcification also called spiculated calcification.
  • A biopsy is diagnostic, and the findings are:
    • Irregular lobules of cartilage
    • Calcium deposits and fibrous bands
    • Treatment of choice is surgery, wide local excision / radical excision

Option A: Pelvis

  • The pelvis can also be involved but is not common as the femur.
  • The pelvis is the most common part affected in Paget's disease.

Option C: Ribs

  • Ribs can also be another site but not the most common. 
  • Plasmacytoma occurs in the pelvis, ribs, and skull.
  • In plasmacytoma, absence of hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia, or additional bone lesions.

Option D: Proximal tibia

  • Only 12% of chondrosarcoma occur in the proximal tibia.
  • In schatzker fracture, the proximal tibia is mostly affected.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with complaints of high-grade fever, cough, myalgia, and loss of sensation of smell for one week. He has no history of any chronic illness. His blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, pulse rate is 110/min, SpO2 is 90%, respiratory rate of 25/minute, and temperature of 102oF. Other general physical examination of the patient reveals no abnormalities. The chest x-ray of the patient was done, which revealed peripheral ground glass opacities in both lungs. He was treated with 15 litres/minute of oxygen through a non-rebreathing mask, antibiotics, and steroids. The maximum FiO2 range delivered to this patient will be which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option D: 0.9-1.0

  • This is a case of sarcoidosis stage 4 in which the patient presents with complaints of high-grade fever, cough, myalgia, and loss of sensation of smell for one week.
  • The chest x-ray of the patient was done, which revealed peripheral ground glass opacities in both lungs.
  • A non-rebreather mask was used in this case which delivers a maximum FiO2 range of 0.9-1.0.
  • The non-rebreather mask is a face mask with two one-way valves. This face mask covers both the nose and mouth.
  • A one-way valve is present between the reservoir bag and the face mask. Oxygen can only flow from the reservoir bag to the mask.
  • The valve prevents the entry of exhaled air into the bag. Another one-way valve lets the exhaled air flow out to the atmosphere but prevents atmospheric air from entering it. Hence there is no re-breathing.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female who is G2P1L1 and has one previous lower segment caesarean section in labour was admitted for emergency repeat lower segment caesarean section under spinal anaesthesia. Which of the following features of anaesthesia will be absent?
questions.solution:
Option D: Segmental block

  • A differential block is a clinical phenomenon in which nerve fibres with distinct functions respond differently to local anaesthetic blocking. It has been seen in both neuraxial and peripheral nerve blocks.
  • Epidural blocks are used to create a differential block. Different concentrations are employed to block certain nerve fibres. Local anaesthetics, for example, induce analgesia by blocking sensory fibres without causing a motor blockage.

Option A: Fast onset

  • Spinal anaesthesia has a rapid onset of lumbosacral and thoracic anaesthesia

​​​​​​​Option B: Dense block

  • Spinal anaesthesia creates a dense block.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option C: Fewer chances of failure

  • In contrast to epidural anaesthesia, spinal anaesthesia is a fairly simple procedure. Therefore it has fewer chances of failure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. She has had two episodes of acute cholecystitis. She has had hypertension for 10 years and type 2 diabetes mellitus for 5 years. Her BMI is 36 Kg/m2. The subclavian vein is cannulated due to difficulty in peripheral cannulation. The intraoperative course remains uneventful, and the patient is extubated and shifted to the postoperative ward. After 24 hours in the postoperative ward, the patient is dyspneic and tachypneic. Her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, pulse is 120/min, and SpO2 is 88%. Chest examination reveals decreased breath sounds on the left side. The most probable diagnosis in this patient is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pneumothorax

  • Central venous cannulation: Subclavian vein
  • This patient’s presentation with hypotension, tachycardia, decreased oxygen saturation, and examination findings of decreased breath sound on the right side after subclavian catheterization are most likely due to right-sided pneumothorax.
  • Pneumothorax is a potential complication of catheterization.
  • Subclavian vein is the site with the least infection and better patient tolerance.
  • The demerit is a torturous course and high risk for pneumothorax, neurovascular injuries
  • Pleura being in close proximity to subclavian cannulation has a high incidence of pneumothorax, and another common problem is the malposition of the catheter due to its tortuous course.
  • Pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum occurs in about one percent of cases. 
  • An increased number of attempts during insertion and a large diameter catheter increases the risk of pneumothorax

Option A: Infection

  • Infection can occur due to central venous cannulation.
  • However, the infection does not cause acute presentation and haemodynamic instability as in this patient.

Option C: Carotid artery puncture

  • Carotid artery puncture can result during cannulation. It can cause haemodynamic instability
  • However, it does not present with decreased breath sounds on the right side.

Option D: Subcutaneous emphysema

  • Subcutaneous emphysema can occur as a complication of subclavian catheterization. It presents with difficulty breathing, swallowing, and speaking. Examination findings reveal crepitus.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema does not present with absent breath sounds as in this patient.

questions.text: A 38-year-old morbidly obese male is posted for bariatric surgery under general anaesthesia. He has been a known case of hypertension and diabetes mellitus for five years. He gives no history of any other abnormalities. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination is unremarkable. After premedication, which of the following is the most effective method to preoxygenate this patient for denitrogenation and to delay desaturation during intubation?

choices.text: Four vital capacity breaths over 30 seconds
Eight vital capacity breaths over 1 minute
Eight vital capacity breaths over 3 minutes

questions.solution:
Correct answer Option B: Eight vital capacity breaths over 1 minute

  • This is a case of bariatric surgery in which a morbidly obese male patient is posted for surgery. This surgery is commonly done for the removal of fat to prevent the risks associated with obesity.
  • Preoxygenation before anaesthetic induction and tracheal intubation is a widely accepted manoeuvre designed to increase the body’s oxygen stores and thereby delay the onset of arterial haemoglobin desaturation during apnea.
  • Because difficulties with ventilation and intubation are unpredictable, the need for preoxygenation is desirable in all patients.
  • During emergence from anaesthesia, residual effects of anaesthetics and inadequate reversal of neuromuscular blockade can lead to hypoventilation, hypoxemia, and loss of airway patency.
  • In accordance, routine preoxygenation before the tracheal extubation has also been recommended.
  • Eight breaths over 1 minute are more effective. Four breaths over 30 seconds are not as effective as the tidal volume method but may be used in some clinical situations.

Other options

Option A: Four vital capacity breaths over 30 seconds

  • The four vital capacity breaths over 30 seconds are not the most effective method as compared to tidal volume ventilation or eight breaths over the 1-minute method.
  • It is a time-sparing method to ask the patient to take four full vital capacity breaths over 30 seconds.

Option C: Tidal volume ventilation over 2 minutes

  • Tidal volume ventilation through a facemask for 3 minutes allows the exchange of 95% of gas in the lungs.

Option D: Eight vital capacity breaths over 3 minutes

  • The vital capacity breaths achieve adequate preoxygenation more rapidly at eight breaths over 1 minute rather than eight vital capacity breaths over 3 minutes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man came to the neurology OPD with chief complaints of ataxia and abnormal eye movements. On examination, vertical gaze palsy is seen. An MRI was performed [refer to image given below]. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option D: Progressive supra-nuclear palsy

Progressive supra-nuclear palsy

  • HUMMINGBIRD SIGN and MICKEY MOUSE SIGN are features of Progressive supranuclear palsy.
  • Figure showing Hummingbird sign in Progressive supranuclear palsy.
  • Figure showing Mickey-Mouse sign in Progressive supranuclear palsy.
  • A hot cross bun sign is seen MSA-C.
  • Loss of swallowtail sign is seen in Parkinsonism.

Option A: Multiple system atrophy-Cerebellar types

  • Multisystem atrophy type – c the involvement in the pontocerebellar pathway
  • Multiple system atrophy - cerebellar subtype (MSA-C) is a rare disease that causes areas deep in the brain, just above the spinal cord, to shrink (atrophy)
  • MSA-C used to be known as olivopontocerebellar atrophy (OPCA).

Option B: Parkinsonism

  • Parkinsonism is a general term that refers to a group of neurological disorders that cause movement problems similar to those seen in Parkinson's disease
  • Tremors are typical, but the disorder may also cause stiffness or slowing of movement.

Option C: Cerebellar ataxia

  • Progressive supranuclear palsy is an uncommon brain disorder that causes severe problems with walking, balance, and eye movements, and later with swallowing.
  • The cause of progressive supranuclear palsy isn't known.
  • The signs and symptoms of the disorder result from the deterioration of cells in areas of your brain.

questions.text: During an exam, a medical student was shown a scintigraphy imaging of a 69-year-old woman. She was admitted to ICU with a severe lung infection and was on a ventilator. Her personal history was positive for anemia, leukopenia, photosensitive rash, and seizure disorder. She is unresponsive. Corneal, gag, and cough reflexes are absent. No motor reaction to noxious stimulation of limbs or face. Her  pCO2 was 67 mm Hg, and her pH was 7.21 when mechanical ventilation assistance was removed. What does the following Tc99m-HMPAO scintigraphy image suggest?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: Brain Death

  • Neurological examination should confirm coma, brainstem areflexia, and apnea.

  • Tc-99m HMPAO scan shows absent Cerebral Perfusion suggestive of Brain Death.

  • Absent uptake in the Brain is called Empty Light Bulb Sign

  • Decreased or Absent flow in internal carotid arteries leads to increase flow within external carotid arteries and subsequently increased perfusion in the nasal region, called a HOT NOSE sign

  • Empty Light Bulb Sign :

Hot Nose Sign :

Option A: Sarcoidosis

  • Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disorder that can involve the nervous system, presenting as facial nerve palsy.

  • Other common extrapulmonary manifestations of sarcoidosis include lymphadenopathy, hypercalcemia, and parotid gland swelling.

  • Imaging shows: Bilateral hilar adenopathy and Pulmonary reticular infiltrates

  • Scintigraphic imaging is not routinely recommended in sarcoidosis and is not consistent with sarcoidosis.

Option C: Adenoid Hyperplasia

  • Adenoid hypertrophy is the enlargement of the adenoid tissue located in the upper airway between the nose and the back of the throat.

  • Enlargement occurs most commonly in children under the age of 5 and is usually the result of bacterial or viral infections.

  • Adenoid hypertrophy diagnoses include lateral neck x-ray, videofluoroscopy, palpation, and nasal endoscopy The standard diagnostic criteria can only be indicative, and the diagnosis is made via transnasal endoscopy confirmed by an otolaryngologist.

Option D: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)

  • Although this patient has exam findings of SLE, her neurological findings suggest brain death.

  • SLE is a clinical diagnosis.

  • Infections are the most common complications of SLE

questions.text: A 20-year-old pregnant woman living in a village came to gynaecology OPD for the evaluation of her pregnancy. She has been married for six months and came to know of her pregnancy through a urine dip test. This is her first antenatal visit. The doctor takes the patient's detailed medical history and performs an obstetric examination. The patient was asked about her LMP, about which she was unsure. The doctor decided to do an ultrasound to determine her gestational age. Which of the below parameter gives an accurate assessment of gestational age?
questions.solution:
Option D: Crown-rump length

  • In the scenario, a woman who got pregnant recently is discussed. It was her first antenatal visit, and she was unsure of her LMP. The best parameter for accurate gestational age assessment is the crown-rump length in the 9-12 weeks or first trimester.
  • The crown-rump length (CRL)is measured as the longest length in a straight line from the cranial to the caudal end of the body of the embryo/fetus.
  • It is the best parameter for assessing fetal age in the first trimester. The best time to assess the gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks (by Crown-rump length).
  • The graph below shows the CRL and gestational age.

​​​​​​​

  • Once the CRL reaches 7 mm, a heartbeat should be detected by ultrasound. If no heartbeat or cardiac activity is detected, then the pregnancy is likely a miscarriage.
  • A decrease in CRL is used to diagnose early chromosomal anomalies like trisomy 18
  • The ultrasound image below shows the CRL.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Ultrasound is an imaging machine that uses sound waves to create images of structures within your body. The images created provide precious information for diagnosing and starting treatment for various diseases and conditions.

Option A: Biparietal Diameter

  • It is the diameter of the developing baby skull taken during an ultrasound and is the measure of length from the right parietal bone to the left.
  • It is used to estimate fetal weight and gestational age.
  • BPD is measured in the trans-thalamic view at the level of the thalami and cavum septum pellucidum.
  • It is significant in the second trimester of pregnancy.
  • Cephalic index = BPD divided by occipito-frontal diameter (OFD) CI = BPD/ OFD.
  • If the head shape is flattened (dolichocephaly) or rounded (brachycephaly), then HC is more reliable than BPD.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option B: Abdominal circumference

  • It is the measure of the fetal abdomen during an ultrasound.
  • It is the best indicator of fetal growth.
  • So the best USG parameter to detect IUGR is an abdominal circumference.
  • The best USG parameter to detect macrosomia is the abdominal circumference.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option C: Femur length

  • Measures the longest bone in the body.
  • It reflects the longitudinal growth of the fetus.
  • It is important in the third trimester of pregnancy.
  • Its significance is similar to the BPD, increasing from about 1.5 cm at 14 weeks to about 7.8 cm at term.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 65-years-old hypertensive patient presented to the Emergency department with sudden onset abdominal pain for one day. On physical examination, the blood pressure was 80/60 mm Hg, and the ECG was normal. An Urgent CT aortogram was performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Aortic dissection Stanford type-B.

Aortic dissection

This patient had a sudden onset of abdominal pain followed by decreased blood pressure, and the CT-aortogram showed an intimal tear, likely aortic dissection.

  • It is the most common non-traumatic acute aortic emergency.

  • The aetiology is frequently unknown but is related to advanced age and hypertension.

  • It is initiated by an intimal tear which allows blood to penetrate the medial layer, producing a cleavage plan (false lumen) between the inner two-thirds and outer one-third of the media.

  • An intimomedial flap separates the true and false lumens.

  • This allows the blood to flow through the tear and eventually extend distal or proximally.

  • ‘Stanford classification’ divides aortic dissections into type A (involving the ascending aorta) and type B (DESCENDING AORTA, Below the Left Clavicular artery ).

  • Approximately 70% of dissections are type A, and 30% are types B. Type A carries high mortality and morbidity and requires urgent intervention compared to type B dissection, which can be managed with medication.

  • Type A: A affects the ascending aorta

    • Accounts for ~60% of aortic dissections

    • Requires surgical management

    • This may result in:

      • Coronary artery occlusion

      • Aortic incompetence

      • Rupture into the pericardial sac resulting in cardiac tamponade

  • Type B: B begins beyond brachiocephalic vessels

    • Accounts for ~40% of aortic dissections

    • Dissection commences distal to the left subclavian artery

    • Medical management with blood pressure control

    • Figure: showing the coronal section of aortic dissection.

Option A: Aortic aneurysm

  • An aortic aneurysm does not show as a false lumen along with a true lumen, as shown in the image above. It merely shows the dilatation of the aortic vessel.

Option B: Aortic dissection Stanford type-A

  • Aortic dissection Stanford type A involves the ascending aorta.

  • The image shown is of the region of the aorta beyond the left subclavian involving the descending aorta.

  • Thus the patient has Stanford type B aortic dissection.​​​​​​​

Option D: Pulmonary thromboembolism

  • Pulmonary thromboembolism may present with sudden onset of chest pain instead of abdominal pain.

  • Furthermore, the chest x-ray would show the Westmark sign. It would not show a dissected aorta with true and false lumens.​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 37-year-old G2P2 woman presents to the gynecologist with pain in her lower abdomen and dysmenorrhea. On a pelvic scan, a complex ovarian cyst is 4 x 5 cm in size with a ground glass appearance. She is a chronic smoker, using combined contraceptive pills, and menstrual cycles coming at intervals of 20 days since menarche. A cystectomy is done, and histology reveals endometrial glands and hemorrhage. Which of the following in the patient's history is a risk factor for her condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Shorter menstrual cycle length

  • History of congestive dysmenorrhea, ovarian cyst and histopathological examination of endometrial glands is suggestive of endometriosis.
  • A shorter menstrual cycle length implies more menstrual cycles, which means more menstruation and, therefore, more severe endometriosis.
  • Protective factors against the development of endometriosis include:
    • Multiparity
    • Lactation
    • Tobacco exposure in utero
    • Diet high in vegetables and fruits.
  • Risk factors for endometriosis:
    • Infertility
    • Early age at menarche
    • Shorter menstrual cycle length
    • Nulliparity
    • High estrogen exposure
    • Mullerian anomalies
    • Low BMI
    • Family history
  • Prior use of contraception, intrauterine devices (IUD), or smoking is not associated with an increased risk of endometriosis.

Option A: Multiparity

  • Multiparity is protective for endometriosis as pregnancy and lactation imply the absence of periods for the associated period of amenorrhea.

Option B: OCPs use

  • OCPs are not risk factors for endometriosis as they reduce the net amount of estrogen in the body. Since endometriosis is a hyperestrogenic condition, it is not increased with the use of OCPs.

Option C: Smoking

  • Smoking inhibits the aromatase enzyme ( responsible for converting androgens to estrogen in the periphery), thus reducing estrogen and not increasing the risk of endometriosis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and itching since menopause. She has a family history of heart disease. She has no history of an abnormal pap smear. She is on hormone replacement therapy. Her vital signs are normal. All of the following would be expected benefits of HRT in this patient, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Option A: Prevention of heart diseases

  • HRT is indicated in menopausal women to overcome the short-term and long-term consequences of estrogen deficiency.
  • Hormone Replacement Therapy is not indicated for the prevention or treatment of cardiovascular disease.
  • Natural estrogens produced in the body till menopause are cardio-protective; however, Hormone Replacement Therapy (containing exogenous estrogens and progesterone) is not cardio-protective.

Indications of hormone replacement therapy in a menopausal woman

  • Relief of vasomotor symptoms: hot flushes.
  • Prevention and treatment of osteoporosis.
  • Urogenital atrophy.
  • Premature Menopause.

 

Option B: Relief in hot flushes

  • Around 75% of menopausal women get hot flushes.
  • This may be seen for up to 1-2 years in most women but can go up to 10 years
  • The most important pathogenesis is not just estrogen deficiency but "estrogen withdrawal." Estrogen is the mainstay of management of hot flush.
  • HRT is used in this condition.

 

Option C: Relief in vaginal itching

  • Vulvovaginal atrophy in menopausal women is associated with vulva and vaginal dryness and increased chances of vaginitis and urethritis.
  • HRT is used for the relief of vaginal itching and urethritis.

 

Option D: Prevention of menopausal osteoporosis

  • Osteoporosis and increased risk of fractures are due to more osteoclastic activity and less osteoblastic activity in the absence of estrogen.
  • HRT is indicated both for the prevention and treatment of osteoporosis.

questions.text: You see four postmenopausal patients in the clinic. The patients have one condition, each listed below. Which of the following is not a contraindication to HRT?

choices.text: Mild essential hypertension with tension headache
A liver disease with abnormal liver function tests

questions.solution:
Option A: Mild essential hypertension with tension headache

  • In this case, the patient with hypertension can use hormone replacement therapy.
  • If the patient has mild or severe hypertension or is on antihypertensive drugs, she can use HRT.

Absolute contraindications:

Absolute contraindications to post-menopausal hormone replacement therapy are

  • Estrogen-dependent tumours (breast or uterus)
  • Active thromboembolic disease
  • Undiagnosed genital tract bleeding
  • Active severe liver disease
  • Malignant melanoma.
  • Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding
  • Untreated endometrial hyperplasia

A history of hypertension, diabetes or biliary stones does not automatically disqualify a patient for hormone replacement therapy.

Option B: A liver disease with abnormal liver function tests

  • Abnormal LFTs imply an active liver disease that is contraindicated to starting HRT.
  • Hormone replacement therapy can cause mild inhibition of bilirubin excretion, possibly leading to jaundice in patients with liver diseases.

 

Option C: Treated stage III endometrial cancer

  • Endometrial cancers are estrogen-dependent cancers, and estrogens, therefore, are contraindicated.
  • Post-menopausal women on HRT containing estrogen are at increased risk of endometrial hyperplasia and cancer.

Option D: Undiagnosed genital tract bleeding

Undiagnosed genital tract bleeding could be due to an estrogen-dependent condition, including genital malignancies, and therefore the patient must be thoroughly evaluated before starting HRT.

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 33 weeks of pregnancy with complaints of swelling in bilateral feet. She states that the swelling is worst at the end of the day and subsides by morning. Her BP is 120/74 mmHg, and cardiac examination shows normal S1 and S2. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bed rest with feet elevation
Physiological oedema of pregnancy:

  • The cause of physiological oedema is due to increased venous pressure of the inferior extremities by the gravid uterus pressing on the common iliac vein Oedema disappears on rest with foot end elevation
  • BP should be checked to rule out pre-eclampsia
  • Salt restriction, diuretics and fluid restriction have no role in the management of physiological oedema
  • Diuretics and fluid restriction may be offered to patients having oedema secondary to heart disease to reduce preload.

Option A: Salt restriction

  • Salt restriction will lead to a decrease in hydrostatic pressure within the vessel.
  • However, the main mechanism of oedema of physiology is venous stasis.

Option C: 2D echocardiography

  • This is recommended in suspected heart failure.
  • In such cases, dyspnea, orthopnea, and raised JVP will be present.

Option D: Diuretics

  • A volume overload states such as cirrhosis and heart failure leads to oedema.
  • In such cases, diuretic therapy is indicated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, presents to the outpatient department in early pregnancy for antenatal counselling. She has a history of deep vein thrombosis of the right leg 5 years ago. She has not had any other episode of a thrombotic phenomenon since then. Her blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and her pulse is 82/min. She is advised for thromboprophylaxis in pregnancy. This is because the risk of thromboembolism increases in pregnancy as:

choices.text: Increased hepatic production of clotting factors

questions.solution:
Option B: Increased hepatic production of clotting factors

  • Stasis, Hypercoagulability and vascular trauma (Virchow’s triad) occur in pregnancy and thus increase the risk of thrombosis.

Hypercoagulability is due to Increased concentrations of all clotting factors except factors XI and XIII.

  • Increase in Fibrinogen, prothrombin and factors VII, VIII, IX & X: In normal nonpregnant women, plasma fibrinogen (factor I) averages 300 mg/dL and ranges from 200 to 400 mg/dL. During normal pregnancy, fibrinogen concentration increases by approximately 50 %. In late pregnancy, it averages 450 mg/dL, with a range from 300 to 600 mg/dL.
  • Decrease in levels of protein S. Resistance to activated protein C.
  • Increase in levels of antifibrinolytic Types 1 & 2, plasminogen activator inhibitor PAI type 1 & 2.

The net result is a reduction in the risk of antepartum, intrapartum and postpartum haemorrhage but a dramatic 10-fold increase in pregnancy-associated thromboembolism.

 

Option A: Viscosity of blood increases

  • The viscosity of blood decreases because of haemodilution; it does not increase.

 

Option C: Increased antithrombin III levels

  • Antithrombin III levels increase in pregnant ladies with a history of hypertension. However, this patient has no history of hypertension.

 

Option D: Increased progesterone levels

  • Oestrogen, compared to progesterone, is more notorious for causing thrombus formation and thromboembolism.

questions.text: What is the risk of using the contraceptive form a female purchased over the counter considering her heart condition, which is categorized as Category-4 in the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria for contraceptive use?

choices.text: She can use it if no other contraceptive fulfills her requirement
It is meant only for a particular heart condition

questions.solution:
Option B: She should not use it

 

  • This patient has this contraceptive in category 4 for her heart condition, which means this particular contraceptive must absolutely NOT be used.

WHO: MEC: Medical Eligibility Criteria for Contraceptive Use

MEC categories for contraceptive eligibility

1. A condition for which there is no restriction for the use of the contraceptive method

2. A condition where the advantages of using the method generally outweigh the theoretical or proven risks

3. A condition where the theoretical or proven risk usually outweigh the advantages of using the method

4. A condition which represents an unacceptable health risk if the contraceptive method is used

 

Categories 1 and 4 are self-explanatory

Category 1 denotes indications and category 4 indicates absolute contraindications;

Categories 2 and 3 indicate relative contraindications)

Option A : She can safely use it

  • Category 1 is the contraceptive that she can safely use.

Option C : She can use it if no other contraceptive fulfils her requirement

  • Category 3 are contraceptives which can be used very rarely when no other contraceptive suits the patient, and using contraceptive is a necessity.

Option D : It is meant only for the particular heart condition

  • Category 4 does not imply that the contraceptive can be used only for that particular condition. There is no such category.

questions.text: A 27-year-old gravida 2 para 1 presents to the maternity emergency with active labour at the 37th week of gestation. The patient is given a trial of vaginal delivery but undergoes a cesarean section due to the arrest of the second stage of labour. A lateral extension of an angle of the uterine incision is given during delivery of the head, which is secured. Two hours postoperatively, the patient develops abdominal distension and pallor. Pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 90/60. Physical examination shows postpartum haemorrhage. Laboratory investigation shows a drop in Hb from 10gm% to 6.5gm%. Which of the following is the next most definitive step in managing the patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Immediate exploration in operation theatre

  • The patient here shows signs of hemodynamic compromise characterized by tachycardia, hypotension, bleeding and a drop in Hb concentration after LSCS which had a lateral extension. This is suggestive of acute haemorrhage in the patient.
  • Mild postpartum haemorrhage does not correspond with the amount of compromise and anaemia. Therefore it appears to be a case of intra-abdominal bleeding from the lateral extension or an unidentified bleeder, which should be immediately explored and secured.

Complications during cesarean section

  • Hemorrhage
  • Infections such as endometritis, surgical wound infection
  • Trauma to surrounding structures such as bladder, bowel, and ureter
  • Thrombophlebitis
  • Anaesthesia-related complications
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Amniotic fluid embolism

Option A: Uterotonics and blood transfusion

  • Uterotonics are indicated in atonic PPH which does not appear proportionate to hemodynamic instability in this case, hence does not appear to be the cause.
  • Oxytocin, ergometrine and misoprostol induce contractions of the uterus, thus helping the blood vessels to close that carried blood to the placenta.

Option B: Blood transfusion and monitoring

  • Blood transfusion must be done immediately to compensate for the blood loss, but it will not suffice until the active source of bleeding is identified and secured.

Option D: Intrauterine packing and blood transfusion

  • Intrauterine packing is indicated for the atonic PPH, where the pressure packing reduces blood loss. It can be used temporarily for shifting the patient to the facility hospital.
  • However, the blood transfusion is immediately required but identifying and securing the active bleeder is foremost in this case.

questions.text: A woman follows up 1 week after delivery for routine evaluation. She has no fever or abdominal pain. On abdominal examination, there are a firm globular mobile pelvic mass measuring 14 weeks in size. Vaginal examination shows bleeding not associated with foul smell, and episiotomy is healthy. Her breasts are enlarged and show milk discharge bilaterally. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Ultrasound to rule out fibroid or ovarian mass
Ultrasound of breasts and serum prolactin levels

questions.solution:
Option C: Routine care

  • The presence of a firm globular abdominal mass arising from the pelvis is suggestive of a well-contracted uterus in a postpartum case.
  • At 1 week, the uterus is still an abdominal organ and becomes pelvic by 2 weeks.
  • Vaginal bleeding and enlarged lactating breasts are also normal signs in the puerperium.

Involution of the uterus:

  • Immediately after delivery- just below the umbilicus
  • The uterus becomes a pelvic organ in 10-14 days
  • Uterus comes to normal size in 4-6 weeks
  • The normal rate of reduction of the size of the uterus → 1-2 cm/ day

Causes of Subinvolution:

  • Infection
  • Retained bits of Placenta & Membranes
  • Blood clots
  • Fibroids

Clinical features of subinvolution:

  • Boggy or flabby uterus
  • Palpable beyond 10 days per abdomen
  • Tender Uterus
  • Fever is present

Option A: Ultrasound to rule out fibroid or ovarian mass

  • USG to rule out fibroid or ovarian mass is required in cases of subinvolution, say, if the uterus remains palpable abdominally after 2 weeks.

​​​​​​​Option B: Ultrasound for RPOCs

  • USG for RPOCs is also required in cases of subinvolution. Symptoms can include abnormal vaginal bleeding, fever or infection. ​​​​​​​

Option D: Ultrasound breasts and serum prolactin levels

  • Enlarged breasts with milk discharge are normal in puerperium, or lactation of the newborn.
  • Some prevalent problems are breast engorgement, plugged ducts, breast infection, breast abscess, and nipple fissures.
  • These problems can cause pain, inadequate emptying of the breasts, and early weaning for the mother.
  • They may appear immediately after delivery or anytime during the lactation period.

questions.text: A baby is born after a difficult delivery. The paediatrician examines the baby for any nerve injuries that may have occurred in the baby as a result of undue traction. Which of the following is true of brachial plexus injuries?

choices.text: They occur exclusively with shoulder dystocia.
They may result in Erb's palsy or Klumpke paralysis.
They frequently occur after downward traction on the posterior shoulder during delivery.

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option C: They may result in Erb palsy or Klumpke paralysis

Brachial plexus injuries of newborn

  • These are fairly common and seen in 1-3/ 1000 live births
  • More common with vaginal delivery than caesarean
  • Risk factors: breech delivery and shoulder dystocia, however, can occur without risk factors.
  • C5-6 nerve injury is Erb's paralysis, more commonly seen with breech, but more severe forms are seen in difficult cephalic delivery. The affected arm is straight and internally rotated, the elbow is extended, and the wrist and fingers are flexed.
  • C8-T1 root injury is Klumpke's paralysis, and the hand is flaccid
  • In most cases, axonal death does not occur, and the prognosis is good
  • Global C5-8-T1 injury is almost always associated with a permanent disability.

Option A: They occur exclusively with shoulder dystocia

  • ​​​​Only half of the injuries are associated with shoulder dystocia.

Option B: They are usually permanent

  • Nerves heal slowly, so brachial plexus injury recovery can take several weeks to months, depending on the severity.
  • During this time, regular physical therapy appointments to prevent muscle atrophy and contractures are often necessary.
  • Most babies who experience a brachial plexus injury at birth will fully recover within three to four months.

Option D: They frequently occur after downward traction on the posterior shoulder during delivery

 

  • These occur with downward traction of the anterior shoulder.

questions.text: An unbooked primigravida presents at term in active labour with adequate uterine contractions. On examination, the cervix is dilated 7 cm, and fetal buttocks are palpable. Soon the membranes rupture, and the breech comes out of the cervix. In which of the following conditions the after-coming head of the breech will be easily delivered?
questions.solution:
Option B: Placenta previa

 

 

  • The after-coming head will deliver if the presenting portion of the baby has already been delivered, which suggests that the placenta was not a full placenta previa and so the after coming head will likely deliver too.

Option A: Hydrocephalus

  • In hydrocephalus, the head is too large for the pelvic space, and decompressing the head necessitates a craniocentesis or a craniotomy.

Option C : Incomplete dilatation of cervix

  • The foetal neck is gripped by incomplete dilatation of the cervix, which prevents the delivery of the breech baby’s head.

Option D: Extension of head

  • When a baby has an extended head of breech, the baby’s chin becomes trapped on the sacrum or the symphysis pubis, preventing the delivery of the after-coming head.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with PCOS undergoing fertility treatment with clomiphene citrate and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) injections complained of severe abdominal distension, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty breathing. On examination, she had moderate ascites, tachycardia, and hypotension. What is the likely cause of her current symptoms?

choices.text: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a potential complication.
The symptoms are likely related to ectopic pregnancy.
The patient is at high risk for ovarian torsion.
The findings are consistent with a normal response to fertility treatments.

questions.solution:
Option A: Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome

  • Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) is a medical complication unique to stimulatory infertility treatment; very rarely, it may present spontaneously.
  • Presents with the symptoms of fluid leakage in the body, such as abdominal distension, pain, nausea, vomiting, increased thirst, and bloating. Severe cases may present with pulmonary oedema, coagulopathy, and acute kidney failure.
  • In the above case scenario, there is a history of infertility and the use of clomiphene with gonadotrophin therapy with multiple follicular development.
  • OHSS may present in pregnancy and can occur with a more severe form in pregnancy, so a positive urine pregnancy test should not create confusion in the diagnosis of OHSS.
  • Early OHSS occurs 3-7 days following the HCG trigger and is associated with the administration of exogenous HCG.
  • The late-onset disease occurs 12-17 days after the HCG trigger. It results from endogenous HCG secretion during the pregnancy and tends to be more severe with multiple gestation.
  • Management is by monitoring the input and output of fluids. And also by intravascular fluid intake to replenish the volume and symptomatic treatment, like the tapping of the ascites and pleural effusion
  • It is normally a self-limiting condition.
  • Management of severe cases of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is done by admitting the patient for monitoring and following strict protocols to prevent secondary life-threatening complications.

Option B: Ruptured ovarian cyst

  • A ruptured ovarian cyst presents with acute abdominal pain and tenderness with abdominal distension; however, here, it is unlikely as there is no history of a pre-existing cyst. Also, the mention of a history of ovulation induction and trigger for follicular rupture makes OHSS more likely.

Option C: Ectopic pregnancy requiring β-HCG follow-up

  • Ectopic pregnancy presents with a history of amenorrhea associated with abdominal pain and spotting PV. It is, therefore, an important differential here. However, she has presented on the day of her missed period, and the USG suggests ascites. Thus, the background of the history of infertility treatment makes OHSS more likely here.​​​​​​​

Option D: Ectopic pregnancy requiring immediate surgery

  • Ectopic pregnancy requiring laparotomy implies a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, which presents with acute abdomen with pelvic tenderness on examination, and USG should reveal an adnexal mass, which is not the case here. A laparotomy would have been indicated if the patient was hemodynamically unstable or if USG suggested hemoperitoneum with the same clinical picture.

questions.text: In a 43-year-old woman with heavy and frequent menstrual bleeding, an endometrial biopsy reveals endometrial hyperplasia. Among the among the given histological patterns which one poses the highest risk for developing endometrial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option D: Complex hyperplasia with atypia

  • The risk of endometrial cancer is highest in a case of complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia.
  • The most common risk factor for endometrial hyperplasia is increased circulating estrogen, which is unopposed by progesterone. E.g., obesity, nulliparity, late menopause, exogenous estrogen such as tamoxifen, etc.
  • There is Complex endometrial hyperplasia which has marked glandular complexities and back-to-back overcrowded glands, and simple endometrial hyperplasia, which has a proliferation of endometrial glands more than normal but lacks glandular complexities and back-to-back overcrowded glands
  • The incidence of occurrence of endometrial cancer in the case of endometrial hyperplasia is as follows
Simple hyperplasia with out Atypia is 1%
Complex hyperplasia with out Atypia 3%
Simple hyperplasia with Atypia 8%
Complex hyperplasia with Atypia 29%

Option A: Simple hyperplasia without atypia

  • Simple Endometrial Hyperplasia without atypical cells 1% risk of Ca endometrium

Option B: Simple hyperplasia with atypia

  • Simple Endometrial Hyperplasia with atypical cells has an 8% risk of developing cancer.

Option C: Complex hyperplasia without atypia

  • Complex Endometrial Hyperplasia without atypical cells has a 3% risk of developing cancer.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman with primary infertility presents for evaluation. Her menstrual cycles have intervals of 40-60 days. She has normal flow and is not associated with dysmenorrhea. She is also currently on treatment for facial acne. The physician has advised certain blood investigations on day 2 of her next cycle. Which of the following biochemical findings are not expected in her case?

choices.text: LH: FSH ratio is increased, FSH is low normal
Increased Sex Hormone binding globulin, Fasting insulin< 10 mIU/L

questions.solution:
Option D: Increased Sex Hormone binding globulin, Fasting insulin< 10 mIU/L

  • History of infertility, delayed cycles (40-60 days), no dysmenorrhea (also hints towards anovulation) and acne (hyperandrogenism) are suggestive of PCOD.
  • Endocrinal changes in PCOS:
  • Increased Estrogen level (chronic hyperestrogenic state), reversal of E1:E2 ratio
  • Increased LH level
  • LH: FSH ratio increases to 2:1 or 3:1
  • Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  • Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidemia
  • HDL<50 mg/dL
  • Testosterone >2 ng/mL
  • Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS
  • Sex hormone binding globin decrease
  • Urinary cortisol <50 µg/24 h.

Option A: Low Progesterone, Increased Estrogen level

  • PCOD is associated with low progesterone (as cycles are anovulatory) and high estrogen (excess ovarian steroidogenesis)

Option B: HDL<50 mg/dL , Triglyceride >150 mg/dL

  • PCOD is associated with an unfavorable lipid profile
  • HDL<50 mg/dL
  • Triglyceride >150 mg/dL
  • Hence increased risk of metabolic syndrome

Option C: LH: FSH ratio is increased, FSH is low normal

  • High estrogen and LH are very high
  • FSH is low
  • LH: FSH ratio >2:1 or > 3:1(classical)

questions.text: What is true regarding elective hysterectomy planned for a 49-year-old perimenopausal female with a large uterine fibroid, heavy menstrual bleeding, and symptomatic gallstones?

choices.text: A supracervical hysterectomy should be considered to preserve sexual function and pelvic support.
Cholecystectomy should not be combined with hysterectomy as it increases postoperative febrile morbidity and length of hospital stay.
Since the age group is likely for an endometrial malignancy, a radical Hysterectomy is a better option.

questions.solution:
Option C: Thromboprophylaxis is required post-operatively.

  • All patients undergoing hysterectomy for benign disorders are at (at least) moderate risk for venous thromboembolism and require prophylaxis.
  • Mechano-prophylaxis (intermittent pneumatic compression devices), chemoprophylaxis (unfractionated heparin or low molecular weight heparin), or a combination of chemoprophylaxis and mechano-prophylaxis are indicated, depending on the patient’s risk.
  • Pelvic surgeries are the maximum risk of DVT development, and hence, thromboprophylaxis is required here.
  • Thromboprophylaxis is summarised below:

Option A: A supracervical hysterectomy should be considered to preserve sexual function and pelvic support.

  • There is no evidence to support the concept that leaving the cervix improves sexual function or lower rates of incontinence or constipation.

Option B: Cholecystectomy should not be combined with hysterectomy as it increases postoperative febrile morbidity and length of hospital stay.

  • Gallbladder disease is about four times more common in women than men, and its highest incidence occurs between 50 and 70 years of age when hysterectomy is most often performed.
  • Women may require both procedures, and a combined procedure does not appear to result in increased febrile morbidity or length of hospital stay.

Option D: Since the age group is likely for an endometrial malignancy, a radical Hysterectomy is a better option.

  • A radical hysterectomy is a way more morbid surgery and is not recommended till a malignancy is proved.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl with irregular menstrual bleeding for 3 months. Menarche at 13 years old. Cycle length varies between 35 to 45 days. Bleeding lasts for 7 to 12 days and sometimes involves heavy bleeding. Negative pregnancy test. Multiple normal ultrasounds and normal coagulation profile. Which of the following is true regarding her condition?

choices.text: Bleeding is likely to be associated with a missed pelvic pathology and an MRI should be advised
Bleeding is most likely due to estrogen breakthrough
Cycle length increases due to a longer secretory phase

questions.solution:
Option B: Bleeding is most likely due to estrogen breakthrough

  • The patient appears to have anovulatory bleeding, which is more common at the start and end of the reproductive age group, post-menarchal and premenopausal age groups.

Anovulation:

  • Absence of ovulation due to immature HPO axis (hypothalamic pituitary ovarian axis).
  • Bleeding is a type of estrogen breakthrough instead of progesterone withdrawal.
  • The absence of ovulation leads to a lack of progesterone.
  • Endometrium keeps building up in response to estrogen and finally due to ischemia, it breaks down resulting in irregular prolonged bleeding.
  • Causes of anovulation include eating disorders, stress, excessive exercise, endocrine disorders like thyroid and diabetes and PCOD.
  • The length of the luteal phase is always fixed at 14 days. The prolonged cycle length is due to a longer follicular phase, as ovulation is delayed or absent.
  • Hormonal therapy with combined or progesterone-only therapy is the first line of management.

 

Option A: Bleeding is likely associated with a missed pelvic pathology, and an MRI should be advised.

  • MRI is not required here as the most likely cause here is an immature HPO axis leading to anovulation, which will not be picked up on MRI. Multiple USG scan have already ruled out any major pelvic pathology.

 

Option C: Oral contraceptives provide no benefit

  • Oral contraceptive pills given in cyclical fashion, will regularize the patient's cycle.

 

Option D: Cycle length increases due to a longer secretory phase

  • The length of luteal phase is always fixed at 14 days, the prolonged cycle length is due to a longer follicular phase as ovulation is delayed or absent.

questions.text: What is the appropriate next step in management for a 14-year-old girl with no first period but normal secondary sexual characteristics ?

choices.text: Reassure and wait for another year

questions.solution:
Option A: Reassure and wait for another year

  • Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menses at the age of 13 years when there is no visible development of secondary sexual characteristics or at age 15 years in the presence of normal secondary sexual characteristics.
  • The commonest cause of primary amenorrhea is a chromosomal abnormality, such as Turner syndrome.
