  • Accelerated growth is the first sign of puberty.
  • The first recognized pubertal change is beast budding, followed by the appearance of pubic hair, peak growth velocity, and menarche.
  • Therefore this patient can safely wait for another year since she has an orderly appearance of secondary sexual characteristics, and evaluation should be done once there is amenorrhea, even by 15 years of age.

Option B: Abdominal ultrasound

  • A pelvic ultrasound is recommended to confirm the presence of a uterus in cases of primary amenorrhea, however, in this case she can wait for another year.

Option C: LH, FSH, estradiol estimation

  • LH and FSH are recommended after the pelvic ultrasound. If the uterus is present, then we can perform LH, FSH and estradiol estimation. A low FSH level indicates hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Increased FSH indicates primary ovarian insufficiency.
  • As the secondary sexual organs are developed so, we can wait for one more year to move on to evaluation.

Option D: Karyotyping

  • Karyotyping can be performed if there is an absence of a uterus to differentiate between androgen insensitivity syndrome and MRKH
  • As the secondary sexual organs are developed so, we can wait for one more year to move on to evaluation in this case.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman who has given birth once (Para 1) visits the Gynecology department three weeks after her delivery. She has been married for two years. Her bleeding had stopped ten days after her delivery. She is currently breastfeeding her newborn and wants to know about the contraceptive options that are suitable for her. What is the recommended mode of contraception for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Progesterone-only pills

  • Progestin-only contraception methods do not impair milk production and are an excellent choice for lactating women. There are no increased risks of the genital tract or breast neoplasia.
  • However, after the initial 4 weeks of delivery, the use of intrauterine contraceptive devices is equally good.
  • OCP contain estrogens which significantly reduce breast milk production and are therefore contraindicated.
  • The relation between birth control and breastfeeding is mentioned below:

 

Option A: IUCD

  • After the initial 4 weeks of delivery are over, the use of intrauterine contraceptive devices is equally good, not before .

Option B: Postpartum sterilization

  • Post partum sterilization is not the preferred option here as the woman has not completed her family.

Option D: OCP

  • OCP contain estrogens which significantly reduce breast milk production and are therefore contraindicated. They are also contraindicated within 6 weeks of pregnancy

questions.text: What is the optimal management for two 4 x 5 cm subserosal fibroids on the uterine fundus that have failed to respond to medical therapy?
questions.solution:
Option C: Myomectomy

  • Myomectomy is the best treatment for such young patients with incomplete families.
  • Recurrent abortions and menorrhagia with failed medical therpy are indications for a surgical treatment
  • Advantages of laparoscopic myomectomy:
    • This procedure easily removes type 5,6,7 fibroids
    • Less blood Loss
    • Shorter hospital stays in comparison to open myomectomy.
    • Earlier Recovery
    • Criteria
      • 3-4 fibroids of ≤5 cm
      • Single fibroid of 15 cm

Option A: Total abdominal hysterectomy + bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

  • Hysterectomy cannot be considered as the patient's family is not complete

Option B: Myolysis

  • Myolysis is a procedure where muscle fibres of the fibroid are directly lysed with freezing, electrocautery or focussed Ultrasound
  • This is a newer minimally invasive technique of managing fibroids and cause shrinkage of fibroid in size resulting in symptom relief
  • This is however not preferred in women who plan future childbearing as the result of myolysis on reproductive outcome is not yet completely known.

Option D: Uterine artery embolization (UAE)

  • Uterine artery embolization is a minimally invasive procedure to manage uterine fibroids.
  • It consists of embolization of uterine artery and vessels feeding the fibroid with PVC particles under fluoroscopy guidance which ultimately causes shrinkage of fibroids and relief in menorrhagia
  • Uterine embolization may result in compromised blood flow later and may be associated with infertility and placental insufficiency in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to the gynaecology clinic complaining of vaginal bleeding and mild fever. She had a cessation of menstruation 5 years ago. A pelvic exam shows a normal cervix. Her pap smear done 1 month prior was normal. She has no other comorbidities. USG reveals an endometrial thickness of 1mm and atrophic ovaries. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Senile endometritis

  • The most common cause of bleeding in women after menopause is cervical carcinoma, but it is unlikely here as cervix appears normal and paps smear is also normal.
  • Senile endometritis : After menopause, the endometrium changes and loses its resistance. It is not shed repeatedly, which leads to the entrance of infection in the uterus. Post-menopausal endometrial atrophy due to lack of estrogen causes senile endometritis. It is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding in the west.
  • It is most likely here since more common causes here, such as cervical cancer and endometrial cancer have been ruled out.
  • USG reveals the endometrial thickness of 1mm and atrophic ovaries, so endometrial carcinoma is unlikely.

Option A: Carcinoma cervix

  • Carcinoma of the cervix usually presents itself as post-coital bleeding (PCB), prolonged intermenstrual bleeding (IMB) or post-menopausal bleeding (PMB).
  • Post-coital bleeding is a typical feature of carcinoma of the cervix. In the progression of the disease, patients may also present with several distressing symptoms such as incontinence, pain and anaemia due to vaginal bleeding.
  • Pelvic and speculum examination reveals a cervical mass that bleeds, and tissues appear hard and fixed in advanced disease. In this case, pelvic and speculum examination shows a normal cervix with no underlying pathology.
  • Pap smear in cervix carcinoma reveals abnormal cervical cytology and squamous cells at different stages of maturity, also known as dyskaryosis. In the case mentioned above, a pap smear done 1 month back is normal.

Option B: Carcinoma endometrium

  • USG findings suggestive of Endometrial carcinoma in post-menopausal women are;
  1. Endometrial thickness >4mm
  2. Polypoidal endometrial mass
  3. Fluid in the uterine cavity
  • Since endometrial thickness is 1mm, it is the least suggestive of endometrial carcinoma.

Option D: Carcinoma ovary

  • Ovaries are atrophic, so ovarian cancer is unlikely.
  • Ovarian carcinomas present with a variety of clinical manifestations, including;
  1. Increased abdominal size and girth
  2. Abdominal bloating, digestion problems and non specific symptoms
  3. Irregular bleeding
  4. Backache
  5. Urinary symptoms
  • An abdominal and pelvic exam may reveal hard and fixed mass arising from the pelvis.
  • Pelvic mass, presence of ascites and omental deposits are characteristic features.
  • The patient is not presenting with the above mentioned features, and the presence of atrophic ovaries rules out ovarian cancer.

questions.text: An Asian woman aged 35 years with delayed cycles and a history of primary infertility presented to the infertility clinic for an infertility workup. On laparoscopic examination, she has a normal uterus with bilateral enlarged ovaries and normal fallopian tubes; chromotubation shows blue dye spillage; however, she did not give a history of any previous pelvic infection. What is the most probable cause of patient this condition and infertility?
questions.solution:
Option B: Polycystic ovarian syndrome

  • Patient with ovaries that are bulky in size (suggestive of PCOS), and the patient has a history of oligo ovulation as suggested by delayed cycles and infertility.

 

Rotterdam / ESHRE /Androgen excess Society /ASRM criteria

Diagnostic requisites: Any 2 out of 3

  • Anovulation/ oligo-ovulation
  • Hyperandrogenism: clinical or laboratory evidence of androgen excess
  • Polycystic ovaries on USG (20 or more follicles measuring less than 9 mm or ovarian volume of > 10 mL)

Features/ Complications associated with PCOD / PCOS

  1. Obesity
  2. Insulin resistance/hyperinsulinemia
  3. Hyperandrogenaemia
  4. Anovulation
  5. Metabolic X syndrome
  6. Oligomenorrhea
  7. Amenorrhoea

 

Option A: Endometriosis

  • There are no endometriotic cysts or peritoneal implants ruling out the endometriotic cyst. Laparoscopy is the single best investigation of choice for the diagnosis of endometriosis. 

Option C: Ovarian Cyst

  • Ovarian cyst is common and often without symptoms, and they are most of the time harmless and interfere not with fertility. There are no ovarian cysts mentioned and bulky ovaries are due to PCOD and ovarian cysts.

Option D: Tubo-ovarian mass

  • Laparoscopy shows no tubo ovarian mass, also ruled out with free spill from bilateral tubes.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the pediatric department for routine vaccination. After the vaccination, the mother took the baby to the doctor as she noticed the baby's asymmetrically flat head and uneven ears.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this infant?
questions.solution:
Option A: Plagiocephaly

  • Plagiocephaly is a condition in which the head shape is asymmetric in the sagittal or coronal plane that can result from:
    • Asymmetry in the closure of sutures.
    • Asymmetry of brain growth or deformation of the skull.
  • It may be frontal or occipital plagiocephaly.
  • Frontal plagiocephaly is caused by premature fusion of coronal and sphenofrontal sutures characterised by:
    • Unilateral flattening of the forehead
    • Elevation of the ipsilateral orbit and eyebrow
    • Prominent ear on the corresponding side
  • Occipital plagiocephaly is caused by positioning during infancy. It is more common in immobile children or children with a disability. Fusion of lambdoid suture can cause unilateral occipital flattening and bulging of the ipsilateral frontal bone.

Option B: Dolicocephaly

  • A condition in which the head is elongated from front to back in the sagittal plane.
  • Dolicocephaly is due to premature closure of the sagittal suture, which produces a long and narrow head with a cephalic index of less than 75.
  • It is characterised by an increased anterior-posterior diameter of the skull.
  • It is also known as scaphocephaly.
  • It is the most common form of craniosynostosis.

Option C: Brachycephaly

  • A condition in which the head shape is shortened from front to back along the sagittal plane; typically, the back of the skull (occiput) and face is flatter than normal.

Option D: Anencephaly

  • A condition in which a baby is born without the parts of the brain and skull.
  • It is a type of neural tube defect that occurs when the neural tube fails to close at the base of the skull during the third to fourth week of development.

questions.text: A 7-year-old female child presents to the outpatient department with difficulty chewing, teeth grinding, and difficulty in speech for six months. Her mother states that the child has a habit of sucking her thumb all the time. She has protruding front teeth on examination, and her thumb is normal. Which of the following conditions is present in children?
questions.solution:
Option A: Buck teeth

  • In this case, a female child presents to the outpatient department with difficulty in chewing, teeth grinding, and problem speaking for 6 months. Her mother gives a history that the child has a habit of sucking her thumb all the time; even at school, his teachers would stop her from doing, but after some time, she again starts with it. On examination, she has protruding front teeth, and her thumb is normal. This scenario indicates that the child has buck teeth due to thumb sucking.
  • Thumb sucking is common in babies during the first and second years of life. Thumb sucking considers a normal habit, and eventually, it will disappear.
  • But if it persists after the age of 5 years, it can lead to problems. It is considered a sign of insecurity and self-soothing behaviour.
  • In some children, it is deeply associated with neglect, insecurities or loneliness. Treatment includes behavioural therapy, and both positive and negative reinforcements can be used.
  • If habitual this habit does not associated with psychological bearing.
  • Buck teeth which are also known as an overbite, is a misalignment of the teeth. In this condition, the front upper teeth tend to protrude out over the lower teeth. The most common cause of this condition in children is buck teeth which can lead to gum damage, bad appearance, a misaligned bite, and trouble speaking clearly.
Type A
  • Seen in 50% population
  • Whole digit placed inside the mouth and thumb pressing over the palate.
  • Maxillary and mandibular oral contact is maintained.
Type B
  • Seen in 13-24% 
  • Where in the thumb is placed into the cavity and mandibular and maxillary contact is maintained
Type C
  • Seen in 18%
  • Beyond the first joint of thumb placed in the oral cavity, contact with hard palate and maxillary incisors
Type D
  • Seen in 6%
  • Only little portion of thumb is placed in the mouth

 

Option B: Paronychia

  • It is an infection that presents around the fingernail and, in some cases, the toenail. The infected area becomes red, painful, and pus-filled.
  • It is common in children who tend to suck their thumb and bite it.

Option C: Open bite

  • It is a malocclusion in which the teeth are not properly aligned while closing the jaw. The front upper and lower teeth protrude outward, so they don't touch when the mouth is shut.
  • Thumb sucking and tongue thrusting commonly cause open bites in children.

Option D: Cavities

  • It is a condition where the spaces around the hard teeth or the surface become permanently damaged with tiny holes.
  • Cavities are common in children due to various bacterial infections and foods rich in carbohydrates.

questions.text: On day 4 of life, a baby girl was rushed to the emergency of the civil hospital after her mother noticed blood on a diaper while changing it. She looked for diaper rashes or any external injury but found nothing and got anxious. There was no family history of any bleeding disorder. What would be the best approach to such a case?

choices.text: Administration of 10 ml/kg of fresh frozen plasma over 4 hours

questions.solution:
Option C: No specific therapy

Neonatal Vaginal bleeding:

  • Baby girls can have minor vaginal bleeding after 3-5 days of birth, which is normal and also called false menses. Neonatal vaginal bleeding is due to the sudden withdrawal of the mother’s estrogen after birth. It is a transient phenomenon, and blood-tinged, or frankly blood discharge, should not last for more than 3 or 4 days.
  • Neonatal vaginal bleeding always appears in the first week after birth, with its highest frequency on the fifth day of life and must be regarded as a physiologic event.
  • Maternal estrogen diffuses across the placenta into fetal circulation in the uterus. After birth, estrogen levels in the infant fall, resulting in a physiologic vaginal discharge that can be blood-tinged or pink.
  • Usually, no specific therapy is needed as it resolves by itself, but if bleeding lasts longer than one week or appears for the first time after that period, the doctor’s advice should be sought.

Option A: Administration of vitamin K

  • Administration of vitamin K at birth-IM/IV is advised regardless of bleeding. Babies are not born with enough of this vitamin needed for blood to clot normally. After birth, this shot of vitamin K helps prevent babies from becoming vitamin K deficient.
  • Babies who do not get a vitamin K shot at birth are at risk of potentially fatal bleeding called vitamin K deficiency (VKDB). It can cause bruising or bleeding in nearly every organ of the body.
  • Subcutaneous administration of vitamin K is given in symptomatic infants having some bleeding. The parenteral supplement is given in case of late-onset of vitamin K deficiency.

Option B: Investigation for bleeding disorders

  • Indications for investigations of bleeding disorders are
  • Family history of bleeding disorders
  • Any medications, procedures, anomalies in infant
  • Maternal diseases such as ITP, preeclampsia and diabetes
  • Maternal exposure to medications such as aspirin, anticonvulsants, rifampicin and isoniazid
  • Previously affected siblings

Option D: Administration of 10 ml/kg of fresh frozen plasma over 4 hours

  • Common fresh frozen plasma transfusion indications include reconstitution of whole blood for exchange transfusion and treating active bleeding due to DIC, Vitamin K deficiency or liver failure.
  • Infusions of FFP in neonates effectively decrease blood loss associated with extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) or cardiopulmonary bypass.

questions.text: CME is being conducted at a medical college, and all departments are supposed to present a seminar on topics related to maternal and neonatal care. The Department of Pediatrics presents a seminar on the benefits of breast milk. While giving the seminar, they have to inform them about the benefits of the higher lactose content of breast milk. Which of the following should they mention in the benefits?

choices.text: Helps in the deformation of galactocerebrosides
Helps in the absorption of vitamin A
Helps in decreasing the risk of infections
Helps in decreasing the growth of lactobacilli

questions.solution:
Option C: Helps in decreasing the risk of infections

  • Lactose is the main sugar in mammalian milk.
  • 40% of calories in milk are provided solely by lactose.
  • Lactose plays an important role in the following:
  • Promoting healthy gut bacteria lactobacilli
  • Insulin regulation
  • Growth of gut antimicrobial factors
  • Galactose helps in the formation of galactocerebrosides.
  • Lactose helps in the absorption of calcium.

 

  • Breast milk is known to stimulate and support the immune system. Such as, lactoferrin and interleukin 6, 8 and 10. 
  • These proteins help to balance the inflammatory response of the immune system
  • The risk of infections is decreased due to anti-infective substances like:
    • Phagocytic macrophages
    • PABA
    • Lactoferrin
    • Lysozyme
    • Antibodies especially IgA
    • Bifidus factor
    • Glycerol monolaurate (GML) present in breast milk is 200 times higher than in cow's milk, fights harmful bacteria such as Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus subtilis and Clostridium perfringens, and promotes the growth of beneficial bacteria. 

Option A: Helps in the deformation of galactocerebrosides

  • Galactocerebrosides are one of the simplest glycosphingolipids, consisting of a single galactose residue linked.
  • It is a major class of glycolipids in the nervous system.
  • Higher lactose content helps in the formation of galactocerebrosides.

Option B: Helps in the absorption of vitamin A

  • Lactose facilitates the intestinal transport of several minerals, such as 
    • calcium
    • iron 
    • zinc 
    • manganese 
    • cobalt magnesium
    • strontium

Option D: Helps in decreasing the growth of lactobacilli.

  • Lactobacilli are considered good bacteria and have a high potential to produce important metabolites.
  • Lactose helps in promoting healthy gut bacteria lactobacilli

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is being managed in a tertiary care hospital. The pediatrician explained to the resident doctors that the patient had a partially compensated metabolic alkalosis on the arterial blood gas analysis. Her urine chloride was lower than normal, and the administration of IV normal saline improved her condition. Which of the following is the least likely cause of her acid-base derangement?
questions.solution:
Option D. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

  • The case describes a patient who suffered metabolic alkalosis with low urinary chloride that responded to the administration of normal saline. The measurement of urinary chloride is a key diagnostic workup that further reveals the etiologies of metabolic alkalosis and guides further management.
  • The urine levels of chloride [Cl−] are low in patients with metabolic alkalosis resulting from volume depletion. These patients are responsive to the administration of chloride in the form of NaCl or KCl.
  • In contrast, patients who suffer from metabolic alkalosis and have a high urinary chloride are generally resistant to the administration of chloride in the form of NaCl.
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia causes chloride-resistant metabolic alkalosis.
  • In congenital adrenal hyperplasia, the deficiencies of 11β-hydroxylase and 17α-hydroxylase result in the excessive production of mineralocorticoids. This causes hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis (excess of bicarbonate). The unbalanced levels of bicarbonate in plasma are balanced by the increased excretion of chloride in the urine. This causes high urinary chloride levels (as compared to low urinary chloride in this patient), and the condition is resistant to the administration of chloride.

Option A: Vomiting

  • Vomiting results in the loss of gastric contents and secretions that are rich in HCl. The loss of chloride in vomiting causes the kidney to retain chloride, so urinary chloride is low. The condition is sensitive to the administration of fluids containing chloride.

Option B: Cystic fibrosis

  • Cystic fibrosis can result in metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, and hyponatremia because of excessive NaCl losses in sweat. As the Cl is being lost in sweat, so the kidneys will decrease the excretion of chloride resulting in low urine chloride. The condition is responsive to the administration of chloride-containing fluids.

Option C: Post hypercapnia syndrome

  • Post hypercapnic syndrome (characterized by metabolic alkalosis) happens after the correction of chronic respiratory acidosis.
  • This is typically seen in patients with chronic lung pathology who are treated with mechanical ventilation.
  • During chronic respiratory acidosis, appropriate renal compensation leads to an increase in the serum [HCO3−]. Because it is still present after acute correction of the respiratory acidosis, this [HCO3−] causes metabolic alkalosis. The metabolic alkalosis persists because the patient with chronic respiratory acidosis is intravascularly depleted because of the Cl− loss that occurred during the initial metabolic compensation for the primary respiratory acidosis. This chloride loss causes low urinary chloride and is responsive to correction by the administration of chloride-rich fluids.

questions.text: A 2.5-year-old female child was admitted to the pediatric ward with complaints of abdominal distension and failure to thrive. She is a product of a consanguineous marriage. The patient has a history of afebrile seizures. On examination, the patient has hepatomegaly and splenomegaly without jaundice. Laboratory investigations reveal fasting blood glucose of 30 mg/dl and normal blood lactate and uric acid. SGOT and SGPT are increased. Intravenous glucagon given after a meal increases blood glucose levels. The glucagon challenge test increased random blood glucose levels but not fasting blood sugar levels. A liver biopsy was performed, which showed fat in the liver. Which enzyme is most likely defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option D: Debranching enzyme

  • The described clinical situation points to Type III glycogen storage disorder brought on by a deficiency of the debranching enzyme.
  • GSD III, also known as Cori disease, is characterised by varying involvement of the liver, heart muscle, and skeletal muscle.
  • Amylo-1,6-glucosidase and 1,4-alpha-glucanotransferase are the debranching enzyme's active (catalytic) sites. Deficiency of this enzyme will result in an insufficient amount of energy/glucose, producing partial glycogen broken down. The remaining structure resembles a "limit dextrin" molecule and is overly retained in the liver and (skeletal and cardiac) muscle tissues.
  • Hepatomegaly and failure to thrive are symptoms of liver involvement in infancy and early childhood, together with fasting ketotic hypoglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and increased hepatic transaminases.
  • Liver involvement becomes less noticeable as people get older. Cardiomyopathy and cardiac hypertrophy characterise the majority of cases of cardiac involvement. Skeletal myopathy, which causes weakness, can appear as early as childhood. It usually becomes noticeable in the third or fourth decade.
  • Biallelic pathogenic mutations in AGL are used to confirm the diagnosis of GSD III in a proband. Debranching enzyme activity can be assessed in blood cells (leukocytes or erythrocytes), skin fibroblasts, liver or muscle biopsy, or skin fibroblasts if molecular genetic testing is equivocal.
  • The major form of treatment is still dietary control customised for each patient. Infancy requires frequent feeding (every 3–4 hours) to maintain euglycemia.
  • Only those with severe hepatic cirrhosis, liver dysfunction, and liver malignancy should have a transplant (hepatocellular carcinoma).

Other options

Option A: Glucose-6-phosphatase

  • Deficiency of glucose 6 phosphate results in type 1 GSD, also known as Von Gierke disease.
  • Clinical signs include severe fasting hypoglycemia, glycogen buildup in the liver and kidneys, elevated blood lactate, triglycerides, uric acid, hepatomegaly and nephromegaly.
  • Treatment consists of taking glucose/cornstarch regularly and avoiding fructose and galactose.

Option B: Muscle Phosphorylase

  • McArdle disease (type V GSD) occurs due to myophosphorylase deficiency (Skeletal muscle glycogen phosphorylase).
  • Disease results in glycogen accumulation in muscle, painful muscle cramps, myoglobinuria with strenuous exercise, and electrolyte abnormalities resulting in arrhythmias.
  • The disease does not typically affect blood sugar levels.

Option C: Branching enzyme

  • Andersen disease (type IV GSD) is due to a deficiency of the Branching enzyme that generates α-1,6-glucosidic branches.
  • The disease commonly presents in early infancy with hepatosplenomegaly and failure to thrive. Other findings include muscular weakness, hypotonia, infantile cirrhosis, cardiomyopathy early childhood death.
  • Hypoglycemia occurs late in the disease.

questions.text: A 20-day-old male boy presented to the emergency department with hypocalcemic seizures. Further examination revealed esophageal atresia, and radiography revealed a right-sided aortic arch. The doctor suspects him of a case of microdeletion of DNA sequence from chromosome 22q11.2. Which of the following features is found in this scenario?

choices.text: Failure of development of 3rd and 4th Pharyngeal pouches

questions.solution:
Option A: Failure of development of 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches

  • This patient is a case of DiGeorge syndrome with 22q11 microdeletion.
  • The failure to develop third and fourth pharyngeal pouches leads to hypoplastic thymus and parathyroids.
  • It is autosomal dominant.
Disease Primary defect Secondary defect
DiGeorge Syndrome
  • 22q11 deletion
  • Failure of development of 3rd & 4th pharyngeal pouches
  • T-cell defect (due to thymic hypoplasia)
  • Tetany (due to parathyroid hypoplasia)
  • Congenital defects of the heart and great vessels (due to ultimo-branchial body defect)
  • Mucocutaneous candidiasis

Option B: Eczema

  • Eczema is not a feature of DiGeorge syndrome.
  • Eczema, recurrent infections, and thrombocytopenia are features of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

Option C: Thrombocytopenia

  • Thrombocytopenia is not a feature of DiGeorge syndrome.
  • Eczema, recurrent infections, and thrombocytopenia are features of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

Option D: Absence of B-cells.

  • DiGeorge syndrome is the failure of third and fourth pharyngeal pouches, leading to thymic hypoplasia.
  • Due to the lack of thymic hypoplasia, T-cells are absent.
  • The absence of T-cells leads to recurrent infections.

questions.text: What diagnosis can be considered for a 6-year-old who has received multiple blood transfusions since the age of 7 months and whose blood smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia, target cells, and decreased osmotic fragility?
questions.solution:
Option B: Beta Thalassemia

  • Peripheral smear findings of microcytic hypochromic anaemia with the target cell and reduced osmotic fragility with severe transfusion requiring anaemia suggest Beta-thalassemia.
  • Beta thalassemia is an acquired blood problem where the body doesn't make as much beta-globin as it ought to.
  • Beta globin and alpha globin are building blocks of haemoglobin.
  • Haemoglobin is a piece of red platelet (RBC) that conveys oxygen all through the body.
  • Its treatment involves multiple blood transfusions.

Classification:

  • Thalassemia trait:
    • Heterozygous state - Mild Anemia (HbA2≥ 3.5%).
  • Thalassemia intermediate(β0/β+):
  • Moderate anaemia, Hepatosplenomegaly, HbF elevated.
  • Thalassemia major(β0/β0):
    • Homozygous, severe anaemia, Hepatosplenomegaly, HbF markedly elevated, require regular transfusions.

Clinical features:

  • Hemolytic facies
  • Hepatosplenomegaly

Investigation:

  • Microcytosis (Low MCV)
  • Hypochromia (low MCH)
  • Targeting of the red cells
  • Nucleated red cells
  • Marked anisopoikilocytosis
  • Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia
  • Elevated LDH
  • Reduced osmotic fragility
  • Lateral x-ray skull- Hair on end appearance or crew-cut appearance.

Option A: Alpha thalassemia

  • Doesn't present with severe anaemia requiring frequent transfusion.
  • Occur most commonly in Southeast Asia

Option C: Sickle cell anaemia

  • Sickle cell anaemia is a disease in which red blood cells are sickled-shaped.
  • The question does not mention features of sickle cell crisis like hand-foot syndrome/ priapism.

Option D: G6PD deficiency

  • G6PD is also a hereditary disease.
  • No history of oxidative stress is mentioned in the question.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the office with a slow-growing mass on the tip of his nose for the last one year. The nose has a pink, lobulated, and nontender swelling on examination. There is no nasal discharge or bleeding from the mass. His picture is shown below. Which of the following is true about his condition?

choices.text: Benign hyperplasia of sebaceous glands is seen
An argon laser can be used for the treatment

questions.solution:
Option C: Associated with acne

  • Rhinophyma is often seen in cases of long-standing acne rosacea.
  • Rhinophyma or potato tumour is a slow-growing benign tumour due to hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands of the tip of the nose.
  • It is often seen in cases of long-standing acne rosacea.
  • It presents as a pink, lobulated mass over the nose with superficial vascular dilation.
  • It mostly affects men past middle age.
  • The patient seeks advice because of the unsightly appearance of the nose or obstruction to breathing and vision due to the large tumour size.
  • Treatment consists of paring down the bulk of the tumour with a sharp knife or carbon dioxide laser and the area allowed to re-epithelialize.
  • Sometimes, the tumour is completely excised, and the raw area skin is grafted.

Option A: Also known as tomato tumour

  • Because of bulbous nose enlargement, Rhinophyma is also called a potato tumour, not a tomato tumour.

Option B: Benign hyperplasia of sebaceous glands is seen

  • This patient has Rhinophyma caused by the benign hypertrophy of sebaceous glands, not hyperplasia.

Option D: An argon laser can be used for the treatment

  • Rhinophyma is treated with a carbon dioxide laser.
  • Argon laser is mostly used in retinal surgeries.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male comes to the clinic with a complaint of otalgia for 7 days. The patient also has a history of progressive hearing loss for 10 years. On examination, you found that there is no clear ear pathology for the pain. So, you are thinking about referred otalgia. Which of the following will be the differential diagnosis of this scenario?
questions.solution:
Option D: Carcinoma oral cavity

  • This is a case of carcinoma of the oral cavity in which the patient presents with complaints of otalgia for 7 days. He also has progressive hearing loss.
  • There is no clear pathology of ear pain on examination.
  • Carcinoma of the larynx, stygian, and carcinoma of the oral cavity can be presented with a referred earache. This pain is felt in the ear, and typically patient presents with an earache, although the source of pain is somewhere else. This usually happens when the organ from where the pain is originating shares the same nerve supply as the organ where the pain is referred.
  • The larynx is supplied by the vagus, which also supplies the ear.
  • The tongue and oral cavity are supplied by the lingual branch of the mandibular, Glossopharyngeal, and vagus, all of which also supply the ear.
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve passes near the styloid process. In the case of stygian, it is the cause of referred otalgia.

Option A: Acute otitis media

  • In acute otitis media, the patient typically presents with complaints of fever, pain and earache for less than 2 weeks.
  • The otoscopy is usually normal or the tympanic membrane is retracted.

Option B: Otitis externa

  • Otitis externa is an infection of the external ear.
  • Its clinal features include pain and itching around the ear pinna.

Option C: Chronic otitis media

  • The chronic otitis media is a chronic infection of the middle ear.
  • In this disease, the otoscopy usually reveals perforated tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents in the ENT clinic with complaints of decreased hearing, recurrent ear infections, and foul-smelling ear discharge. On examination, pale skin-lined granulation tissue is present behind the tympanic membrane. He is diagnosed as having cholesteatoma. Which structures are at immediate risk of damage by this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: The long process of the incus

  • The long process of the incus is one of the structures that are at immediate risk of erosion.
  • Ossicular necrosis is a common in atticoantral disease.
  • The destruction may be limited to the long process of incus or may also involve the stapes superstructure, the handle of the malleus, or sometimes the entire ossicular chain.
  • Therefore, hearing loss in Cholesteatoma is always greater than in a disease of tubotympanic type.
  • Occasionally, the Cholesteatoma bridges the gap caused by the destroyed ossicles, and hearing loss is not apparent (cholesteatoma hearer).
  • Structures immediately at risk of erosion are:
    • The long process of the incus.
    • Fallopian canal containing facial nerve.
    • Horizontal/lateral semicircular canal.

Option B: Round window

  • The round window is not included in the structures that are immediately affected by Cholesteatoma.

Option C: Eustachian tube

  • One of the causes of Cholesteatoma is Eustachian tube blockage, although the Eustachian tube is not included in the structures immediately affected by Cholesteatoma.

Option D: Base Plate of Stapes

  • Cholesteatoma can invade the supra structures of stapes but not its base plate.

questions.text: A 55-years-old male presents to the physician with complaints of subtle weakness of his right lower face for 2 weeks, which he first noted while brushing his teeth. He also complains that he can no longer close his right eyelid fully, and he has increasing weakness in the remainder of his right face. Which of the following is the first nerve branch involved in this pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Greater Petrosal Nerve

  • The case discussed is facial nerve palsy and the first branch of the facial nerve- The greater superficial petrosal nerve.
  • First motor branch of the facial nerve- Nerve to stapedius.
  • First embryological branch of the facial nerve- Chorda tympani.

 

Greater Superficial Petrosal Nerve

Secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland and the glands of nasal mucosa and palate

Nerve to Stapedius

Stapedius muscle

Chorda Tympani Nerve

Secretomotor fibers to submandibular and sublingual glands and brings taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue

Communicating Branch

Concha, retro auricular groove, posterior meatus, and the outer surface of the tympanic membrane

Posterior Auricular Nerve

Muscles of pinna, occipital belly of occipitofrontalis

Muscular Branches

Stylohyoid and posterior belly of digastric

Peripheral Branches- 2 Divisions:

Upper temporofacial & lower cervicofacial

All muscles of facial expression

(Temporal, zygomatic, buccal, mandibular and cervical)

Branches of the facial nerve:

Option B: Lesser petrosal Nerve

  • It is a false statement.
  • The lesser petrosal nerve is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve. So, according to this case, it is an incorrect answer.

Option C: Chorda tympani nerve

  • It is a false statement.
  • Chorda tympani nerve is the first embryological branch of the facial nerve, so according to this case, it is an incorrect option.

Option D: Nerve to stapedius

  • It is a false statement.
  • The nerve to the stapedius is the first motor branch of the facial nerve. So, according to this case, it is an incorrect answer.

questions.text: A 3-year-old, well-immunized boy was brought to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of sore throat, high-grade fever, and noisy breathing with an inability to swallow for the past four hours. The physical examination showed a toxic, tachypnoeic child with inspiratory stridor. There is suprasternal, supraclavicular, and intercostal recession during inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Acute Epiglottitis

  • It is a case of Acute epiglottitis. The child is well immunized; however, he presents with a high-grade fever, sore throat, and inability to swallow (dysphagia). The examination findings, such as inspiratory stridor and toxic look with respiratory difficulties, support the diagnosis of acute epiglottitis.
  • Epiglottitis is an acute infection of the supraglottis characterized by inflammation of the supraglottic structures.
  • Historically the most common causative organism was Haemophilus influenza type b.
  • TREATMENT:

 

  1. Systemic Antibiotics
  2. Systemic corticosteroids
  3. Nebulization with Adrenaline

Option A: Acute Laryngo-tracheobronchitis

  • It has a similar presentation, but odynophagia and dysphagia are usually absent.
  • The patient presents a croupy cough (barking seal-like cough) and hoarseness.
  • The fever is usually low-grade or absent.

Option C: Diphtheria

  • Diphtheria is ruled out as the child is well immunized, even though he has the symptoms.
  • The presence of a tough pseudomembrane over the larynx and trachea is a differentiating factor not seen in this patient.

Option D: Bronchopneumonia

  • Bronchopneumonia will not have inspiratory stridor. In addition, the patient will not show an inability to swallow and stridor due to involvement of the lower respiratory tract only.

questions.text:
A 1-day old child is brought to the pediatrics emergency with respiratory distress and cyanosis for the past few hours. His cyanosis improves on crying. An endoscopy of the nose is done, and the following endoscopic picture is obtained:



Which of the following is not true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: Occur due to persistence of Bucco nasal membrane
Bilateral usually presents with respiratory difficulties

questions.solution:
Option C: 10% Bony & 90% Membranous

Choanal Atresia is 90% Bony & 10% Membranous.

Choanal atresia:

  • Choanal atresia is a congenital condition involving occlusion of the posterior choanae in the nasal cavity by bone, soft tissue, or both.
  • Complete nasal obstruction in a newborn may cause death from asphyxia.
  • During attempted inspiration, the tongue is pulled to the palate, and obstruction of the oral airway results.
  • Vigorous respiratory efforts produce marked chest retraction. Increased cyanosis and death may occur if appropriate treatments are not available; however, if the infant cries and takes a breath through the mouth, the airway obstruction is momentarily relieved.
  • Then the crying stops, the mouth closes, and the cycle of obstruction is repeated. Treatment for choanal atresia can be divided into emergent and elective definitive categories.
  • Bilateral choanal atresia in a neonate is an emergency that is best initially treated by inserting an oral airway to break the seal formed by the tongue against the palate.
  • This oral airway can be well tolerated for several weeks.

Option A: Occur due to persistence of Bucco nasal membrane

  • Choanal atresia results due to the persistence of Bucco nasal membrane.
  • It is characterized by respiratory distress and cyanosis which improves with crying.

Option B: Bilateral usually presents with respiratory difficulties

  • Bilateral choanal atresia can block the nasal cavity which results in severe respiratory distress.

Option D: Bilateral is treated by surgery

  • Bilateral choanal atresia is an emergency and treated by surgery

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the hospital for the follow-up of his diagnosis of Potts puffy tumor. You and your senior resident are planning for the resection of the tumor. In the nasal endoscopy, the endoscope is guided through an elevation, anterior to the middle turbinate. Your senior resident questions you, "what is that elevation?"
questions.solution:
Option C: Agger Nasi Cells

  • It is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate.
  • It is also called the nasoturbinal concha and the nasal ridge.
  • In 90% of patients, an anterior ethmoidal cell (called the "agger nasi cell") can be found in the lacrimal bone below the Agger Nasi ridge, which communicates with the frontal recess.
  • An enlarged agger nasi cell may encroach on the frontal recess area, constricting it and causing mechanical obstruction to frontal sinus drainage.

Option A: Haller Cells

  • Haller cells are air cells situated on the roof of the maxillary sinus. They are pneumatized from anterior or posterior ethmoid cells.
  • Enlargement of Haller cells encroaches on ethmoid infundibulum, impeding draining of maxillary sinus.

Option B: Onodi Cells

  • Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal cell that may grow posteriorly by the side of the sphenoid sinus or superior to it for as much distance as 1.5 cm from the anterior surface of the sphenoid.
  • Onodi cell is surgically important as the optic nerve may be related to its lateral wall.

Option D: Bullae Ethmoidalis

  • Bullae Ethmoidalis: Most prominent and the largest anterior ethmoidal cell. It is posterior to the frontal recess and later enclosed by the lamina papyracea. It forms the roof of the middle meatus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of nasal bleed 20 minutes ago. He was working in a garden when he suddenly experienced such gush of blood from the nasal cavity. He tried to stop bleed with nasal pressure but bleeding continues. An endoscopy has been ordered. Endoscopy shows bleeding in the woodruff area. Which of the following describes the location of Woodruff's plexus?
questions.solution:
Option C: Posteroinferior part of the nose

Woodruff's Plexus:

  • A nosebleed (epistaxis) usually occurs in the anterior part of the nose from an area known as Kiesselbach's plexus which consists of arteries.
  • Woodruff's plexus is a venous plexus in the posterior part and a nosebleed here accounts for only between 5 and 10 per cent of nosebleeds.
  • Older adults are most often affected.
  • Posterior nasal packing is needed for posterior epistaxis.

Option A: Anterosuperior part of the nose

  • Woodruff's plexus is a plexus of veins situated inferior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate.
  • It is a site of posterior epistaxis in adults.

Option B: Anteroinferior part of the nose

  • Woodruff's plexus is a plexus of veins situated inferior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate not on the anteroinferior turbinate.

Option D: Posterosuperior part of the nose

  • The Woodruff's plexus which is a site for the posterior nasal bleed is located below the posterior end of the inferior concha, on the lateral wall of the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A newborn girl baby who was delivered 14 hours before is brought to the neonatology department with bilateral watery secretions from her eyes, suggesting Ophthalmia neonatorum. This type of Ophthalmia neonatorum presenting within 24 hours of birth is most likely due to which of the following possible cause?
questions.solution:
Option A: Chemical inoculation

Chemical conjunctivitis:

  • Time of onset of chemical conjunctivitis: Immediately after birth, within the first 4-6 hours.

Ophthalmia Neonatorum

  • Bilateral conjunctival inflammation in a neonate in the first 30 days of life.
  • CAUSES :
    • BACTERIAL
      • Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes D to K (neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis)
      • Neisseria gonorrhoeae
      • Haemophilus species
      • Streptococcus pneumoniae
      • Staphylococcus aureus
    • VIRAL
      • Adenovirus
      • Herpes simplex II virus (HSV)
    • CHEMICAL CONJUNCTIVITIS
      • Crede's solution
      • Silver nitrate or antibiotics used for the prevention
  • ​​​​​SIGNS :
    • Conjunctival discharge: mildly sticky in staphylococcal infection, watery in chemical and HSV infection, mucoid or mucopurulent in neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis, purulent in other bacterial infections, hyper-purulent in gonococcal infection.
    • Conjunctiva shows hyperemia and chemosis.
    • Eyelids are usually swollen.
    • Corneal involvement may occur in herpes simplex ophthalmia neonatorum in the form of superficial punctate keratitis, dendritic ulcer or geographical ulcer.
    • Ulceration with rapid progression can be seen in gonococcal infection.
    • Others:
      • Eyelid or periocular vesicles can be seen in HSV.
      • Pseudomembranes in chlamydial infection.
      • Delayed nasolacrimal duct canalization.​​​​​​​
  • Time of Onset
    • Chemical: Within 4-6 hours
    • N. Gonorrhea: 2-4 days
    • Staphylococcus, H. influenzae, Streptococcus, Enterococcus: 2-5 days
    • Viral: within one week
    • C. Trachomatis: 1-3 weeks

​​​​​​​

Option B: Herpes simplex

  • It can cause conjunctivitis but usually after the 3 weeks.

Option C: Staphylococcus

  • Staphylococcus causes conjunctivitis between 2-5 days after the birth.

Option D: Neisseria gonorrhoea

  • It causes conjunctivitis between 2-5 days after birth.
  • Presents with mucopurulent discharge.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of double vision following head trauma 1 week ago. He is standing on a stool to change a light bulb in the kitchen when he loses his balance, falls to the tiled kitchen floor, and strikes his head. He lost consciousness for less than 1 minute. He noticed diplopia immediately upon awakening. He presents to the hospital for evaluation. Cranial nerve examination reveals nerve palsy. Which feature is not seen in this patient with this nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Option C. Ipsilateral chin lift

Ipsilateral chin lift is not typically a feature observed in a patient with double vision following head trauma and nerve palsy. The other options (unilateral head tilt, blepharoptosis, and hypertropia of the affected eye) are potential features associated with nerve palsy and resulting diplopia:

Option A: Unilateral head tilt: This can occur when the patient tilts their head to align their eyes properly and reduce double vision.

Option B: Blepharoptosis: Ptosis, or drooping of the upper eyelid, is common in cases of nerve palsy. It can affect the position of the eye and contribute to double vision.

Option D: Hypertropia of the affected eye: This refers to the upward deviation of the affected eye, causing vertical misalignment and double vision in some cases.

Ipsilateral chin lift, where the patient lifts their chin to align their eyes, is not a typical compensatory mechanism seen in cases of nerve palsy-induced diplopia. Patients usually adopt head tilting or other positional adjustments to alleviate double vision.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of seeing spots floating around in her eye. Now she notes streaks of light in the same eye accompanied by a shadow in her peripheral vision that moves up and down. Her past medical history is significant for migraine headaches, but she has never had such visual symptoms with her headaches. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Retinal detachment

  • In the above-given case, the floaters, streak of light with shadow, and past history of migraine suggest retinal detachment.
  • The vitreous detaches from the retina and causes the perception of "floaters."
  • Vitreous disassociating from the retina can cause a peripheral "horseshoe" tear in sensitive areas of the retina.
  • This tear allows fluid in the vitreous to collect under the retina and causes a detachment.
  • When the retina is partially detached and the eye moves, the patient might see a shadow" corresponding to the torn retina.
  • Retinal detachment is an ophthalmic emergency because the detachment can progress to the fovea and threaten central vision.
  • Types of retinal detachment:
    • Rhegmatogenous, also called primary RD, occurs due to a full break in the thickness of the sensory retina
    • Non-rhegmatogenous, also called secondary RD.it is further divided into
      • Tractional RD
      • Exudative RD

Option A: Ophthalmic migraine

  • It is an eye condition that causes brief attacks of blindness or visual problems like flashing lights in 1 eye.
  • Common triggers are bright lights, flashes of light, and skipping meals.

Option B: Malingering

  • It is a profound exaggeration of the disease.
  • Compensation or conscious behavior are the main features of malingering or simulation.
  • It is done by covering the infected eye and bisecting the healthy eye with a base of a strong prism lens, and then the infected eye opens quickly.

Option D: Amaurosis fugax

  • A person cannot see from one or both eyes due to transient failure of blood supply to the retina.
  • It is seen in branch retinal vein occlusion.

questions.text: A 23-year-old girl presents to eye OPD with the complaint of defective vision due to progressive myopia for the last 3 months. She also reports that her soft contact lenses, which were bought only 6 months back, are causing blurring of vision. Her visual acuity is 6/18 in one eye with a refraction of – 7.0/+3.5 X145. Her Slit lamp examination may show thinning and ectasia of the central cornea, opacity at the apex, Fleischer's ring at the base of the cone, and folds in Descemet's and Bowman's membranes. What could be the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Keratoconus

  • Features of blurred vision despite using full correction for myopia and slit lamp examination findings of thinning and ectasia of the central cornea, opacity at the apex and Fleischer's ring at the base of the cone suggest the girl has keratoconus.
  • The girl suffers from keratoconus, which soft contact lenses can no longer control.
  • Keratoconus is more commonly seen in female patients and refers to the abnormal protrusion of the cornea.
  • Clinical features: The patient presents with defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism, which does not improve fully despite full correction with glasses.
  • The following signs may be elicited:
    • The window reflex is distorted.
    • Placido disc examination shows irregularity of the circles.
    • Keratometry depicts extreme misalignment.
    • Photokeratoscopy reveals distortion of circles.
  • Slit lamp examination may show thinning and ectasia of the central cornea, opacity at the apex and Fleischer's ring at the base of the cone, and folds in Descemet's and Bowman's membranes. Very fine, vertical, deep stromal striae (Vogt lines), which disappear with external pressure on the globe, are peculiar features.
  • A yawning reflex (scissor reflex) and the high oblique or irregular astigmatism are obtained on retinoscopy.
  • On distant direct ophthalmoscopy, an annular dark shadow (due to total internal reflection of light) separates the central and peripheral areas of the cornea (oil droplet reflex).
  • Munson's sign i.e. localized bulging of the lower lid when the patient looks down, is positive in the late stages.

Option A: Nuclear cataract

  • It is an opacity or clouding that develops in the lens nucleus.
  • A nuclear cataract is located in the center of the lens.
  • A nuclear cataract is unlikely to occur in a 23-year-old, as it is mostly seen in older adults.

Option B: Dry eye

  • A dry eye occurs when the eyes don't make enough tears to stay wet.
  • It also happens when tears don't work correctly.
  • This can make the eyes feel uncomfortable and, in some cases, also cause vision problems.
  • It is unlikely to occur in a 23-year-old, as it is mostly seen in older adults.

Option D: Irregular astigmatism

  • It usually occurs in conditions leading to cornea scarring, and no such history is given.
  • It is similar to regular astigmatism in that the curvature of an eye's surface is not perfectly round, but where it differs is that instead of curvature being evenly shaped (mostly in one direction), it is uneven or curved in multiple directions.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to ophthalmology OPD for an eye checkup with complaints of pain, photophobia, decreased visual acuity, and some redness for 4 days. The general physical examination was unremarkable. On ocular examination, vitreous floaters, edema of the retina, and choroid are observed by the ophthalmologist. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Posterior uveitis:

  • Based on the clinical findings given in the scenario, the most likely diagnosis is posterior uveitis.
  • It refers to inflammation of a choroid (choroiditis). There is always association.
  • Inflammation of the retina and hence the term 'chorioretinitis’ is used.
  • The typical symptoms of posterior uveitis include the presence of 'floaters' with or without a diminution of vision, which is often painless but occasionally accompanied by pain, photophobia, and some redness if there is associated involvement of the anterior segment.
  • Signs include:
  • Detectable inflammatory cells and opacities in the vitreous, exudates or infiltration in the retina or choroid, edema of the retina and choroid, and sheathing of vessels.
  • Micropsia.
  • Macropsia.
  • Positive scotoma.
  • Treatment:
    • Non-specific therapy consists of topical and systemic corticosteroids.
    • Posterior sub-tenon injections of depot corticosteroids effectively check the acute phase of posterior uveitis.
    • Rarely, immunosuppressive agents may be required to check the inflammation.
    • Specific treatment is required for the causative disease such as toxoplasmosis, toxocariasis, tuberculosis, syphilis, etc.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Conjunctivitis:

  • Inflammation of the conjunctiva (conjunctivitis) is classically defined as conjunctival hyperemia associated with a discharge that may be watery, mucoid, mucopurulent, or purulent.
  • Etiological classification.
  • Infective conjunctivitis: bacterial, chlamydial, viral, fungal, rickettsial, spirochetal, protozoal, parasitic, etc.
  • Allergic conjunctivitis.
  • Irritative conjunctivitis.
  • Keratoconjunctivitis is associated with diseases of the skin and mucous membrane.
  • Traumatic conjunctivitis.
  • Keratoconjunctivitis of unknown etiology.

Option B - Keratitis:

  • Keratitis is the inflammation of the cornea, and it is characterized by corneal oedema, cellular infiltration, and ciliary congestion. It is classified as.
  • Topographical (morphological) classification:
    • Ulcerative keratitis (corneal ulcer.
    • Non-ulcerative keratitis.
  • Etiological classification:
    • Infective keratitis.
    • Allergic keratitis.
    • Trophic keratitis.
    • Keratitis is associated with diseases of the skin and mucous membranes.
    • Keratitis associated with systemic collagen vascular disorders.
    • Traumatic keratitis.
    • Idiopathic keratitis.

Option C - Anterior Uveitis:

  • Though anterior uveitis almost always presents as a combined inflammation of the iris and ciliary body, the reaction may be more marked in the iris or ciliary body. Clinically it may present as acute or chronic anterior uveitis. The main symptoms of acute anterior uveitis are pain, photophobia, redness, lacrimation, and decreased vision. In chronic uveitis, however, the eye may be white with minimal symptoms, even signs of severe inflammation.
  • Clinical Features are as under:
    • Pain.
    • Redness.
    • Photophobia and blepharospasm.
    • Lacrimation.
    • Defective vision.
  • The following signs can be observed:
    • Lid edema.
    • Circumcorneal congestion.
    • Corneal edema.
    • Keratic precipitate.
    • Posterior corneal opacities.
    • Anterior chamber signs.
    • Aqueous cells.
    • Aqueous flare.
    • Hyphema

questions.text: A thirteen year old girl is brought to your clinic by her mother. The girl's childhood has been complicated with developmental delays and a learning disability. Currently, she presents with decreased vision. Eye examination revealed lens subluxation. She is admitted to the hospital for further testing. Blood tests show an increased level of homocysteine. In the patient's condition, the lens is subluxated in which direction?
questions.solution:
Option B: Inferonasal

  • Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism.

  • It is characterised by elevated levels of homocysteine in blood and urine due to the body's inability to break it down.

  • Symptoms include:

    • Lens dislocation

    • Developmental problems

    • Chest deformities

    • Scoliosis

  • Subluxation of the lens is the partial displacement of the lens from its position.

  • Common causes of subluxation of the lens include:

    • Trauma

    • Marfan syndrome

    • Homocystinuria

    • Weill-Marchesani syndrome

  • Examinations findings show a golden crescent on focal illumination and a dark line (due to total internal reflection) on distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

  • In homocystinuria, the lens is usually subluxated downwards and nasally.

Option A: Inferotemporal

  • The patient's signs and symptoms suggest a diagnosis of homocystinuria.

  • In homocystinuria, the lens is subluxated in an inferonasal direction.

  • Other directions of subluxation may be seen in patients with Marfan syndrome.

Option C: Superonasal

  • The patient's signs and symptoms suggest a diagnosis of homocystinuria.

  • In homocystinuria, the lens is subluxated in an inferonasal direction.

  • Other directions of subluxation may be seen in patients with Marfan syndrome.

Option D: Superotemporal

  • This type of subluxation is common in Marfan syndrome.

  • But other directions can also occur.

  • The patient's signs and symptoms suggest a diagnosis of homocystinuria.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents to the emergency department after she had a hit in the face with a metal instrument. She is otherwise vitally stable. And other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. On examination, a right facial laceration and contusion were noted. On examination, a fracture of the right inferior orbital rim with an associated fluid level in the maxillary sinus and significant soft tissue swelling was seen. Which of the following is true about the bone fractured in this case?

choices.text: Formed by maxillary and zygomatic bones
Infraorbital foramen is about 5 cm from orbital rim
It transmits trigeminal nerves and vessels

questions.solution:
Option A: Formed by maxillary and zygomatic bones

  • The inferior walls of the orbit are formed by three bones:
    • Maxilla,
    • Zygomatic bone
    • Palatine bone
  • This is a case of facial trauma in which a female patient presents to the emergency department after she had a hit in the face with a metal instrument. On examination, a right facial laceration and contusion were noted. On examination, a fracture of the right inferior orbital rim with an associated fluid level in the maxillary sinus and significant soft tissue swelling was seen.
  • Inferior walls of the orbit transmit infraorbital nerves and vessels.
  • The floor, or inferior wall, separates the orbit and the maxillary sinus.
  • Inferior margin of orbit.
    • Formed of maxilla & zygomatic bones.
    • It transmits infraorbital branch of maxillary nerves and vessels.

Option B: Infraorbital foramen is about 5 cm from the orbital rim

  • Infraorbital foramen is about 5 mm from orbital rim.
  • The orbital rim is the base of the orbit.

​​​​​​Option C: It transmits trigeminal nerves and vessels

  • Inferior walls of the orbit transmit infraorbital nerves and vessels.

Option D: Circular in shape

  • Inferior walls of orbit are not circular in shape.
  • It is triangular in shape.

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient came with pain and watering in the right eye for 24 hours. On examination, a 3×2 cm corneal ulcer is seen with elevated margins, feathery hyphae, finger-like projections and minimal hypopyon in the cornea. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Option B: Aspergillosis

  • This patient presents with features of fungal keratitis.
  • The most common fungi (in India) to cause corneal ulcer is Aspergillus fumigatus.
  • Patients with aspergillomas may present with facial pain or symptoms secondary to chronic sinusitis. Invasive aspergillosis patients may present acutely or over a period of weeks to months and may report a wide range of symptoms, including naso-orbital pain, headache, proptosis, epistaxis, and worsening vision.

Option A: HSV-1

  • Herpes simplex eye infections are a potentially serious type of eye infection. They're caused by a virus called herpes simplex – usually the herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1), which also causes cold sores.

Option C: Acanthamoeba

  • Acanthamoeba keratitis is a rare but serious infection of the eye that can result in permanent visual impairment or blindness. This infection is caused by a microscopic, free-living amoeba (single-celled living organism) called Acanthamoeba. Acanthamoeba causes keratitis when it infects the transparent outer covering of the eye called the cornea. Acanthamoeba amebas are very common in nature and can be found in bodies of water (for example, lakes and oceans), soil, and air.

Option D: Pseudomonas

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative rod. It is an opportunistic human pathogen known to cause a variety of infectious diseases. In the eye, P. aeruginosa is a common cause of bacterial keratitis, particularly in contact lens wearers. It is known to be particularly virulent, with pseudomonas keratitis being more difficult to treat and having a worse prognosis than other forms of bacterial keratitis. P. aeruginosa secretes proteases that can cause liquefactive necrosis of the cornea, leading to rapid corneal weakening and perforation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with progressive difficulty comprehending familiar faces, such as coworkers. He is not showing any weakness, parkinsonism, or bulbar symptoms. There is no family history of any significant illness, and there is no history of any trauma or psychiatric illness. MRI shows marked right temporal anterior atrophy, particularly involving the right anterior fusiform and Parahippocampal gyrus. The frontal and parietal lobes were relatively spared. True regarding frontotemporal dementia, are all except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Rapid onset static course

  • It is a false statement.
  • Frontotemporal disorders (FTD), sometimes called frontotemporal dementia, result from damage to neurons in the frontal and temporal lobes of the Brain. Many possible symptoms can result, including unusual behaviors, emotional problems, trouble communicating, difficulty with work, or difficulty with walking.
  • The frontotemporal dementias have a progressive course and not a static course.
  • It is usually of early onset (45 -65 years)
  • The patient presents with behavioral symptoms with relative preservation of memory.
  • It has three distinctive clinical presentations-
  1. Frontal variant
  2. Semantic dementia
  3. Progressive Non-fluent aphasia
  • There's no cure for frontotemporal dementia or medication that will slow it down. But some medications can help regulate some symptoms, probably for several years.
  • The frontal lobe has Broca's area. Damage to Broca's area causes Broken words. Therefore, non-fluent aphasia as it is the motor area of speech. Temporal part damage cause dementia. The temporal lobe is the Temple of memory.
  • The diagnosis of FRONTOTEMPORAL DEGENERATION (FTD) generally involves a medical narrative and comprehensive neurological examination.
  • The neuropsychological examination evaluates language, behavior, memory, executive, and visual-spatial purposes.
  • Neuroimaging is done to deduce where and how largely brain regions have atrophied.
  • People with FTD generally live six to eight years with their situation, periodically longer, occasionally less. Most people die of problems related to progressive diseases.

Option A: Semantic dementia

  • It is a true statement.
  • It is one of the distinctive features of frontotemporal dementia.

Option B: Non-fluent aphasia

  • It is a true statement.
  • It is a common presentation of frontotemporal dementia.
  • The frontal lobe has Broca's area. Damage to Broca's area caused Broken words. Therefore, non-fluent aphasia as it is the motor area of speech. Temporal part damage cause dementia. The temporal lobe is the Temple of Memory.

Option C: Apathetic, disinhibited personality

  • It is a true statement.
  • An apathetic and disinhibited personality is a classic feature of frontotemporal dementia

questions.text: A 37 year old male patient claims that after 10 years of his marriage and satisfactory sex life, he cannot get an erection with his wife since the last 6 months. He doesn't have any extramarital affairs . He doesn't have any chronic medical illness like HTN/DM/Thyroid diseases. The consultant doctor checks which one of the following and says it's a psychological problem that he has ?
questions.solution:
• Presence of early morning erections and erection during REM sleep (nocturnal erection) are suggestive of psychogenic erectile dysfunction as there is no anxiety.
  • Whereas, a patient with organic erectile dysfunction (due to vascular or neurological causes) would not have erections even during sleep.
  • Investigations, such as penile plethysmography and nocturnal penile intumescence (NPT) can be used to record nocturnal erections.

HOW TO REMEMBER: imagine a romantic night with full moon. Moon shines bright in night when there are no clouds. Penis rises(erects) at night when there is no organic cause.

questions.text: Child Tej's parents noticed his hyperactivity, impulsivity, and difficulty following orders when he was three. His parents attempted everything they could to keep his conduct under control, including confining him in his crib, verbally punishing him, and spanking him on occasion. He was regularly suspended from school and forced to relocate from one school to the next during his pre-school years because he couldn't sit still, couldn't wait for his turn, and continually disrupted other pupils in the class. He is now six years old and remains the same. What treatment options are available for Tej?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above​​​​​​​

  • In children with ADHD, stimulants are the favored class of medicines.
  • For youngsters with ADHD, the medicine of choice is Methylphenidate.
  • Atomoxetine is an ADHD medication that also has some antidepressant properties.

ADHD:

  • Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder that presents in childhood with symptoms such as impulsivity, hyperactivity, and inattention.
  • A core feature of this disorder is that symptoms must impair social, occupational, or academic performance.
  • The diagnosis of ADHD may be established at any age, though core symptoms must have been present prior to the patient's 12th birthday.
  • Management of ADHD is multimodal and typically consists of stimulants (e.g., methylphenidate) in combination with behavioral and school-based interventions.
  • ADHD is associated with adverse long-term consequences including impaired educational and occupational performance and higher rates of substance use and personality disorders.

Option A: Amphetamine

  • Amphetamine is used in ADHD.
  • Other mentioned drugs are also used in ADHD
  • So, alone, amphetamine is not the right choice.

Option B: Modafinil

  • Modafinil is used in ADHD.
  • Other mentioned drugs are also used in ADHD
  • So, alone Modafinil is not the right choice.

Option C: Methylphenidate

  • Methylphenidate is used in ADHD.
  • Other mentioned drugs are also used in ADHD
  • So, alone Methylphenidate is not a right choice

questions.text: A patient is presenting to the emergency room with abrupt onset of motor symptoms. The neurology resident is unable to correlate the presentation and a concrete neurological diagnosis. It also appears that the patient is not very concerned about his own symptoms. This is called:
questions.solution:
La belle indifference

  • Inappropriate attitude of calm or lack of concern about one's disability
  • Seen in Dissociative or conversion disorders
  • Here, the neurology resident is unable to correlate the presentation indicating Conversion disorder and the patient is not very concerned towards his own symptoms indicating La belle indifference.

Labile Affect

  • Rapid and abrupt changes in emotion largely unrelated to external stimuli
  • Most commonly seen in mania

Affective blunting

  • Severe reduction in the intensity of affect
  • Seen in Schizophrenia

Incongruent affect

  • Patient may be feeling depressed or describe a depressive theme but do so with laughter, smiling and no suggestion of sadness
  • Seen in schizophrenia

Learning Objective

Dissociative Disorders

  • Dissociation or disruption in normally integrated functions of memory, identity, perception, consciousness or motor behaviour.
  • Unconscious symptoms to escape reality or deal with anxiety
  • Usually sudden in onset, associated with a psychological stressor

Dissociative Functional Neurological Disorder / Conversion Disorder:

  • Motor, sensory or cognitive deficit
  • No physical cause
  • Caused by psychological causes
  • La Belle indifference: Lack of concern or indifference to symptom
